  「那個女孩兒醒來了。」林醫生著重地看向周澤，「他父親要請我們科室的人吃晚餐，在通城大飯店，你也一起來吧。」



  「我去做什麼。」



  「女孩兒醒來後一直喊叔叔。」林醫生有些好奇地問周澤，「你和她之前就認識？」



  「人哪怕是在昏迷的時候，也是有感知的吧。」周澤繼續胡謅，「我救她的時候，她可能其實能感覺的到。」



  「去麼？」林醫生問道。



  「不去了。」周澤搖搖頭，「我不餓，一點胃口都沒有。」



  林醫生點點頭，沒繼續強求，她似乎準備走了，但走到書店門口，她又停下了腳步，「今晚，你回家麼？」



  又回到了熟悉的老問題，



  我回家了你又不陪我睡……



  所以，周澤很果斷地回答：



  「不回去了，最近有些忙。」



  嗯，雖然店裡的生意已經冷清成冰拿鐵了。



  林醫生猶豫了一下，沒強求，從口袋裡取出車鑰匙準備離開。



  就在這時， 



  「哐當」一聲響，



  林醫生轉過身，看見自己的「丈夫」已經趴倒在了書架上，書架上的書滾落了一地。



  「你怎麼了？」林醫生馬上走過來查看周澤的情況。



  周澤感知到自己眼睛開始泛花，視線難以聚焦，自己的胸口一陣起伏，同時腳下一陣發軟，剛剛像是踩在了棉花上一樣徹底失去了重心：



  「餓暈了……」



  周澤回答道。



  他，



  已經幾天沒吃過飯了。



  ————————、



  發書五天，同期新書總榜第二！



  靈異分類，除了沒上架不能投月票的月票榜以外，咱們其他榜單全是第一！



  昨日，日銷起點第二名！今天日銷起點第十一名！



  作為一本三萬字沒上架的新書，龍只想說，



  兄弟們，



  牛逼！

title: 第十一章 畫皮
content:
Next to the bookstore was a noodle shop. Business was average, at best—practically as deserted as Zhou Ze’s bookstore.

This was because the pedestrian street had originally been built around a central plaza, but the plaza was now "defunct." Aside from a movie theater, all the other businesses had moved out or shut down. As a result, the entire plaza had become a desolate, "rarely visited" area.

In Tongcheng, at least, the symptoms of overzealous urban development were already showing. A few years ago, commercial centers were planned and built in great numbers, but Tongcheng wasn't Shanghai, after all; it couldn't supply that much foot traffic.

Fortunately, the noodle shop could still do delivery business, and it seemed to be doing quite well. But obviously, no one would suddenly feel mentally "hungry" and order a few books for delivery to chew on.

Zhou Ze leaned back in his chair, still a little dizzy. Dr. Lin sat opposite him, wiping his chopsticks with her own tissue before placing them in front of him.

She was meticulous and considerate, just as she had been when she let Xu Le have the bed while she slept on a floor mat. But at the same time, she was also very cold.

Zhou Ze didn't bother asking if she was genuinely opposed to feudal arranged marriages or if she was just a lesbian. The question was meaningless. Zhou Ze himself had no interest in the baffling network of relationships Xu Le had left behind, nor did he feel any attachment to it.

"Are you sure you're okay?" Dr. Lin asked again.

"It's a small problem, a small problem." Zhou Ze was a doctor himself. He knew that his issues with eating and sleeping were difficult to explain with modern medical theory, let alone treat.

Fortunately, his sleeping problem was now taken care of. It was the eating that was a headache.

If he didn't eat, he would pass out again, as he just had. But eating... the very thought made him nauseous.

"If you have no appetite, try a bowl of sour plum juice first," the noodle shop owner said. He was around thirty, but his face already had some wrinkles. The burdens of life seemed to weigh heavily on him.

"Sour plum juice, will that work?" Zhou Ze asked helplessly.

"It'll whet your appetite." The noodle shop owner smiled, then called toward the back room, "Honey, is the pickled vegetable noodle soup ready yet?"

The owner walked into the back room, and the sound of the couple talking could be heard.

Zhou Ze looked at the sour plum juice in front of him. He picked up a spoon, scooped a little, and brought it to his lips. The moment he swallowed, his expression changed.

"What's wrong?" Dr. Lin pulled out a facial tissue and held it to his chin.

Zhou Ze's face twisted as he clutched his stomach.

Then he took a deep breath and said:

"That's really sour."

Yes, so sour it felt like his whole body was about to seize up, so sour it even overpowered the nausea.

"Coming, the noodles are here." The owner's wife walked over carrying a bowl of noodles. She set it down in front of Zhou Ze and said, "You can't drink our sour plum juice that fast."

Dr. Lin glanced at the noodles and frowned slightly. "These noodles... they're way too mushy."

Meaning they had been cooked for too long and had lost their firmness, which would greatly affect the texture.

"Well... our noodles are just like that," the owner's wife said, a look of shame on her face.

"It's fine, it's fine."

Zhou Ze waved his hand. Mushy or not, firm or not, it didn't matter to him right now. As long as he could get it down, that was all that mattered. He needed energy. If he couldn't eat, Zhou Ze's only option was to go to a hospital for a glucose drip.

With great solemnity, he lifted his head, feeling as dignified as a warrior on a suicide mission. Then he abruptly lowered it and poured the entire bowl of unimaginably sour plum juice into his mouth in one go.

*Hiss...*

That invigorating sourness...

It was like pouring sulfuric acid into his stomach.

But immediately after, Zhou Ze grabbed his chopsticks, scooped up the noodles, and shoved them into his mouth. He wolfed them down as fast as he could. In five or six bites, the entire bowl of noodles was in his stomach. Then he lifted the bowl and gulped down all the broth.

*Huuuh...*

*Clack!*

Zhou Ze set the empty bowl down.

He let out a long breath. He'd eaten!

The next moment, Zhou Ze reached up and clutched his chest. The nausea, which had been suppressed by the sour plum juice, came rushing back. But the food was already in his stomach. Zhou Ze practically had to choke himself with both hands to keep from throwing it all up.

Not throwing up was a success.

He had finally,

finally,

eaten something.

Beads of sweat had formed on Zhou Ze's forehead. He grabbed a napkin from the table and wiped them away.

At that moment,

both Dr. Lin and the owner's wife were staring at him, stunned. The way Zhou Ze had just eaten was simply too horrifying.

"Hehe, looks like you were really hungry. Want another bowl?" the owner's wife asked.

"No, no, that's alright," Zhou Ze declined.

"Alright then." The owner's wife cleared away the bowl and chopsticks in front of Zhou Ze and called to the back room, "Honey, get the dough for the afternoon ready. The delivery orders should start coming in soon."

The owner's wife went inside. Her figure couldn't be called graceful, merely average-looking, but her full chest and well-defined backside added a special kind of charm, making her surprisingly attractive.

"You like... that type?" Dr. Lin asked.

Zhou Ze had been watching the owner's wife until she disappeared into the back room.

"No." Zhou Ze shook his head. *I actually like your type, but you won't let me sleep with you.*

Zhou Ze was slightly startled by his own thought. The idea of "not being allowed to sleep with her" had been in his mind for a long time, almost becoming an obsession. He had to admit, Dr. Lin was truly beautiful, and young too.

Even though she was Xu Le's wife,

even though Zhou Ze had never been married in his past life,

if he were being honest with himself,

he still wanted to sleep with her.

It was precisely because he couldn't that he was so fixated on it, that she was so often on his mind.

"Not going home?" Dr. Lin asked again.

"Not going back," Zhou Ze confirmed.

"Then I'm leaving." Dr. Lin stood up. "Call me if you need anything."

After all, he was her husband in name, even if there was no substance to their marriage.

"Alright." Zhou Ze nodded. *If I'd known you were this easy to talk to and this considerate, I really should have asked to borrow some money when I was broke.*

Dr. Lin left, driving away in her Porsche Cayenne.

Zhou Ze, however, remained seated in the noodle shop. His bookstore was right next door. Even though he'd finished his noodles, it was fine to sit and chat for a bit. They were neighbors, after all.

The owner came out from the back room and handed Zhou Ze a cigarette.

"How much?" Zhou Ze asked.

"Don't be a stranger. I can afford to treat you to a bowl of noodles, brother." The owner waved his hand magnanimously. They were neighbors who would see each other all the time; no need to create distance over a bowl of noodles.

"Your wife won't get mad?" Zhou Ze asked.

"She won't. She's just a woman, what does she know? It's not her place to talk," the noodle shop owner said, his machismo radiating off him.

A man, regardless of his status at home, always had to put on a bit of a show in public. No one wanted to admit they were afraid of their wife, just as no one wanted to admit they couldn't perform in bed.

"Hehe, your wife is very pretty," Zhou Ze said.

Joking about another man's wife was taboo. If two men were facing outward, joking about some woman walking down the street, that was just fun banter between men.

The owner paused for a second but said nothing, just smiled. He had a good temper. People who run small businesses generally understand that harmony brings wealth.

"Her figure is excellent," Zhou Ze continued. "Solid, full of flavor. Just like the noodles I just ate."

The owner took a deep drag from his cigarette.

"How is she in bed?" Zhou Ze asked, pushing his luck even further this time.

The owner's fist clenched slightly, but he quickly relaxed and said nonchalantly, "Oh, her legs... they could squeeze a man to death. So powerful!"

Zhou Ze smiled.

The owner smiled too.

"Can you handle it?" Zhou Ze asked again. "She's at that age where she wants it, right?"

The owner rubbed his lower back. "Can't handle it anymore. Not a young man anymore."

"Well then, how about you let me have a try?" Zhou Ze asked again.

The owner's face completely darkened.

His knuckles cracked as he squeezed his fist.

"If you can't, I can. I'm still young," Zhou Ze said to himself, though the words were somewhat disingenuous. Xu Le's body, for all its youth, had the feel of a silver spear with a wax tip. It wasn't nearly as well-maintained as Zhou Ze's own body from his previous life.

"Isn't this joke going a bit too far?" The owner was still suppressing his anger.

"What if your wife agrees?" Zhou Ze continued.

"Was that your wife just now?" the owner asked, changing the subject.

"Yeah," Zhou Ze nodded.

"Would you be willing to give her up?" the owner asked.

Zhou Ze hesitated, then shook his head. Even though she was Xu Le's wife, she was his in name now. Zhou Ze was unwilling.

"Then what makes you think I'd be willing?" the owner retorted.

"Who knows, maybe you have some special tastes or unusual kinks? That kind of thing isn't so rare these days, is it?"

"Brother, it's been a long time since I've hit someone." The owner stood up.

"Call your wife out. Ask her. I want to hear her say whether she's willing or not." Zhou Ze leaned back slightly, smiling.

"Heh." The owner took a few steps closer to Zhou Ze.

"You stand here and call her out," Zhou Ze insisted.

"You're asking to die!" The owner lunged forward.

"Can she come out?" Zhou Ze asked suddenly.

The owner froze.

Then a look of terror appeared on his face, and he stumbled back several steps in fear.

Zhou Ze stood up and walked toward the back room himself. He pushed aside the curtain. The room was empty.

There was only a human skin, a woman's skin,

hanging on a clothes hanger.

As the curtain was pushed aside, a breeze entered,

making it flutter gently,

drifting slowly.

"How... did you figure it out?" the owner asked, slowly walking over. His voice betrayed neither joy nor anger.

"There's a saying... Are you trying to fool a ghost?" Zhou Ze turned around and looked at the owner. "This layer of skin you're wearing, shouldn't you be tearing it off now?

I'm very curious,

just how bored are you,

to be here,

putting on this kind of two-man act."

title: 第十二章 立意！
content:
The boss smiled, not feeling the least bit provoked. He just found it a little amusing.

A person's disposition and their aura are often more credible than their words.

"Riiip..."

A crisp, somewhat drawn-out sound, like a snake shedding its skin, echoed as he began to tear off his own.

At the same time, the boss's frame and skeleton began to shrink, his physique slowly thinning out, like a balloon with a small hole in it, gradually deflating.

Zhou Ze now finally understood why that bowl of noodles had been so overcooked.

This kind of "transformation" of his really did require some time.

He was still wearing the boss's clothes, complete with the apron, but the face had changed into that of a slightly greenhorn youth.

The youth had a smile on his lips, his charm seemingly innate. The curve extending from the corner of his eye, in particular, seemed capable of scratching that itch deep in the hearts of any man or woman nearby—just right, perfectly pitched.

To describe a man as "charming" or "coquettish"[^1] is somewhat incongruous, but some men are indeed born with a seductive charm. Take the ancient emperors, for instance; countless among them had a preference for male companionship. The reason being that some men are, in fact, more like women than women themselves.

"Am I pretty?" the youth asked Zhou Ze.

Zhou Ze felt the nausea he had suppressed after eating the noodles surge up again. He waved a hand apologetically, then clutched his chest, striking a pose that said, *I can't throw up.*

*Who knows that of the meal in the dish, every grain comes from hard toil!*

Zhou Ze knew how to cherish food, especially food he had managed to swallow and was about to digest into energy for his body.

The youth sat down on a nearby chair, a lighter in his hand, which he casually flipped and twirled.

He was sizing up Zhou Ze, because Zhou Ze had discovered him. He had thought his imitation was seamless, and given that this was a small diner, he didn't think there would be any problems.

Most importantly, he was imitating his own parents.

Ever since he was young, he had been observing his parents. Their every move, every expression, was already etched into his heart.

"How did you find out it was me?" the youth couldn't help but ask.

"You're not a ghost?" Zhou Ze asked at the same time.

The youth frowned slightly. He thought Zhou Ze was mocking him, accusing him of playing pretend and making things needlessly mysterious.

But in reality, Zhou Ze had assumed he was a ghost from the very beginning.

Zhou Ze didn't want to meddle in other people's business. As someone who, not long ago, was fretting over the cost of a freezer, Zhou Ze didn't think he had the right to meddle.

But this was business he couldn't ignore.

This business was happening right next door.

So Zhou Ze felt that, no matter what, it was best to expose the matter first. If it was easy to solve, he'd solve it himself. If it wasn't, he could always just move again.

"Your fingernails," Zhou Ze said. "I'm a bit sensitive when it comes to fingernails."

When the proprietress brought the noodles to him, and when the boss personally handed him a cigarette, their fingernails had both been on full display.

Although the thickness, fairness, and calluses of their fingers were different, the patterns on their nail beds were identical.

And recently, Zhou Ze had been paying even more attention to fingernails—not just his own, but others' as well.

The youth's eyes narrowed slightly. He felt a sense of loss. The details hadn't been perfect.

Although he had been careless, the fact that he was discovered was indeed his own oversight.

"You're really not a ghost?" Zhou Ze asked again.

If he was human, then that was truly outrageous.

In truth, Zhou Ze hadn't seen many ghosts. Not counting his journey in Hell, the number of ghosts he had seen in the mortal realm could be counted on one hand.

"Painted Skin is my family's ancestral art," the youth said, standing up. He reached out, grabbed Zhou Ze's hand, and placed it on his own chest. "It's just that the line was broken for many generations. It was only with my generation that it could be picked up again."

The gesture was a bit ambiguous, a bit out of line, but Zhou Ze still subconsciously gave a squeeze.

Zhou Ze would never believe it was because Dr. Lin hadn't let him sleep with her that he was now developing an interest in men.

Of course, the man before him was indeed more coquettish than a woman. That was a fact.

"No bones?" An expression of surprise appeared on Zhou Ze's face. "No, it's rickets."

Rickets, also known as osteomalacia, is caused by a calcium deficiency that hinders bone calcification, making the bones soft and easily deformed. Zhou Ze used to be a doctor, so he naturally knew a little about it. But just as a single cold can have many variations and different pathologies, rickets also has many sub-categories. The young man before him was likely an extreme case.

According to unofficial histories from the Spring and Autumn period, a prince from the State of Lu suffered from this disease. He was said to be boneless, his body pliant. He could walk like a person, but also crawl like a snake.

"You can think of it as a genetic disease. It requires a certain probability to manifest. For many generations before me, my family couldn't practice Painted Skin because they didn't have this disease. But I..."

The youth smiled, not finishing his sentence.

"So, you're really not a ghost?" Zhou Ze was still not convinced.

"My name is Xu Qinglang," the youth replied very seriously.

"And who were you imitating?" Zhou Ze asked.

"My dad and my mom."

Zhou Ze froze for a moment, a wry smile appearing on his face.

Well then.

This was a huge misunderstanding.

Earlier, after he'd finished his noodles and Miss Lin had left, Zhou Ze had intended to expose him, deliberately provoking him with his words. But he never expected that the guy was just playing role-play here out of boredom, commemorating his deceased parents.

But from Zhou Ze's perspective before, he had just assumed that this was a ghost, a ghost like in the story "Painted Skin," who had killed people, skinned them, and was now parading around in their guise.

"Then... my apologies."

Making fun of your mother... that really is a bit embarrassing.

"I'm not angry," Xu Qinglang said. "But I am very curious. What did you mean by insisting I was a ghost?"

"It was nothing."

"Have you seen a ghost?" Xu Qinglang asked.

"I am a ghost," Zhou Ze said, looking at Xu Qinglang very seriously.

His expression was stern, his features solemn.

He was baring his soul.

Xu Qinglang's face froze.

Then, he couldn't stop himself from bursting out with a "Pfft" of laughter.

The way he looked at Zhou Ze...

Was as if he were looking at an imbecile.

Zhou Ze nodded. Sometimes, that's just how it is. You tell them the truth, and they think you're joking. They just won't believe you.

"Anyway, I'm sorry. By the way, I wanted to ask, was that human skin... real human skin?" Zhou Ze asked curiously.

"Fish skin," Xu Qinglang replied. "Processed, painted, and crafted."

"Then why are you selling noodles?" Zhou Ze couldn't quite understand. "I heard that a single piece of snake-skin clothing from the Hezhen people can sell for a lot of money, sold as art. Yours should be even more valuable, right?"

"It's an ancestral craft. I can't bring myself to use it for profit."

"Then you must be very rich," Zhou Ze said.

"My family's property was just part of a demolition and relocation project," Xu Qinglang didn't answer directly. "We got over twenty apartments in compensation."

"..." Zhou Ze took a deep breath.

So, the world really is this unfair. In his past life, he worked himself to the bone at the hospital and barely earned anything, while this guy casually ends up with over twenty apartments.

Tongcheng couldn't compare to Shanghai, but housing prices were still close to ten thousand yuan per square meter.

A second-generation nouveau riche from demolition... Truly enviable.

Zhou Ze shook his head. "Are you going to keep making noodles in the future?"

"Are you going to keep selling books in the future?"

The two of them asked each other a question at the same time again.

"I'll see how it goes for now," Zhou Ze replied.

"Same here."

"Well then, see you around. By the way, does your plum juice come in other flavors?" Zhou Ze was very curious about this. "Like bitter melon? Or grape?"

"I have the secret recipes. I can make them," Xu Qinglang said honestly.

"Excellent." Zhou Ze reached out and patted Xu Qinglang on the shoulder.

Damn it.

It was like cotton.

So soft. He was truly pliant, truly boneless. If you were to hold him in your arms in bed...

Zhou Ze immediately conjured an image of Dr. Lin emerging from the shower in her pajamas in his mind, forcefully suppressing that discordant thought.

Zhou Ze walked out of the noodle shop.

Xu Qinglang went into the back room, lifted the curtain, and said to the woman's skin hanging there:

"Mom, do you think he really believed me, or was he faking it?"

The woman's skin swayed gently.

It swayed ever so slightly.

As if to say, *he didn't believe you*.

Or as if to say, *she didn't know either*.

...

Zhou Ze returned to his shop. The freezer was already set up. The next step was to overhaul the broken-down bookstore Xu Le had left behind. Letting it continue to lose money like this was not a solution.

The sign at the entrance of the bookstore read "Xu Le Bookstore." It was as tacky as tacky could be.

In short, in that guy's hands, this bookstore, from top to bottom, inside and out, exuded an aura of "guaranteed to lose money."

Zhou Ze sat down at the computer and tried several times to log into his original QQ account, but he couldn't. He couldn't pass the identity verification, and filing an appeal was basically impossible.

Afterward, Zhou Ze had no choice but to go out and hail a taxi. He planned to get a new sign, or maybe a pair of couplets for the doorway.

He knew someone who owned a plaque shop, specializing in carved wooden plaques. The owner was an old man who often donated to that orphanage. Back when Zhou Ze himself was a member of the orphanage, the old man was already donating. After Zhou Ze started working, the old man and Zhou Ze donated together.

The plaque shop wasn't far, located at the foot of Langshan Mountain. It was surrounded on all sides by shops selling incense and candles; only this one sold plaques.

However, when Zhou Ze walked in, he found the shop in the middle of a major cleaning. Even the main plaque had been taken down.

A middle-aged man was there, directing workers.

"Can I help you?" the man asked when he saw Zhou Ze approach.

"I'm looking for Old Mr. Zhao," Zhou Ze said. He held the old man in high esteem.

"I'm sorry, my father passed away last month," the middle-aged man replied.

"Passed away?" Zhou Ze was a bit surprised, and also a bit saddened. He and Old Mr. Zhao weren't actually close; they just knew of each other. So, it was perfectly normal that he wasn't notified of the funeral.

Besides, it was possible that Old Mr. Zhao's family, seeing him donate all the income from his plaque-making to the orphanage, naturally held no goodwill towards the orphanage. They might not have even notified the orphanage of the funeral, afraid they would come asking them for money.

"Are you here to order a plaque?" the middle-aged man asked.

"Yes," Zhou Ze nodded.

"Our family... we're not making them anymore," the middle-aged man said apologetically. "From now on, we're selling incense and candles."

Langshan Mountain is one of the ten minor Buddhist holy mountains. Even if it didn't attract tourists from afar, the locals who came to burn incense and pray during holidays were enough to let the shops at the foot of the mountain make a fortune.

This was another way of living off the mountain.

"That's a shame," Zhou Ze said, feeling a bit regretful.

He decided he would go visit the old man's gravestone.

"But we still have a few plaques my dad made before. They didn't sell. I don't know why my dad carved them; they weren't custom orders. If you like any of them, I'll sell them to you cheap." The middle-aged man was thinking of getting rid of them like scrap.

"Alright, I'll take a look," Zhou Ze agreed.

He followed the middle-aged man into a small courtyard in the back. The man opened a storeroom and switched on the light.

Inside were some miscellaneous items, including Old Mr. Zhao's crafting tools, all piled up in disarray, signifying that the younger generation had no intention of inheriting the craft.

Nowadays, everyone wanted illuminated signs. Who would want to use these? It was hard work and didn't even make much money.

"Whoosh..." The middle-aged man blew a breath of air at the few plaques on the floor. "Take a look. Two hundred yuan apiece. If you see one you like, you can take it. If not, no big deal."

Clearly, the middle-aged man wasn't very confident he could sell these plaques.

Zhou Ze walked over to take a look.

The first plaque read:

"Life and death are ruled by fate; wealth and honor are decreed by heaven."

Zhou Ze shook his head. The middle-aged man sighed, knowing that one was a no-go.

The next one read:

"Men know the terror of ghosts; ghosts know the poison of human hearts."

Zhou Ze paused for a moment. This one... resonated with him.

The middle-aged man didn't sigh this time, because he knew it was a definite no-go. What kind of shop owner would be crazy enough to hang this at their entrance?

The third one:

"Take it for what it's worth. Thus have I heard."

Zhou Ze smiled.

Seeing Zhou Ze smile, the middle-aged man smiled too.

Finally, one had found a home.

---
[^1]: The original word used is `媚` (mèi), which means coquettish, charming, or seductive, and is typically used to describe women. The text explicitly notes this is an unusual but fitting description for this particular man.

title: 第十三章 第一位顧客！
content:
He brought the plaques back. Zhou Ze planned to nail them up on either side of the door; he didn't care which one went on the left and which on the right.

The young man from next door, Xu Qinglang, was very warmhearted.

He had been squatting by his door peeling garlic, but when he saw Zhou Ze getting ready to hang the plaques, he went right into his own place to get a hammer and nails.

Zhou Ze said thanks and took the hammer. It felt a bit greasy and heavy in his hand. Suppressing a slight sense of discomfort, Zhou Ze still nailed the two plaques up.

Afterward, the two of them stepped back a few paces together, looking at the plaques, at the door, at the bookstore.

Zhou Ze handed Xu Qinglang a cigarette as a thank you. Xu Qinglang lit it for him.

They both exhaled rings of smoke, in perfect sync.

"It's got atmosphere, don't you think?" Zhou Ze said, a classic case of tooting his own horn.

Xu Qinglang shook his head. "If I'm not mistaken, those two lines are from the chapter titles of Ji Yun's *Notes from the Thatched Abode of Close Scrutiny*."

*Notes from the Thatched Abode of Close Scrutiny* is a collection of stories written by Ji Yun, also known as Ji Xiaolan, similar to *Strange Stories from a Chinese Studio*. It uses tales of fox spirits, ghosts, and monsters to express the author's own ideas.

To put it simply, the couplet meant: *These are all just stories I've heard, so everyone here should just take them as such.*

"Mm," Zhou Ze nodded.

"Still too artsy. This shop of yours is still going to lose money," Xu Qinglang's assessment was blunt.

"Why?"

"In this world, there are too many stories. All sorts of bizarre things happen every day, but not many of them are actually interesting.

Some things are boring when you tell them.

Some things, you're not allowed to talk about at all.

Some things, no one will listen to unless you change them.

And some things, people don't dare to listen to unless you change them."

Zhou Ze stared at Xu Qinglang for a long moment.

Xu Qinglang lowered his head slightly, a blush spreading across his face.

He was a man who naturally exuded a flirtatious charm, and at this moment, he looked exquisitely beautiful.

Seeing that Zhou Ze wasn't speaking, Xu Qinglang continued:

"Take these tales of mountain spirits, fox fairies, ghosts, and monsters, for example. Where would you ever really find them in the real world?" Xu Qinglang yawned. "How true can the morals be when they're hidden in fake stories?"

Zhou Ze continued to stare at Xu Qinglang, not saying a word.

Xu Qinglang started to feel his scalp tingle under the intense gaze.

But Zhou Ze kept on staring at him.

Finally, Xu Qinglang waved his hand dismissively, saying he had to go back to make his soup base. As he walked back to his noodle shop, he felt as if there were needles on his back, because just now, it had felt as though Zhou Ze wasn't looking at him, but at a joke.

Zhou Ze paid Xu Qinglang no mind. Since they were neighbors, it was best to just let well water not mix with river water. They weren't in competition anyway, and most importantly, Zhou Ze didn't have the money to move to a new shop.

In the afternoon, Zhou Ze sorted through most of the textbooks and study guides in the bookstore and had a scrap collector take them away for the price of waste paper.

He also went to the supermarket and bought ten small plastic chairs. The only two remaining bookshelves were filled with books that Zhou Ze himself found somewhat interesting.

At this point, it was less a bookstore and more a recreational center for the elderly.

Zhou Ze stretched. He wasn't very good at running a business. Right now, he was just messing around aimlessly. After all, Xu Le had been constantly losing money when he was around, so there was no pressure on him.

Going up to the small second floor, Zhou Ze turned on the freezer's power and set the temperature. He smoked a cigarette outside while waiting for a bit, then reached into the freezer to feel it.

The temperature was about right. Zhou Ze lay down inside it.

A freezer that cost over ten thousand yuan naturally had many functions, for instance, a timer setting, which served as Zhou Ze's alarm clock.

He closed the freezer lid.

Zhou Ze placed his hands on his abdomen and lay perfectly straight.

It looked like…

…he had passed away peacefully.

***

Late at night, a red sedan pulled over on the street in front of the bookstore. The entire street was somewhat deserted. Over by the shops, only the adjacent noodle shop and bookstore still had their lights on.

Inside the car sat a well-dressed girl. Black down jacket, shoulder-length hair, looking rather cute and delicate.

"Xiao Bai, you bastard! I prepared for three days, and today you tell me you've gone on a business trip! You can just go to hell! Get lost!"

The girl hung up the phone and sat fuming in the driver's seat.

The corgi in the passenger seat jumped onto the girl's lap. Its coat was lustrous and flowing; one look was enough to tell it was a good breed and very well cared for.

"Good boy. At least I still have you with me."

The girl lit a cigarette, stuck her hand out the window, and flicked the ash. Her gaze drifted outside and she saw the bookstore. More importantly, through the glass window, she could see that the furnishings inside were a bit unusual—not many bookshelves, but rows of plastic stools instead.

Getting out of the car, the girl walked toward the bookstore, holding her corgi. She didn't want to spend this Valentine's night driving around aimlessly by herself. She wanted to find a quiet place to sit for a while.

The bookstore door was unlocked. Stepping inside, she could feel the warmth from the air conditioner.

The girl, leading her dog, first picked a random magazine from a shelf, then sat down on one of the plastic chairs.

She let the corgi off its leash, and the little guy began to "explore" the shop.

After finishing the magazine, the girl stretched lightly. Feeling a bit thirsty, she called out:

"Hello? Is the owner here? Do you have milk tea or coffee?"

The girl stood up, put the magazine she was holding back, and picked out an illustrated version of *Dream of the Red Chamber*. By the time she sat down again, she couldn't help but shout once more:

"Owner! It's the middle of the night, are you dead or something? Is this any way to run a shop?"

The bookstore's glass door had a small sign hanging on it that read "Open for Business, Welcome." The door was open, and the heat was on; it was definitely still open.

If the girl had been a little less polite or a little more curious at that moment and had gone up to the second floor to take a look, she might have been impressed at how her words had become a prophecy.

In the low-ceilinged space of the second floor, there was indeed a freezer.

The owner was lying inside, looking just like a dead person.

No, the owner *was* a dead person.

Of course, the girl probably wouldn't have had time to admire her own prescience before being scared out of her wits.

A normal person enters a shop late at night only to find the owner lying in a frozen coffin... pretty terrifying, right?

The girl lit another cigarette, growing impatient, and took out her phone to play with it.

At that moment, the sound of footsteps came from the top of the stairs. Zhou Ze hadn't gotten up because he heard the girl's shouts; he had woken up naturally.

Just as he came down the stairs, Zhou Ze saw a small yellow figure dart over to his leg, asking to be held.

Zhou Ze smiled and bent down, scooping the corgi into his arms. The little guy wasn't shy with strangers, acting familiar with everyone.

Only then did Zhou Ze notice the woman sitting in the shop.

Oh. The first customer since the reopening.

But he wasn't as excited as he might have imagined, because all Zhou Ze had done today was change the bookstore's signs and clean up the interior; he still hadn't figured out how he was going to make money.

"Do you have coffee here, owner?" the girl asked.

Zhou Ze pointed a finger at a water cooler in the corner. There were disposable paper cups by it.

The girl looked a bit resigned, but she got up anyway, poured herself a glass of water, and sat back down on her plastic stool.

Owner and customer, facing each other in silence.

After about half an hour of silence, the girl started scrolling through Weibo and watching videos. One video was very loud and boisterous:

"Step right up, ladies and gentlemen, don't miss out!

Spirit money, blessed by yours truly, the Old Taoist! Limited supply!

You can burn it now and withdraw it for use when you go down below! You'll even earn interest, higher than Yu'e Bao!¹

You can also burn it for your relatives down below! Fast and convenient, no swindling of old or young, the ghost bailiffs won't bother you, and there's no skimming off the top!"

The girl laughed when she saw the video. People usually have a habit of wanting to share when they find something funny. She looked up at the owner sitting behind the counter and said:

"Owner, have you seen this video? This Old Taoist's livestream is pretty famous. He's practically an internet celebrity."

"Oh, a livestream?" Zhou Ze took out his phone. On Xu Le's phone, there were quite a few livestreaming apps. It seemed the guy had been really bored in his daily life, either watching livestreams or writing a sequel to *Bai Jie*.²

"Yeah, search for his ID. It's hilarious. I think he runs a spirit money shop in Rongcheng, but he hasn't streamed in a long time."

Zhou Ze opened an app and searched for the Old Taoist's ID as the girl suggested. He found a stream room—"The streamer is not home."

But luckily, he could watch past recordings. Zhou Ze randomly clicked on a video from a month ago.

In the video, the Old Taoist had his phone fixed in one spot and was practicing martial arts. His punches had force; you could tell he was a trained practitioner. In the frame, a young man was sitting there, a smile on his lips and his eyes narrowed, as if he were watching a monkey show.

Zhou Ze casually scrubbed through the video. Another man appeared on screen, sitting behind the counter, holding a spoon, looking like he was eating congee.

The Old Taoist was chattering away in the main frame, endlessly promoting himself and the spirit money he sold on Taobao, but Zhou Ze's gaze was subconsciously drawn to the man in the corner of the video.

He was frowning, he was suffering, he was in pain, he was resisting.

One mouthful of congee, he ate it with great difficulty.

Then he continued with a second mouthful, as if he were being tortured.

Watching this, Zhou Ze took a deep breath, as if he himself had been infected by the man in the corner of the video.

Eating... really isn't an easy thing to do.

He didn't know the identity of the man in the video but was instinctively intrigued. Was he anorexic? Or did he have some kind of gastrointestinal disease?

After the video ended, Zhou Ze opened the page. On a whim, he used the still-logged-in account of Xu Le to send the Old Taoist a private message:

"Who was the man sitting in the background eating congee in your video?"

"Hey, I'm leaving. How much is it?" The girl stood up and stretched. "If I tell anyone about this, they'll definitely think I'm an idiot. I spent Valentine's night sitting in a bookstore reading *Dream of the Red Chamber* for so long."

"Pay what you think is fair," Zhou Ze said.

The girl glanced at Zhou Ze. "Owner, you've got a good routine here. Just like those masters in temples who interpret fortune sticks. The sign by the cushions says 'Free Fortune Readings,' but after the tourist gets their fortune read, the master pulls out a red donation ledger. It's filled with a long list of names and donation amounts, and the lowest one is a hundred."

Zhou Ze just smiled, noncommittally.

The girl took out a hundred-yuan bill, placed it on the chair she had been sitting on, then left with her corgi, pushing open the bookstore door.

Zhou Ze stood up and collected the hundred-yuan bill. He flicked it in his hand.

A crisp snap.

One of the most wonderful sounds in the world.

When he walked back to the counter, Zhou Ze saw his phone screen light up. He opened his phone and saw there was actually a reply. It was a private message from the Old Taoist. The reply was very simple:

"Gone!"
***
¹ Yu'e Bao is a high-yield money market fund offered by Alipay, a major Chinese digital payment platform.
² *Bai Jie* is a well-known work of Chinese internet erotica.

title: 第十四章 過年了！
content:
Only one customer the entire evening. Total income: one hundred yuan. The only cost: a single glass of water.

Of course, you could argue there were also costs like electricity and rent...

But that’s not how you should look at it. Back when Xu Le was around, those were costs too, but his income was practically negligible. A person has to find the right point of comparison to feel a little satisfaction and confidence in life.

Also, it was only because of that girl with the Corgi that Zhou Ze even realized today was Valentine's Day.

He scrolled through WeChat, found Dr. Lin's contact, and tapped on it. Zhou Ze wanted to send her a red envelope. He tried to send 1314 but realized he didn't have enough money.¹ He had enough for 131.4, but sending that would just seem cheap.

*Besides, it's not like she's sleeping with me.*

*Forget it.*

*Not sending it.*

Tossing his phone aside, Zhou Ze grabbed a random book and flipped through it, holding that pose until morning.

He went next door for wontons. Whether the wrappers were thin or the filling was generous, Zhou Ze couldn't tell. He ate them the same way as before: after downing a large bowl of sour plum juice, he immediately scarfed them down. Then he clutched his throat, taking deep, continuous breaths to suppress the urge to vomit.

The thought that every meal from now on would follow this same routine cast a shadow over his future.

Zhou Ze thought of the man in the video, painfully drinking congee. He felt a wave of sorrow. Eating was once one of life's greatest pleasures, but now, it was lost to them.

He wondered if there was an "Anorexics' Club" somewhere in the world, where everyone would gather around a table, and whoever managed to eat a bite of food first would get a collective thumbs-up from the rest:

"You're so awesome!²
My XXX is so amazing!"

He took a deep breath. The image was somewhat chilling.

In any case, yesterday's video, including the old Daoist priest and the man drinking congee, felt too distant for Zhou Ze at the moment.

After Valentine's Day came New Year's Eve. Normally, this shopping center would be festooned with lanterns and decorations, brimming with a festive "New Year's atmosphere." But now, it was the same as always—cold and deserted.

It was just like life.

If you've had your moment in the sun, you'll naturally have your time in the shadows.

Zhou Ze remembered when this shopping center first opened; it was all the rage for a time. Now, it was utterly neglected.

Xu Qinglang's business was booming today, likely because many other shops were closed. As someone who insisted on doing deliveries even on New Year's Eve, he naturally raked in more orders. After all, the customers had fewer options.

Delivery drivers in blue, yellow, or red uniforms constantly came and went from his noodle shop. Zhou Ze squatted at the entrance of his own bookstore, smoking a cigarette and sighing with emotion.

That son-of-a-bitch Xu Le. He should have opened a braised chicken joint instead.

In myths and legends, deities were fond of saying, "A day in heaven is a year on earth."

In fact, Zhou Ze felt this was probably right, and it applied to hell just as well.

He remembered when he died in the car crash... no, wait, he remembered being sent into the incinerator for cremation. It must have just been Children's Day on June 1st. And now, in the blink of an eye, it was New Year's Eve.

Half a year had passed so quickly. Life is but a fleeting dream, nothing more than a dazed walk halfway down the road to the underworld.

After smoking quite a few cigarettes and thinking quite a few thoughts, Zhou Ze felt a bit tired. He took out his phone, wanting to see what movies were playing recently. The theater was right next door; he could go there to kill some time.

"Hey, you got any newspapers over there?" Xu Qinglang asked, walking out after a busy spell of sending off the last batch of delivery drivers.

"What for?"

"To paper the walls," Xu Qinglang replied.

"That frugal?"

"Newspaper on the walls gives it atmosphere, a sense of an era. You didn't sell them all yesterday, did you?"

"There are still some left. Wait, I'll go get them for you."

Zhou Ze went back into the store. On the second floor, next to his freezer, he heaved out a half-man-high stack of newspapers. He brought them downstairs and gave them to Xu Qinglang, who was waiting there.

"You're not going home for the New Year either?" Xu Qinglang asked.

"I'm spending the New Year with my books."

It was a pity Zhou Ze didn't have a goatee or wine in his hand, otherwise he could have drunk a toast to that incredibly classy line.

"You're not going home either, are you?" Zhou Ze asked after a moment of self-satisfaction.

"With over twenty properties, which home am I supposed to go back to?" Xu Qinglang sighed.

"..." said Zhou Ze.

After a moment of silence, Zhou Ze said, "Let me tell you a story."

"Alright." Xu Qinglang nodded, his expression slightly demure. His hair was a little long, and a few strands drooped towards the corner of his mouth. He reached up and gently brushed them away, his gesture so delicate he was truly bashfully charming.

Such charm was not for outsiders to know.

"Once upon a time, also on New Year's Eve, a man on a late-night road ran into the richest man in town.

The rich man was dead drunk.

The man asked the tycoon, 'Why don't you go home?'

The rich man replied, 'Home? Where is my home? My family and relatives aren't by my side. The home you speak of, is it that mansion of mine, the largest in the city?'"

After hearing the story, Xu Qinglang nodded slightly, as if he deeply related.

"Then the man pinned the tycoon to the ground and beat the crap out of him, shouting:

'That'll teach your ass for coming out on New Year's Eve to act all pretentious!'"

Zhou Ze finished the story.

"..." said Xu Qinglang.

Their conversation ended.

Zhou Ze returned to his bookstore. The heat was on, making it warm and cozy. He fiddled with his phone, but there was no one to contact.

He'd thought about visiting the orphanage, but then decided against it. He didn't have much money left.

But just then, a customer arrived. It was a young man in blue work clothes and a hard hat. He pushed open the bookstore door and walked in, asking somewhat shyly:

"Can I read books here? How much is it?" The man pursed his lips.

"Go ahead. Pay what you think is fair," Zhou Ze said with a wave of his hand, indicating the man could browse freely.

"That's great. Do you have any novels here?" the young man asked, a bit reservedly. "I like reading novels, the web novel kind."

Zhou Ze pointed to a box behind a bookshelf. "They're all over there."

The man walked over to the box and rummaged through it, looking very pleased. Some of the books were still in their plastic wrap.

"Go ahead and open them. No charge," Zhou Ze said magnanimously.

"Alright, thanks."

The young man unwrapped a web novel, sat down on a plastic stool, and began to read.

As the owner, Zhou Ze sat behind the counter, trimming his nails. The young man just sat there reading. About half an hour later, the young man stood up, took out his cigarettes, and offered one to Zhou Ze.

"It's not a good brand, hope you don't mind."

"Hey, cigarettes are no good to begin with. Why distinguish between good and bad?"

Zhou Ze took the cigarette. The man took one for himself and proactively walked outside the shop door to light up while standing in the cold wind.

This made Zhou Ze, who had been planning to smoke inside, pause for a moment. He decided against it, put the cigarette aside, and continued trimming his nails.

After finishing his smoke outside, the young man came back in. This time, he didn't sit on the plastic stool but leaned against the wall and sat on the floor.

Although the air conditioner was on, the floor tiles were still cold. The young man didn't seem to mind at all, as if he were used to it.

About fifteen minutes later, four more men in clean, well-worn blue work clothes walked up to the shop. The oldest looked to be no more than thirty, while the youngest was perhaps only about seventeen.

The four of them came in together. The young man leaning against the wall waved to them; he must have been the one who called them over.

The newcomers greeted Zhou Ze. He gave a perfunctory reply and went back to trimming his nails.

Zhou Ze decided he needed to buy a professional manicure set. His nails deserved it.

But with deliveries suspended and most physical stores closed, he'd have to put it off for now.

When he looked up again, Zhou Ze saw that all five workers were sitting on the floor, each holding a novel.

He could tell from the covers that they were all web novels, mostly fantasy. One was holding a horror novel, biting his nails as he read, clearly engrossed.

However, Zhou Ze found the man's nail-biting habit hard to condone.

*Only those who know how to cherish their nails know how to cherish life.*

From time to time, someone would laugh while reading, a genuine laugh inspired by the story.

The bookstore was full of people, but it was quiet. There was an occasional small sound, but it wasn't disturbing.

When evening arrived, Xu Qinglang walked in carrying a bowl of dumplings. He entered and said directly:

"Well now, the shop's pretty lively."

Zhou Ze smiled and nodded.

"Brothers, want something to eat?" Xu Qinglang asked the workers sitting in the shop.

They looked at each other, at a loss.

"Forget it, it's on me." Xu Qinglang was, after all, a man with over twenty properties. "It's New Year's, and it's not easy for you guys not to be home. We're all out here trying to make a living. We're brothers, no matter where we're from."

"Well, thank you, boss. May you get rich," the oldest worker said, standing up to thank Xu Qinglang.

"It's what I should do, what I should do."

Xu Qinglang put down Zhou Ze's dumplings and went back to his own shop.

Zhou Ze drank a little of the broth, then forced down two dumplings. That damn Xu Qinglang had forgotten to bring him sour plum juice, so he couldn't eat.

Taking out the cigarettes on the counter, Zhou Ze walked out from behind it.

"When you're done, just grab another. I should have the full sets of whatever I've got here. Anyway, this shop is a money-losing business, so don't be polite with me."

Zhou Ze handed out cigarettes one by one.

The workers accepted them, flattered and overwhelmed.

Then they all got up and went outside the shop door, squatting in a row to smoke.

They didn't want to dirty the shop's environment.

Zhou Ze thought for a moment, then also walked outside. The wind was a bit cold. He squatted down next to them and smoked along.

The workers chatted.

The married ones talked about their wives and kids.

The unmarried ones talked about girls they knew in Tongcheng or back home.

They joked with each other.

They teased one another.

Even though they all knew each other's stories, there was still plenty to talk about.

Judging by their accents, this group of workers was from all over the country, not from the same village.

Tongcheng was near Shanghai, part of the Yangtze River Delta region. Although it couldn't compare to Shanghai in scale, the demand for labor here was huge every year. As long as you were willing to work hard, you wouldn't have trouble finding a job or making money.

Another two rounds of cigarettes were passed around.

Zhou Ze spoke up, "Brothers, you're really not going home for the New Year?"

"Nope, everyone at home is fine."

"It's a lot of trouble to go back and forth. There's still work in the first lunar month, and the boss will even give out red envelopes. It'd be a waste not to take them, and we can send more money home."

"Haha, today's been great. We've got novels to read and cigarettes to smoke. This New Year's feels pretty good."

"Boss, when are you closing up?" one of the workers asked.

"I'm not closing," Zhou Ze replied.

"The boss isn't going home?"

"The old lady at home won't listen to me, so I'm not going back."

Zhou Ze suddenly felt a surge of heroic spirit reaching the heavens!

All the workers gave Zhou Ze a thumbs-up in applause.

Of course, no one took the joke too far. They could tell from his accent, and the fact that he ran a bookstore and not a fruit stall, that Zhou Ze was a local.

For a local to be minding his shop on New Year's Eve instead of being home, there had to be a reason, so no one continued to joke or tease him about it.

Besides, they were each the pillar of their own family. They came out to work and earn money while their wives managed the elderly and children back home. They worked hard, they were tired, but their wives were too.

Life is built on generations of hardship and endurance. Whose life is ever easy?

Just as Zhou Ze was about to pass out more cigarettes, a voice called out from a distance:

"Xu Le!"

Zhou Ze looked up and stood. He then noticed a Porsche Cayenne parked on the other side of the road. A familiar car.

Right, his wife's car.

The one shouting was his sister-in-law. She had indeed been scared out of her wits by Zhou Ze in the bathroom a while back, but she was back to normal now. She couldn't possibly believe her brother-in-law was a ghost, so she just chalked it up to her eyes playing tricks on her in her fear.

Of course, she couldn't possibly be in a good mood with Zhou Ze. After all, he made *her* pee her pants. How humiliating!

"Xu Le, come home for dinner!" the sister-in-law shouted.

"Not going back. The shop's busy, and it's quite lively here," Zhou Ze waved his hand.

What a joke.

Go back on New Year's Eve to see that pair of坑爹³ in-laws?

And put up with this bratty sister-in-law?

Most importantly, rush home on New Year's Eve just to sleep in separate beds?

Was he a glutton for punishment?

"Sis, is this guy nuts? He's unreasonable, just plain weird, and so stubborn!"

The sister-in-law pouted from the back seat.

Dr. Lin smiled. "Let's go home and eat with Mom and Dad first."

"Ooh, sounds like you're planning on coming out tonight, Sis?"

"I am, after all, his... legal wife." Dr. Lin said no more, started the car, and drove away.

Watching the car leave, Zhou Ze shouted to the workers beside him, "Brothers, is my wife pretty or what?"

"Pretty!"

"You're a lucky man!"

"Gorgeous!"

"Hahahaha."

Xu Qinglang came out of his shop carrying a large tray.

"Here we go, braised pork over rice! Dig in, brothers!"

The workers were a bit reserved and hesitant. The oldest one said, somewhat embarrassed, "We came out without bringing any..."

"We already agreed, it's my treat for my brothers! If you mention money again, you're not treating me as a brother. We're all from different places, who knows when our paths might cross again. There might be a day when I need to ask you guys for a favor."

"Alright!"

"Say no more!"

"When you come to my hometown..."

"Let's eat!"

The workers each took a large bowl of rice and went into the bookstore. They all squatted on the floor, placing their bowls on the plastic stools, and ate heartily.

One worker was eating while still reading his novel. A worker next to him tapped him on the head with his chopsticks.

"You've got lard in your brain. What if you get the book dirty? How's the boss supposed to sell it then?"

"You're right. I'll eat first."

The atmosphere was lively. Zhou Ze returned behind his counter. The dumplings were already a bit cold. He ate three more. This time, for some reason, maybe because of the atmosphere, his nausea was much less severe than before.

After the meal, the group went back to reading.

The room was warm, there were novels to read, and the atmosphere was harmonious.

Unconsciously, it got to be ten o'clock at night.

The oldest worker stood up, stretched, and said, "Brothers, it's about time. Let's head back. Let's help clean up the place for him."

"You got it!"

The five workers helped Zhou Ze clean the entire shop, upstairs and downstairs.

"Boss, we're leaving. Thanks for everything today."

"Don't mention it," Zhou Ze waved his hand.

They left.

Unlike the girl with the Corgi from last night, who left a hundred-yuan bill after reading for a while, these men had read for a whole day and half the night without leaving a single yuan.

But Zhou Ze didn't mind in the slightest, nor did he feel any dissatisfaction.

Stretching, Zhou Ze was about to call Xu Qinglang over to collect the bowls and chopsticks when he walked to the noodle shop and saw Xu Qinglang sitting at a table, reading a newspaper.

Yes, the very newspaper Zhou Ze had given him that day.

Xu Qinglang was wearing a pair of gold-rimmed glasses, which gave him a rather scholarly air. A man with over twenty properties was truly something else.

No matter how you looked at him, he had class!

"The bowls and chopsticks over there, you can clear them," Zhou Ze said.

"Alright, I'll go right now."

Xu Qinglang took off his glasses, rubbed his eyes, and got up to go next door to clean up.

On top of the large stack of newspapers was a copy of the *Yangzi Evening News*. The date showed it was from seven days ago.

The front page headline was in large, bold, black type:

**"Residential Building Fire, A Moving Tale of Heroism"**

Last week, a fire broke out in a densely populated residential complex in Tongcheng. The fire was severe.

Five young construction workers from a nearby site rushed into the building to save people without regard for the danger. In total, they rescued over twenty elderly people, women, and children. But after they charged back into the fire one last time to save more people,

they never came out again.

The front page of the *Yangzi Evening News* featured a large photograph.

It was a group photo of the five men.

They were standing shoulder to shoulder, making old-fashioned peace signs with their fingers. It seemed to be a photo taken after they first arrived at the construction site and were living in the same dorm.

Their faces were youthful yet etched with a hint of world-weariness.

In the photo,

their smiles were a bit reserved, but also brilliant.

Xu Qinglang walked into the bookstore.

He looked at the five bowls of braised pork over rice sitting on the plastic stools.

Not a single bite had been taken. The food had long since gone cold.

In each bowl of rice, a pair of chopsticks was stuck straight up.⁴

"My brothers,"

"Eat well,"

"Drink well."

Xu Qinglang murmured.

Outside, the sound of firecrackers erupted.

Tongcheng hadn't banned fireworks. For a moment, the sky was filled with brilliant colors, exceptionally lively and festive.

Zhou Ze lifted his head and looked outside.

He whispered softly:

"It's the New Year."

***

**Footnotes:**
¹ `1314` in Mandarin sounds like *yīshēng yīshì*, which means "for a lifetime," a common romantic gesture.
² `你含棒棒哦` (nǐ hán bàng bàng o) is a cutesy, almost childish slang term for "you're awesome." It literally means "you're holding a lollipop."
³ `坑爹` (kēng diē) is a popular slang term literally meaning "to scam one's own father." It's used to describe something that is deceptive, frustrating, or a total rip-off.
⁴ Sticking chopsticks upright in a bowl of rice is a traditional East Asian funereal rite, as it resembles incense sticks burned as offerings to the dead. It is a major taboo to do this during a normal meal.

title: 第十五章 生活要想過得去
content:
The sound of firecrackers rang out, bidding farewell to the old year. After the clock struck midnight, the noise of fireworks and firecrackers erupted from all directions, exceptionally lively and dense. What had been a sparse commotion now took on an overwhelming scale.

Zhou Ze blew on his fingernails. The clamor outside had little to do with him. He had no home—though nominally, he now had a "home," he didn't want to go back.

Many people, while alive, have had the thought of what they would do if they could be reborn.

*To write with passion, to command the world, to scorn the marquises of yesteryear.*¹

But when you truly return from hell, you suddenly discover that your former pursuits, your old ideas, your aspirations—they're like when a kindergarten teacher asks, "Children, what do you want to be when you grow up?"

And all the children answer in unison: "Scientists, doctors, astronauts, soldiers..."

Dreams are always full.

And reality, while not exactly skeletal, is a reminder that a person's zeal is inevitably finite.

Sometimes, just being able to breathe, to hear sounds, to sit here and slack off a bit, to waste a little time,

This, perhaps, is what it truly means for the years to be quiet and good.

Xu Qinglang was sleeping in the shop again tonight. Zhou Ze heard him lock the front door.

He said he had over twenty properties, but Zhou Ze knew his parents were right there in the shop.

A family should be together and complete.

This New Year, naturally, was even more important.

Outside, it began to rain. A dampness started to seep in, making one feel a bit oppressed.

Zhou Ze's phone rang. It was his wife.

"Hello," Zhou Ze answered.

"Are you asleep?" Dr. Lin asked.

Zhou Ze thought this was a moronic question.

*If I were asleep, who would be answering your call?*

*A dead person... oh, no, a ghost?*

Wait, that didn't seem quite right.

Zhou Ze leaned back slightly in his chair. An image surfaced in his mind of Dr. Lin gently poking his chest with her finger, calling him, "You old devil..."

For the first time, he felt how, honestly speaking, the plain truth could be so dazzling.

Perhaps he was too bored, or maybe he was just idle,

Zhou Ze found his thoughts starting to wander.

He was thinking... a little too much.

"No, I'm not," Zhou Ze replied.

*Creak...*

Dr. Lin pushed open the shop door and walked in. She held a red umbrella, wore leather pants on her lower half and a white sweater on top, her hair draped over her shoulders.

For a moment, Zhou Ze forgot to put down the phone.

This woman,

she was truly beautiful.

Especially her aura, which always gave you the feeling of "if life were only like the first time we met," instantly piercing a man's heart.

"Afraid I'd be lonely and cold by myself?" Zhou Ze stood up and poured Dr. Lin a glass of water.

She was the mistress of this place.

Well,

to be precise, the money Xu Le had used to open this bookstore had come from her family.

Dr. Lin took the water and shook her head, not saying a word.

The two were husband and wife, but in reality, they were like the most familiar of strangers, stuck in a position more awkward than being platonic best friends.

Taking a step forward was hard;

taking a step back was even harder.

"Let's go for a walk," Zhou Ze said, feeling the room was a bit stuffy. Besides, he couldn't possibly invite Dr. Lin to his sleeping quarters on the second floor.

Even if Dr. Lin had taken the wrong medicine today and decided to feed her body to the tiger, the sight of the freezer on his second floor would probably make her immediately call the number of a familiar psychiatric hospital and have him sent there for some serious rehabilitation.

"It's raining," Dr. Lin said.

"It's a light rain, it's fine." Zhou Ze waved his hand, relaxed and at ease.

...

*Pitter-patter-patter-patter...*

The rain grew heavier. Much heavier.

Zhou Ze, who had initially planned to experience the "spring rain as precious as oil" without even taking an umbrella, was now soaked like a drowned rat. Dr. Lin still held her umbrella, standing to the side. Zhou Ze had refused her offer to share it.

A bluff you start yourself, you have to see it through, even with tears in your eyes.

Patting his soaking wet hair, Zhou Ze shivered. He wasn't particularly afraid of the cold; in fact, he was quite resistant to freezing. It was just that the woman beside him, though barely wet under her umbrella, was still trembling slightly.

The bus stop shelter could block most of the rain,

but the cold night wind still blew through with impunity.

Petty-bourgeois sentimentality,

a man and a woman together,

soaked on a rainy night,

a beauty in distress...

This should have been a good opportunity for the two to cultivate their relationship, a perfect opening. It could even have led to an accidental discharge, a "mistake in the flower patch,"² and hitting the jackpot on the first try. But the two stood in mutual silence.

Zhou Ze lit a cigarette. Dr. Lin stood beside him.

One wanted to escape, the other was inherently resistant; naturally, they couldn't meet in the middle.

A melon twisted from the vine isn't sweet, and in this case, both the melon and the vine felt awkward.

In his heart, Zhou Ze grumbled a bit at Xu Le. If that coward had just forced the issue after getting married, none of this nonsense would be happening now. Even if Dr. Lin had become a wife or was pregnant with a child, she would probably still be devastatingly beautiful, perhaps even earning a few extra points.

Then he could have just gone with the flow. Why would he be stuck between a rock and a hard place like this?

Of course, this complaint was rather unfair to Xu Le. If Zhou Ze himself had forced the issue that night, would Dr. Lin have desperately fought back, screaming "indecent assault"? And then called the police to have Zhou Ze sent to the Public Security Bureau? Accuse him of rape?

The rain continued to fall.

Zhou Ze dropped his cigarette butt on the ground.

"Did you drive here?"

"I took a taxi," Dr. Lin replied.

"I'll see you home."

"Okay."

There was no need to dwell on how this seemingly foolish and naive New Year's Eve walk in the rain had begun.

At least, for now, both of them felt that ending it here was the most appropriate thing to do.

They hailed a ride-sharing car, and Zhou Ze and Dr. Lin got in together.

Fifteen minutes later, they arrived. Zhou Ze got out of the car with Dr. Lin. The driver settled the fare and drove away immediately.

Home was just upstairs, but Zhou Ze and Dr. Lin didn't go up right away.

The scene was a bit like a pair of junior high sweethearts walking the girl home at night. Now it was time to say goodbye, lingering, whispering sweet nothings.

But the atmosphere here was even less rich than that of a pair of shy middle schoolers. It was like meat broth without salt or MSG—tasteless to eat, but a waste to throw out.

"Aren't you coming up?" Dr. Lin asked.

"Not today. Let's wait a while, then we can take care of our business."

Dr. Lin understood Zhou Ze's underlying meaning. "I'm sorry," she said.

Zhou Ze smiled, then raised his hand. He had intended to pat Dr. Lin on the shoulder, but after his hand landed, he suddenly felt an impulse and pulled her into a hug instead.

Dr. Lin's body stiffened for a moment, but she didn't resist.

The two drew slightly closer, but it wasn't a particularly intimate gesture. Given their relationship, it could even be called distant.

She smelled quite nice. He didn't know which brand of body wash she used, but in any case, it was very pleasant.

"I've always been curious about something. Is there someone else in your heart?" Zhou Ze added, "And that 'someone' could be a man or a woman."

"Yes," Dr. Lin said honestly, without even a hint of hesitation.

Before, her husband had been so timid and shrinking, she couldn't bear to hurt him.

Now, her husband seemed like a different person, which allowed her to shed some of her burdens as well.

"Oh," Zhou Ze grunted, his gaze drifting slightly upward, as if to see if his head was now sporting a certain protective coloration.

He was still a little disappointed.

He couldn't say it was love.

He couldn't say he liked her that much.

He could barely even say they were familiar.

But she was, no matter what, nominally his woman. And in the end, he'd still been cuckolded.

Yes, as long as you're a man,

no,

as long as you're a male of any species,

you probably wouldn't be too happy about something like this.

"I'm sorry." This was the second time she had said sorry.

Zhou Ze released his hands, and the two slowly separated.

"Saying sorry makes us sound like strangers," Zhou Ze said, leaning back against a nearby stone bollard. The rain had lightened, and there was a small eave here.

"I'll give you another sum of money. You can open another bookstore," Dr. Lin said, then added, "I'm sorry."

Zhou Ze wanted to magnanimously wave his hand and say, "I don't care about the money."

But then he thought about his freezer, about his future life,

and Zhou Ze suddenly found he couldn't get the words out.

What if,

what if,

what if this woman took him at his word, thought that giving him money was an insult, and really didn't offer any compensation?

"Let's talk in a few days," Zhou Ze shrugged. "So, that guy, what's he like?"

"He's very handsome, in my opinion," Dr. Lin answered.

*It's a guy.*

*Stab.*

*Another knife wound.*

*It would have been easier to accept if it were a woman...*

Zhou Ze felt as if the intensity of the photosynthesis above his head had grown stronger.

"There's no chance, is there?" Zhou Ze asked a very stupid question. He regretted it as soon as he asked it, but then consoled himself: *I'm asking for the pitiful Xu Le.*

*You've occupied his body, and now his wife is cheating. You have to at least help him ask why, right?*

*Yes, that's it.*

"No chance," Dr. Lin's reply was just as quick, and just as certain.

This woman was also a surgeon. Her style of speaking was truly decisive, like wielding a scalpel—every cut hit a vital spot, no hemming and hawing.

Otherwise, the patient would only suffer more. The same principle seemed to apply to matters of the heart.

"Fine, fine. I can't compare, I can't compare. It's fine. We'll each live our own lives. You should go back and deal with your parents," Zhou Ze said, feeling annoyed.

Dr. Lin nodded and turned to walk into the building's hallway.

Zhou Ze stood up, preparing to hail a taxi, but at that moment, an unknown number called:

"Hello."

"Sir, I've brought the car back."

"So efficient?" Zhou Ze was a bit surprised. He recognized the voice of the driver from before.

"You left a bag on the back seat. I brought it back for you."

"Oh, thank you."

The car pulled up to the building again, and from the window, the driver handed out a woman's handbag.

"Please check it."

"Alright."

Zhou Ze didn't stand on ceremony. He opened Dr. Lin's bag. Inside was just a phone, a wallet, a charging cable, and a few packs of tissues.

Taking out the wallet, Zhou Ze froze the moment he opened it.

His eyes were fixed on the photo slot in the wallet.

There was a photograph there.

The woman in the photo looked very young, even... naive, wearing an ill-fitting white lab coat.

And the man to the girl's right... Zhou Ze felt a sense of unfamiliar familiarity.

He stared for a good while.

Only then did Zhou Ze realize,

wasn't that... himself?

It was a cropped photo, likely from a group picture, but it had been cut down to just the two of them.

"Is anything missing?" the driver urged.

"Everything's here. Thanks, Master Driver. You can go."

The driver drove off.

Zhou Ze continued to stare at the wallet. It didn't even occur to him that he should call Dr. Lin and tell her to come down and get her bag.

Some memories, not exactly buried but certainly not often considered, began to surface.

He vaguely remembered,

about five or six years ago, he had supervised a group of students assigned to the hospital for their internship. There was a girl, her surname seemed to be Lin, and her face... it seemed to match the girl in the photo.

*A girl really does change so much by the time she's eighteen.*

A smile touched the corners of Zhou Ze's mouth.

Who knew Dr. Lin had such an adorkable phase back then? And to think she would turn out so stunning five or six years later. He really hadn't noticed this girl's potential to blossom at all.

Moreover, he had been very perfunctory about the hospital making him supervise interns back then. He had basically just used those students as "medical grunts."

Zhou Ze shook the wallet in his hand.

"Damn it, serves you right for being single until you were almost thirty."

This time, surprisingly, he wasn't cursing Xu Le.

He was cursing himself.

"My eyes...

were truly blind..."

Zhou Ze stretched out his arms and arched his back.

The one who cuckolded him,

was actually himself.

After the rain, in the wee hours of the morning, on the first day of the New Year.

Heh heh.

He gazed at the sky.

He very solemnly reached out and patted his own chest.

Zhou Ze paused.

And said, very seriously:

"Xu Le, you truly are my good brother!

*Your wife I shall care for myself; you need not worry.*"³

---
¹ A line from Mao Zedong's 1925 poem, "Qinyuan Chun: Changsha," expressing youthful, revolutionary ambition.
² "A mistake in a field of flowers" (花田裡犯的錯) is the title of a popular song by Leehom Wang about an affair.
³ A famous and cynical quote attributed to the warlord Cao Cao in the historical epic *Romance of the Three Kingdoms*. He says this to a general before having him killed, implying he will "take care of" the man's wife by taking her as his own. It's a classic example of dark, historical humor.

title: 第十六章 老司機帶帶我
content:
The air was still thick with the lingering smell of fireworks, a bit acrid, but this seemed to be the smell a New Year's ought to have—what is commonly called the spirit of the New Year.

For Zhou Ze, at this particular moment, life seemed to have gained a little more beauty.

It wasn’t some romance of eternal vows, nor was it as dramatic as "the mountains losing their peaks and heaven and earth merging."

It was simply like a little kid who normally had no pocket money finding a ten-dollar bill on the street, with no passing policeman in sight, but a small convenience store right nearby.

A trip through hell, a change of bodies, and still so many troubles, both discovered and undiscovered, that needed solving. His own personality had also undergone a considerable change without him even realizing it.

He thought back to himself in his previous life. After leaving the orphanage, his mind was filled with nothing but climbing the ladder step by step with his own two hands and abilities. In retrospect, the reason he had overlooked Dr. Lin back then probably wasn't just because of how dorky or plain she was five years ago. A young girl at that age should have been full of romantic notions; otherwise, she wouldn't have cut out that photo and kept it in her wallet.

It was just a pity that the him of that time had neither the energy nor the inclination to glance at the scenery along the way. His obsession was too strong, wearing an air of deep-seated tragedy while pretending to be so cool he was like a breath of fresh air.

Unlike now. Having died once and come back, he felt a kind of carefree abandon and wistfulness, like the lightness that comes with having no official duties.

But no matter what,

the feeling of being secretly loved, even a "love you even after death" kind of feeling,

was indeed quite nice.

He made the call, and Dr. Lin came down again. She came down in a bit of a hurry, took her handbag from Zhou Ze’s hands, and smiled. She didn't say thank you; given their current relationship, saying "thank you" was even more inappropriate than saying "I'm sorry."

With a wave,

Zhou Ze left her with a view of his back.

Time to go back and sleep.

And then wait for tomorrow. Tomorrow would be even better.

***

Dr. Lin felt that her husband's mood seemed to have undergone a slight change, a sense of relief, as if a great weight had been lifted.

Perhaps it was a good thing for both of them to be able to move on.

Rather than remaining awkwardly entangled, it was better to part ways gracefully and each face life anew.

One could only chalk it up to the unpredictability of life. Dr. Lin could never have imagined that the shell of her husband was now inhabited by another soul.

The soul of the man she, as a young intern, had naively and innocently admired.

***

Zhou Ze hailed another car, then squatted by the residential complex gate, smoking. The phone screen persistently showed that it was searching for a ride. Zhou Ze felt a pang of regret. Why did he let that driver go? He should have asked him to wait a little longer so he could take his car back to the bookstore.

And now look.

On New Year's Eve night,

it was truly difficult to get a car.

After waiting for about ten minutes and smoking three cigarettes, Zhou Ze started to get annoyed. He stood up straight and stretched.

Although he wasn't particularly afraid of the cold, walking all the way back would be exhausting.

Just then, a black sedan drove past on the road in front of Zhou Ze. As it passed him, it slowed down.

"Need a ride?" The driver stuck his head out the window. He had a big, round face, was middle-aged, unshaven, and wore a black cotton-padded jacket.

"Yeah." Zhou Ze had no other choice.

"Hop in. I won't overcharge you," the driver said with a smile.

Zhou Ze got in the car, gave the bookstore's location, and settled on a price. The driver started the car again.

The car must be new; the seat cushions still smelled of plastic and leather, and the interior was very clean.

Generally speaking, very few people were willing to use a new car as a taxi.

"That place is pretty out of the way," the driver said, proactively offering Zhou Ze a cigarette. Zhou Ze took it.

"Yeah."

"You live there?"

"My shop is there."

"Oh, business can't be good then, huh?" Everyone knew that the commercial center was long dead, with hardly any foot traffic.

"You're not a local?" Zhou Ze asked.

The Tongcheng dialect was very different from others, almost like a completely different language from Mandarin. It was easy to tell.

"I'm from Rongcheng. I work here." The driver lit his cigarette. "Go on, smoke. Don't be a stranger."

Zhou Ze lit his cigarette as well, took a drag, and frowned slightly. The smoke was so faint it was ridiculous.

"Not going back for the New Year?"

"Wife and kids are at home, everything's fine. Not going back. Figured I'd earn a bit more money." The driver stuck his hand out the window and flicked his ash. "I have four kids."

"That's impressive," Zhou Ze said admiringly.

"It's tough, too." The driver smacked his lips. "My wife's first was a son, the second was a boy too. I really wanted a daughter, but the third was another boy. Luckily, the fourth was finally a girl. I'm satisfied now."

"Nice," Zhou Ze echoed. He took another drag of the cigarette, then tossed it out the window. It was so mild it was like smoking a paper scroll.

"I'm not old-fashioned, and I don't favor boys over girls. I just like kids, want to have a few more, haha." When talking about his children, the driver became much more talkative.

"Haven't paid the fine for the youngest yet. When it's time for her to start school, I'll pay it and get her household registration sorted. By the way, what kind of shop do you run?"

"A bookstore."

"How's business?" The driver had a knack for hitting a sore spot.

"Not great."

"That's true. Nowadays you can buy books online, and with discount coupons too."

Up ahead on the road, there was a car accident. Traffic police had set up a roadblock, and the original four-lane road was now down to a single lane. Fortunately, there weren't many cars on the road late on New Year's Eve, so it shouldn't cause too much of a delay.

"Getting into a car crash on New Year's, that's some bad luck," the driver said, blowing out a smoke ring. His tone was very much like that of a leader, tinged with a bit of criticism.

Zhou Ze leaned back in his seat, shifting to a more comfortable position, and asked,

"Is this car new?"

"Yeah, my son gave it to me."

Zhou Ze smiled. "How old are you? How old is your son?"

"Hehe." The driver's eyes narrowed to slits. "My son is promising. These days, ambition isn't tied to age. If you've got hands, feet, and a brain, and your fate isn't constantly against you, how can you stay poor?"

"That's the truth," Zhou Ze nodded in agreement.

"Beep... Beep..."

A car behind them seemed to be in a hurry to get home, honking its horn frequently, urging the cars ahead to get a move on.

"Hurry, hurry, hurry. Rushing to meet the devil, are you?"

The driver had a bit of a show-off streak in him. He leaned out of the car again and yelled at the car behind him.

But the cars behind them only honked more frequently, as if in deliberate defiance.

"Hey!"

The driver made a show of pushing open his door, ready to get out and have a proper argument.

Just then, the traffic police officer directing traffic gestured for their lane to pass through quickly. The driver sheepishly sat back down, started the car, and drove past.

"Business isn't good today," the driver started lamenting again. "Should've just gone home to see my wife and kids."

"It's alright, I suppose." Zhou Ze was noncommittal. He had seen that the noodle shop next door was doing decent business. With most of their competitors closed for the holiday, even if demand was a little lower during the New Year period, business was still better than before.

Especially since Zhou Ze had just spent so long trying to hail a cab with no one taking the order.

"Hey, it's not easy," the driver insisted, shaking his head. "I don't dare to rest either. The kids' school fees, got to send money home every month. I work my day job, then drive for half the night. This life is pretty dull. Can't even bring myself to smoke a better pack of cigarettes."

*This cigarette of yours... seems to be fake.*

Zhou Ze took out his own pack, pulled out a cigarette, and played with it in his hand.
