"But it's okay. The internet is convenient now. At night when I get home, I can have a video call with my wife and kids before bed. That's pretty good. I can see them." A look of relief appeared on the driver's face.

Zhou Ze closed his eyes slightly. He couldn't fall asleep, but right now, he didn't feel like talking or chatting.

But even without Zhou Ze's feedback or reaction, the driver continued to talk. It was New Year's, and he was a stranger in a strange land, all alone. Of course he was lonely.

From naming his children to their schools, to his own parents, to the local customs of his village, the driver rambled on.

In the end, Zhou Ze just rested his forehead against the car window and urged, "Driver, can you go faster?"

This driver was driving way too slowly, maybe only thirty miles an hour.

And this was an elevated highway.

Zhou Ze even suspected the man was just too lonely and was deliberately driving slowly to have someone to talk to, but Zhou Ze had no interest in playing therapist.

"Hehe, it's a new car, I'm not too familiar with it yet. Don't dare to drive too fast." The driver stroked the steering wheel fondly. "This car isn't worth much, it's actually really cheap, but it's a token of my eldest son's love. I have to cherish and treasure it.

"I'll try to use this car to run fares for a few years, and after my eldest son finds a girlfriend, I'll get him a down payment for an apartment. Get one sorted out, then worry about the next. I don't want the older one to have to provide for the younger ones. That's not fair to the eldest. After all, the one who decided to have them was me, their father. As long as I can still work, still have a job, I have to grit my teeth and bear it. I'm not an irresponsible person. I wouldn't do something like have kids and not raise them."

Zhou Ze frowned slightly.

He was getting annoyed.

Then he lit one of his own cigarettes and took a drag.

"Driver, seriously, I'm begging you to go a little faster." Zhou Ze was starting to miss his ice chest. He was also regretting not asking Dr. Lin to drive him back.

"Don't be in such a hurry, young man. It's the New Year. It's fate that brought us together, right? No need to rush. I get it, I get it. I'm an old hand at this..."

Zhou Ze flicked his ash.

He accidentally missed the window.

A small clump of ash landed on the inside of the car door.

Immediately after,

the spot on the inner car door was burned through by the ash, leaving a hole.

A hole the size of a thumb.

The cool night air whistled in through the small hole.

title: 第十七章 究竟，救了個什麼東西（修）
content:
For people who don't know much about cars, buying one can be a real headache. They inevitably turn to knowledgeable friends or relatives for advice, since some cars do have their disadvantages or potential issues, whether with quality or performance.

But when you get right down to it,

a car door you can burn a hole clean through with a cigarette butt,

you can't just chalk that up to "poor quality," can you?

All of this pointed to only one thing:

This was a…

paper car!

The driver was middle-aged, but his eldest son was probably only elementary school age. And because of this, when the driver said the car was sent to him by his son,

the "sent" here,

could also be written as "burned."[^1]

The father died,

and his son burned a paper car for him.

Zhou Ze shook his head. To be honest, he hadn't noticed beforehand. Only after getting in the car did he belatedly realize that something was slightly off, but he still wanted to play dumb.

He himself was a stowaway; he had no ambition to be some Zhang Tianshi.[^2]

At the end of the day, he was a ghost, too.

If he were to take up the banner of slaying demons and defending the righteous, he'd be no different from a Hanjian[^3]—a "Gui-jian," a traitor to ghosts.

He pressed his palm over the small hole to cover it. Feigning drowsiness, Zhou Ze half-closed his eyes, pretending that nothing had happened.

Zhou Ze remembered that when he was in the orphanage, there was a teacher who usually led everyone in gym activities and also had a part-time job: manning the gate.

And because his surname was Qin, the children at the time called him Gatekeeper Uncle Qin.

Uncle Qin was a great storyteller, and he often told ghost stories. He seemed to derive great satisfaction from the frightened expressions on the children's faces when they heard his tales. The director had spoken to him about it several times, but he never toned it down.

But before Zhou Ze left the orphanage for school, Uncle Qin passed away from a heart attack.

Zhou Ze remembered a ghost story Uncle Qin had once told, called "Ghosts Carrying a Sedan Chair."

According to legend, in ancient times, there were many different kinds of ghosts. Most people, after dying, went directly down to the Underworld, entered the Yellow Springs, drank Meng Po's soup of forgetfulness, and re-entered the cycle of reincarnation. Very few ghosts could remain in the mortal world.

But some ghosts did stay. They might have known they were dead, or they might not have, but regardless, they often continued doing what they did in life.

For example, sedan chair bearers.

They would appear on deserted country roads or in the dead of night, asking people if they wanted a ride in a sedan chair, offering an extremely cheap price. After the person was transported to their destination, the transaction would be complete.

But for a living person to do business with a ghost and enjoy a service provided by a ghost was never so simple. When ghosts carried a sedan chair, what they wanted wasn't mere money, but your lifespan, or perhaps your vitality and spirit.

In the underworld, ghosts carry sedans for figures like King Yama. What status does a living person have? Are they worthy?

It's like having an eighty-year-old man kneel to you—it'll shorten your life.

Zhou Ze remembered this story, and very clearly. In fact, Zhou Ze still remembered many of the stories Uncle Qin told; even after becoming an adult and starting work, he hadn't forgotten them.

Because Zhou Ze knew that on the day before Uncle Qin's sudden death, Uncle Qin, who had always just guarded the gate and never entered the back courtyard, made an exception and walked into the children's dormitories. He looked into each room, at each child, one by one. Zhou Ze happened to be awake at the time and saw it.

It was as if Uncle Qin knew his time was up and had come to say goodbye in advance.

It's like how if Warren Buffett farts, people will think it contains some profound financial secret.

A man who could know he was going to GG the next day—the ghost stories he told couldn't really be dismissed as mere nonsense.

The driver was still chattering away, continuing to bullshit. Zhou Ze remained calm in the back.

Shorten my life?

Drain my vitality and spirit?

Zhou Ze wasn't particularly afraid. He wasn't a living person; he was a ghost, too.

To put it bluntly, although Zhou Ze didn't understand the stratification and class divisions of ghosts, the fact that he could walk under the sun, interact with the living, and run a business meant he had to be on a much higher level than the lonely souls and wandering ghosts out there, right?

Besides, even the faceless woman in the pool of hellish water could be injured by his fingernails. When facing other ghostly beings, Zhou Ze felt quite confident.

"These days, more and more people are buying cars and driving, and more and more of them don't follow the rules," the driver continued his monologue. He kept on talking even though Zhou Ze didn't respond or engage.

"When the forest gets bigger, you get all kinds of birds. All in all, if you really get angry at every single one of them, you'd probably shorten your life by quite a few years.

"Even though you know you shouldn't get angry, some people get on the road like they have a sign pasted on their forehead saying, 'Hit me! You bastard, come on and run me over!' It's really infuriating."

Zhou Ze's eyes narrowed. He felt himself getting sleepy, even wanting to sleep.

But he knew he was incapable of sleep. Therefore, this distinct feeling must be fake.

Zhou Ze suddenly let out a small, silent laugh.

He understood why the driver had been chattering nonstop the whole way. It wasn't that the driver didn't know he was being annoying.

It was because he hadn't fallen asleep yet, so the driver had to keep talking to pretend that everything was normal.

He was trying to make him fall asleep.

And his own reaction to sleep-inducing effects had always been very sluggish.

A smile touched the corners of Zhou Ze's mouth. He placed a hand on the car seat and closed his eyes.

*Sleep, then.*

The car began to slow down.

As Zhou Ze "fell asleep," the driver's voice also grew softer and softer.

At the same time, the driver specifically turned his head to look behind him.

However, just then, a look of struggle suddenly appeared on the driver's face. Finally, he shook his head violently, sighed, and continued driving forward.

It looked like they were almost at the bookstore.

Zhou Ze wasn't sure how a ghost driving a paper car was able to transport him, a person with a physical body.

It was hard to explain, as physics has no "ghost-dynamics" branch.

Then again, ancient Chinese legends speak of "Yellow Turban Strongmen" and "Qi Men Dun Jia."[^4] It was probably something similar to those principles.

Zhou Ze slowly woke up, because he sensed that the body of the driver in front of him was slowly evaporating in a shimmering light.

*Interesting,*

*It seems I've been running into good ghosts lately.*

This driver was supposed to "collect payment" from him, but he couldn't bring himself to do it. It must have been his first time doing something like this, and in the end, he couldn't go through with it. In that struggle, he achieved his own release and redemption.

He began to dissipate.

After dissipating, he would enter the underworld and begin reincarnation.

From this, it was clear that not all the "nonsense" the driver had spouted was false. He had four children, he enjoyed the feeling of being a father, and he worked hard to earn money to support his family and provide a good environment for his children to grow up in.

He was a good father. In terms of character and personality, he was decent enough. After becoming a ghost, he'd wanted to try his hand at the "Ghosts Carrying a Sedan Chair" business, but in the end, he was too soft-hearted.

Zhou Ze slowly lifted his head and opened his eyes. The driver didn't notice, still absorbed in his driving.

Gradually, Zhou Ze saw light shining in from outside. Through the window, he could see the endless stream of traffic on the road.

The driver was about to dissipate.

This must be a memory from the driver's final moments.

Similar to the principle of how lightning, combined with a special environment, can supposedly record a scene.

Zhou Ze subconsciously lit another cigarette. Since the driver had already found his own release, it wouldn't matter even if he burned this whole car down now.

Music was playing in the car, a very popular song at the time called "Liang Liang" (Cold Cold).[^5]

The driver was humming along as he drove. He must have just finished a big fare and was in a good mood, planning to go home and treat himself to a plate of peanuts, then video chat with his kids for a while. Life was hard, but it was also pretty good.

Just then, Zhou Ze saw a minibus appear on the road ahead of the car.

It must have been a school bus. It had a school emblem printed on it, along with the words "XXX Elementary School."

At first, Zhou Ze didn't think much of it, but then a girl in the back of the bus suddenly stood up. She was facing the rear of the bus, and even from the car behind, he could see her clearly through the glass.

The girl was wearing a cute, blue pleated skirt.

Zhou Ze frowned slightly.

He knew this girl. He was the one who had saved her. He'd heard she had woken up. Just a little while ago, Dr. Lin had told him that the girl's father wanted to host a thank-you banquet and had planned to invite him.

Zhou Ze's gaze darkened. So, this driver was the culprit who caused that car accident?

So many children were injured.

And if he hadn't intervened, some children would have even died.

"What a pretty little girl, just like my youngest."

The driver muttered to himself. This was the final memory of his life, so he had no idea there was another person sitting in the back seat.

Zhou Ze looked around. He didn't think the driver had been drinking, nor did he seem to have any other issues. So, what exactly caused him to crash into the school bus? What caused that accident?

Was it a chain-reaction collision caused by a nearby car?

And just at that moment,

the girl in the pleated skirt, who had been standing at the very back of the school bus, suddenly opened her mouth. Her tongue shot out.

Yes,

it shot out,

like a red carpet being rolled out for a newlywed couple, it just shot out, long... so long... so long it made one's scalp tingle with fear.

At the same time,

the girl's eyes held a mocking smile, fixed squarely on the driver in front of her.

"Oh my god, a ghost!!!!!!!!!!"

In his panic, the driver stomped on the accelerator, and the car shot directly toward the school bus in front of it.

"Boom!"

Sparks flew.

Zhou Ze was standing at the entrance of his bookstore.

On the ground around him were the still-smoldering ashes of the paper car, scattering with the wind, swirling and falling, dissolving into final, fading specks.

Zhou Ze was unharmed, not even a scratch.

And that driver had kept his promise, delivering him to his destination.

But Zhou Ze didn't rush back into the bookstore.

In his hand, he still held the cigarette, its embers glowing.

Taking a deep breath,

Zhou Ze licked his lips.

"Mister, you're not supposed to smoke in the hospital, you know." The girl's voice still echoed in his ears.

What...

exactly...

had he saved?

***

**Footnotes:**

[^1]: The Chinese words for "sent" (捎, *shāo*) and "burned" (燒, *shāo*) are homophones, both pronounced the same way. The author is making a pun indicating the car was a paper effigy burned for the dead.
[^2]: Zhang Tianshi refers to the lineage of Celestial Masters of the Zhengyi school of Daoism, who were known for their power to subdue demons and ghosts. Zhou Ze is saying he has no desire to be a ghost-hunting hero.
[^3]: A *Hanjian* is a deeply derogatory term for a traitor to the Han Chinese people, especially those who collaborated with foreign invaders. "Gui-jian" (鬼奸) is a clever play on this, meaning "ghost traitor."
[^4]: Yellow Turban Strongmen (黃巾力士) are divine warriors from Daoist lore. Qi Men Dun Jia (奇門遁甲) is an ancient form of Chinese metaphysics, divination, and strategy, often depicted in fiction as a source of mystical powers.
[^5]: "Liang Liang" (涼涼) is the title of a popular song. The phrase itself has become internet slang meaning "it's over," "doomed," or "chilled to the bone," making it a darkly ironic choice of music for the scene.

title: 第十八章 風波再起！
content:
The next morning, after washing up, Zhou Ze went to the noodle shop next door as usual. This had gradually become a habit for him. When eating was no longer a process of enjoyment, it became purely a task. And for tasks, simple and efficient was best. There was nowhere more convenient and quick than Xu Qinglang's place.

"Bitter melon juice." Xu Qinglang placed a large glass tumbler in front of Zhou Ze, then brought over a serving of egg-fried rice.

Zhou Ze took a tentative sip. The moment the liquid entered his throat, he felt an unbearable bitterness between his lips and teeth. Then, after swallowing, it even felt like his intestines and stomach were tying themselves in knots.

It took about ten seconds for Zhou Ze to recover, letting out a long sigh.

It really was bitter.

"Haha, packs a punch, doesn't it?" Xu Qinglang wore an expression that said, *Go on, praise me.* He then sat down across from Zhou Ze. "Seriously, you have some heavy tastes. You can't eat without drinking this stuff?"

Zhou Ze composed himself, then picked up the large, full glass of bitter melon juice and downed it in one go. Immediately after, he quickly grabbed his chopsticks and began to wolf down the egg-fried rice in front of him.

A minute later, Zhou Ze finished his meal, set down the plate, and closed his eyes.

"That way of eating... the spitting image of a hungry ghost that crawled out of hell," Xu Qinglang teased.

Whether this was just a tease or held some other meaning, it was hard to say.

Zhou Ze opened his eyes and glanced at him. On the day of the five migrant workers' seventh-day soul return,¹ it was normal that his sister-in-law and wife couldn't see them. But this noodle shop owner could see them; otherwise, he wouldn't have made those five servings of braised pork over rice.

But between the two of them, there was a tacit understanding of seeing the truth but not speaking it, and they had never broken the unspoken rule. Perhaps this was the best way for them to get along.

"How come you're not taking orders today?" Zhou Ze asked.

In the past few days, even on New Year's Eve, Xu Qinglang's phone had been constantly buzzing with delivery orders. But today, it was much quieter, and there were no delivery drivers coming to pick up food.

"Taking a break." Xu Qinglang took out a pack of cigarettes, stuck one in his own mouth, and passed one to Zhou Ze.

Although it was strange not to rest on New Year's Eve but to rest afterward, as a man who owned over twenty properties, he certainly had the capital to be willful.

"Do you know about 'ghost-carried sedans'?" Zhou Ze asked. The events of last night were still fresh in his mind, but he hadn't rushed to do anything about them. He had simply gone home and slept in his freezer.

He had indeed saved the person himself, but if any problems arose from it, Zhou Ze didn't want to get involved.

He was just living his own little life, cautiously and with a mix of seriousness and levity. If he encountered things he could handle along the way, he would, but he wouldn't force anything.

Even if there really was something wrong with that little girl in the lily-patterned dress, it was no longer his business to manage.

"Ghost-carried sedans?" Xu Qinglang paused for a moment, then chuckled. "Heh heh, there are probably a lot of them on New Year's Eve. They say that when everyone burns joss paper and spirit money for the New Year, the ghosts have some spare cash in hand, so they can finally afford to catch a ride."

Xu Qinglang continued his nonsense, then let out a yawn. "By the way, why isn't your bookstore open yet?"

"I'll open it tonight."

"Fine, be willful." Xu Qinglang took out his phone and glanced at it a couple of times. "How about we go see a movie this afternoon?"

The scene instantly fell into an awkward silence.

"Not going," Zhou Ze refused.

"See? So ungrateful. After I went to all the trouble of mixing a new juice for you, you won't even accompany me to a movie. Men... not a single one is any good."

"..." said Zhou Ze.

"Sorry, I forgot I'm a man too." Xu Qinglang shook his head with a somewhat mournful air, as if lamenting the fact that he wasn't born a woman.

"Did you suffer some kind of psychological trauma as a child?" Zhou Ze asked. "I know a few psychologists, I could help you out."

Xu Qinglang scoffed with a "pfft."

"Heterosexuality is just a heresy created for the sake of procreation. Homosexuality is true love."

"I'm afraid I can't agree."

"Those with different principles cannot make plans together."

With that, their post-meal conversation ended on a sour note.

Zhou Ze returned to his bookstore, opened the door, and after a moment's thought, decided not to lock it. He simply sat down behind the counter, turned on his computer, and sent Dr. Lin a message on WeChat:

"Movie this afternoon?"

About ten minutes later, Dr. Lin replied:

"Working."

The New Year didn't stop people from getting sick or having accidents. Having been a doctor himself, Zhou Ze knew that holidays at a hospital were mostly for show.

It was understandable, but still a bit disappointing.

Zhou Ze really wanted to tell her that he was Zhou Ze, not some damn Xu Le.

But he was worried the result would be Dr. Lin being so frightened she'd question her own sanity, and that even the hazy, one-sided crush she had might be washed away. Of course, the most important thing was that the fewer people who knew about certain things, the better.

Someone would come for him.

Zhou Ze was very clear on this point.

And while he waited, he hadn't chosen to curl up and tremble in some dark corner like a sewer rat. He still needed to live, and live a very normal life at that. Otherwise, he might as well have not come out of hell and just followed the main procession down the Road to the Underworld.

As for the neighbor next door, Zhou Ze didn't know if he had figured things out, nor did he care to find out.

"Tonight, maybe."

Dr. Lin sent another message.

Zhou Ze smiled. He felt his smile was like a dumbass's, just like being back in middle school, seeing the class academic representative give him a shy, sidelong glance.

In his previous life, he had lived too tired a life.

In this life, he had to live a bit more freely and unrestrainedly.

Many of life's great truths are only truly understood right before death or in old age, but by the time you understand them, you've already lost the chance to start over.

Zhou Ze cherished his present life and opportunity.

A small red car pulled up on the street in front of the bookstore, and two females got out.

One was a woman under thirty, the other a girl who looked to be only five or six.

The woman wore a red dress, her hair flowing. Though she was a mother, it was hard to hide her captivating charm, which, if anything, was even more capable of tugging at one's heartstrings.

The girl wore overalls, likely with several layers of warm clothes underneath, making her bundled up like a small zongzi,² looking sweet and adorable.

But when he saw the girl, Zhou Ze's eyes subconsciously narrowed.

This was no friendly visit.

He hadn't gone looking for her, but she had come looking for him.

He had felt a bit smug when he heard from Dr. Lin that the girl had been calling for her "uncle" at the thank-you dinner. Thinking back now, it was clear she had no intention of letting him go.

When it came down to it, the death of that father of four was because of this girl.

The bookstore door was pushed open. The woman looked around with curiosity, while the girl walked timidly to Zhou Ze's counter, looked at him, and said in a soft, sweet voice:

"Hello, Uncle."

Zhou Ze nodded, maintaining a reserved demeanor.

In reality, he was wondering if he should just whip out his fingernails and strangle this girl to death right then and there.

"Hello, I'm Ruirui's mother."

The woman walked up to Zhou Ze and placed a gift box on the counter.

"Thank you for saving Ruirui."

The woman bowed to Zhou Ze, her gratitude deep and sincere.

"You're too kind." Zhou Ze still didn't get up.

He really wanted to act as if everything were normal, so the girl wouldn't suspect a thing.

But it was too difficult.

Even an Oscar-winning actor, after seeing the memories of the driver's life last night, would probably find it hard to remain composed in front of this girl.

Since he couldn't pull off the act, he might as well not even try.

"Mommy, I want to read here," Ruirui said to the woman.

"Alright, Mommy is going to get her hair done. You can stay here with Uncle and read." The woman smiled at Zhou Ze. "Sorry to trouble you."

"No trouble."

"It was Dr. Lin who told me you owned a shop here."

*Silly woman.*

"You and Dr. Lin really make a handsome couple, the man talented and the woman beautiful."

That was such a disingenuous thing to say; Xu Le himself wouldn't have believed it.

The woman drove off, leaving her daughter behind. This was a bookstore, after all. And since Zhou Ze was a sort of savior to her daughter and also Dr. Lin's husband, she felt very at ease leaving the girl here for a while, not worried that anything would happen.

Next, Ruirui picked out an illustrated book herself and sat on a small plastic stool to read.

She wasn't noisy, nor did she cause a fuss.

She didn't ask for a drink, nor did she whine for snacks.

Zhou Ze just sat behind the counter, watching her.

Just then, Xu Qinglang walked in. Seeing the porcelain-doll-like little girl, he immediately went over and picked her up.

"My, what an adorable little girl."

"Thank you, big sister," Ruirui replied.

The smile on Xu Qinglang's face bloomed like a chrysanthemum, growing ever more brilliant.

The little girl's flattery had scratched him right where he itched.

Zhou Ze, however, sat there with a somber face.

"Come out. I need to talk to you about something." Xu Qinglang put the child down and gestured to Zhou Ze.

Zhou Ze and Xu Qinglang walked out.

"Some people from the plaza management came by. They're asking if we want to terminate our contracts. They can refund the rent we paid in advance."

"Let's not." Zhou Ze didn't want to go through another upheaval just yet. Besides, he didn't have enough capital. Even with the refunded rent, it wouldn't be enough to open a new shop.

"That's what I was thinking too." Xu Qinglang nodded, indicating he understood. "Then I'll go negotiate on your behalf as well?"

"Fine."

"Alright, it's settled then."

The two of them stood outside the shop, smoked another cigarette, and then went their separate ways.

When Zhou Ze turned, pushed open the shop door, and walked back in, he found that the little girl was gone from the row of small plastic stools. The illustrated book was left on one of them.

Zhou Ze frowned.

He raised his head.

At the top of the stairs, he heard the sound of little leather boots.

The little girl emerged from there, half of her body revealed, the other half blocked by the wall.

She had just been...

on his second floor.

---
**Footnotes:**

1.  **Seventh-day soul return (頭七回魂):** A concept in Chinese folk religion where the soul of the deceased is believed to return home on the seventh day after death.
2.  **Zongzi (粽子):** A traditional Chinese food made of glutinous rice stuffed with different fillings and wrapped in bamboo leaves, making them look like small, tightly wrapped parcels.

title: 第十九章 不公平！
content:
"You went up to look?" Zhou Ze asked.

The little loli shook her head. "It's dark up there, I couldn't see anything clearly."

As soon as she finished speaking, the little loli slowly walked down and stood before Zhou Ze.

She was very short and wore many layers of clothing. Her delicate face was like an exquisite work of art.

But Zhou Ze knew that her tongue could get very, very long. So long... it would make one's skin crawl.

"Uncle, I'm going to keep reading now."

The little loli gave a charmingly innocent smile, sat back down on the small plastic stool, picked up the illustrated children's book, and continued to read with relish.

Zhou Ze stood behind her, his hands clasped behind his back.

*Strangle her.*

*Strangle her.*

*Whatever she's planning,*

*There's no need to keep up this charade!*

This voice resounded in Zhou Ze's mind. It wasn't someone else's voice; it was his own.

Compared to the noodle shop owner next door, Xu Qinglang, this little loli in front of him provoked a much greater sense of irritation and revulsion in Zhou Ze.

He had been the one to save her.

She was very cute,

very sensible,

very well-behaved,

very polite and reasonable,

possessing a sense of propriety and discipline rarely seen in a child her age.

Perhaps,

it was precisely because his initial impression of her had been so very, very good that when Zhou Ze witnessed her true nature, the resulting distortion and reversal of expectations made his revulsion and rejection of her all the more intense.

The little loli continued to read her book, seemingly paying no mind to Zhou Ze behind her.

Zhou Ze stared at her, able to see even the fine hairs on the nape of her neck with perfect clarity.

*Strangle...*

*Don't strangle...*

*In the end...*

*To strangle or not?*

...

"Dad, Mom, your son is off work today."

In the back room, Xu Qinglang had set out several cold dishes and hot dishes on a small table, along with two cups of alcohol.

One cup was Maotai; his old man had loved its flavor when he was alive.

The other cup was home-brewed rice wine. His mother hadn't drunk alcohol and had strongly disapproved of his father's drinking. On the rare occasion she attended a banquet where the host was overly enthusiastic, his mother would only drink a little rice wine.

His mother often said that rice wine was nourishing.

On the east and west corners of the small table, two candlesticks were also placed, their flames flickering.

Two human skins were hanging behind their respective seats, stirring as if in a breeze where there was none.

Xu Qinglang first toasted his father with a full cup, then took a small sip with his mother.

Picking up his chopsticks, he said to his parents:

"Help yourselves, help yourselves. Dad, you're trying to snatch the meat from me again!"

He took several pieces of meat for himself and wolfed them down.

In his memory, when he was little, his father always liked to pretend to fight him for the meat, but every time he would just make him hurriedly gobble it down until his cheeks were puffed out and he couldn't swallow.

And his mother, at that moment, would gently pat his back while chiding his father.

Today was the first day of the Lunar New Year.

Most people made offerings to their ancestors before the New Year,

but Xu Qinglang was different. He did it on this day, because his parents had died together in an accident on this day.

For ordinary people, the New Year might have lost some of its so-called festive spirit¹ compared to the past, but for Xu Qinglang, it meant the return of his own heartbreak.

Taking a deep breath,

Xu Qinglang smiled,

and said:

"Dad, Mom."

He pursed his lips,

poured himself another cup of white liquor, and drained it in one gulp.

The fiery alcohol made his already delicate and lovely face even more flushed and tender.

He was a man,

yet a *femme fatale* in his own right.²

If this were ancient times, he would surely have been the forbidden treasure of many an emperor and prince. Of course, even in the modern era, if he were willing, he could have lived a life of ease and success.

How terrifying a man who could turn a straight man gay was, went without saying.

After long hesitation,

after long contemplation,

Xu Qinglang couldn't hold it in any longer.

He said:

"The man next door... that man next door, I'll find a chance to ask him. Ask him... ask him how on earth he came back!"

Xu Qinglang wasn't drunk, but his speech was a little slurred.

Clearly,

he knew in his heart that the man next door wouldn't just sit down and tell him, as if they were having a normal chat.

The process,

in the end, would be somewhat unpleasant, and would require him to use certain methods.

The two human skins stopped swaying,

as if in disapproval.

"Dad, Mom, it's alright. Your son will definitely bring you back to life!"

"Clatter!"

"Clatter!"

Two pairs of chopsticks fell to the floor.

Xu Qinglang, holding his own chopsticks, froze for a moment.

But he still shook his head.

"No, I can't listen to you this time. Even if you disagree, I will pry his mouth open!"

...

*Strangle,*

*or not to strangle?*

Zhou Ze was still pondering this question.

He didn't know why he was so hesitant, nor did he understand what he was struggling with right now.

He was a ghost,

no longer the doctor from his past life.

He was dangerous, and his situation was perilous. Therefore, he knew he should nip all dangers in the bud.

This little loli was a threat to him.

She had come looking for him.

She had come of her own accord.

Just like that day when her soul had sought him out to speak.

She...

had probably been watching him for a long time.

Even a child understood the story of the Farmer and the Snake. Zhou Ze didn't think that just because he had once saved her, everything would be fine.

In fact, most of the world's enmities evolved from kindness.

The nails on Zhou Ze's ten fingers had already begun to slowly lengthen, and at the same time, wisps of black mist were swirling around his fingertips.

Simultaneously,

a black luster was shimmering in the depths of Zhou Ze's eyes.

*I have to strangle her.*

*Strangle her!*

Zhou Ze told himself this over and over in his mind. He had fought so hard for this new life; he still had a life, he still had things he wanted to do.

He still wanted to be lazy, to reminisce, to think.

He didn't want to be like the old and young on the Yellow Springs Road, numb and hollow, knowing only to take one step after another.

Zhou Ze raised his hands,

and slowly approached the little loli.

The little loli was reading, very engrossed, a smile on her lips, looking very cute and lovable.

Suddenly, she felt two fingers placed on her temples.

She asked, a little confused, "Uncle?"

"Giving you a little massage to protect your eyes."

"Mm," the little loli responded, continuing to read her book.

A perfectly applied pressure emanated from her temples, and the little loli found it very comfortable.

Afterward,

the little loli saw her uncle silently walk over and sit down in the chair behind the counter.

"Uncle, what's wrong?"

"It's nothing," Zhou Ze said with a wave of his hand.

The little loli lowered her head and continued to read her book.

Then,

*Smack!* A crisp sound.

The little loli looked up and saw that one side of Zhou Ze's face, over by the counter, was bright red.

"Uncle?"

"Killing a mosquito." Zhou Ze let out a long sigh of relief, then leaned back in his chair, lamenting inwardly: *Damn it, I still couldn't do it. How am I so useless?*

The little loli apparently didn't realize there were no mosquitoes in the middle of winter, but she stood up and looked around, as if helping Zhou Ze find it.

*Damn it,*

*keep acting,*

*you've been possessed by a drama queen, haven't you!*

*Still acting!*

*And acting so convincingly!*

*Hurry up and stick out your tongue,*

*let's have a fight!*

*It would be great if you killed me or I killed you.*

*Still wearing that loli face. Are you banking on the fact I can't bring myself to do it?*

*And I... really can't bring myself to do it.*

*Fuck!*

Feeling helpless, Zhou Ze turned and went into the bathroom, turned on the tap, and splashed cold water hard against his face.

"You used to be a doctor. Curing diseases and saving people was your instinct, your profession."

"You've already fucking turned into a ghost,"

"why are you still such a damn bleeding-heart!"

"Useless piece of trash!"

Zhou Ze started cursing his reflection in the mirror.

Then, Zhou Ze noticed that the frequency with which he cursed himself lately seemed to be higher than the frequency with which he cursed Xu Le.

But the little loli, who had been sitting in the bookstore reading, now put down her book.

She cast a deep glance in the direction of the bathroom door, but instead of walking toward it, she walked out of the bookstore,

and went next door.

...

"Dad, Mom, it's no use no matter how you try to persuade me. I want you to sit here and eat with me for real. If he can be like that, I can make you like that too!"

"Our family can continue to live together, just like before."

Xu Qinglang was still rambling on.

Suddenly,

the two human skins hanging by the small table began to sway frantically.

A look of shock appeared on Xu Qinglang's face. He looked up at the yellow talismans pasted on the wall of his back room, only to find that for some unknown reason, they had turned gray.

He violently threw aside the curtain and rushed out.

He saw a little girl standing in his noodle shop.

The girl opened her mouth,

and a long tongue stretched out.

Very long,

very long,

terrifyingly long!

"The Underworld has its order; the dead must be on their way."

A grim, childish voice came from the girl's mouth.

The next moment, the two human skins in the back room began to wither and decay, losing their luster and resilience. Two streams of white gas trickled out, landing beside the little girl and materializing into the figures of a middle-aged man and woman.

They swayed unsteadily,

as if they had forgotten everything,

knowing only to dazedly walk step by step along the long tongue that came out of the girl's mouth, as if her tongue was their final destination, leading to some unknown place.

Gradually, their forms began to fade, growing more and more indistinct.

"You... you're actually... you're actually a..."

Xu Qinglang pointed at the sweet-talking little loli he had held in his arms not long ago, his face a mask of shock. But when he saw his parents slowly disappearing,

he immediately tried to rush over hysterically. However, his feet seemed to be shackled, and instead of running, he fell hard onto the floor.

He reached out, pointing at his parents, and began to plead:

"Don't take them away, don't take them away."

"I haven't hurt anyone."

"I've never hurt anyone."

"I just want my family to be together."

"They never hurt anyone either!"

"Don't, don't, I'm begging you, I'm begging you, please..."

However, in the face of Xu Qinglang's tearful pleas,

the little loli remained unmoved. Only after the two souls had completely vanished did she retract her long tongue and revert to her cute loli appearance.

Xu Qinglang felt as if two chunks had been brutally gouged out of his chest.

His parents,

had left him for good.

Xu Qinglang's eyes were shot with blood. He pounded the tiled floor with his fists, striking it fiercely.

Suddenly,

as if he had thought of something,

he immediately pointed next door and roared:

"He's not human either! He's not human either!"

"Why don't you take him? Why don't you take him!"

"This isn't fair! What you're doing isn't fair!"

"He's not human either!"

"Why did you only take my parents?"

"He's not human either!"

"It's not fair!"

"It's not fair!!!!!"

---
**Footnotes:**
¹ `年味兒` (niánwèir) literally means "New Year's flavor." It refers to the special atmosphere, traditions, and excitement surrounding the Lunar New Year.
² `紅顏禍水` (hóngyán huòshuǐ) is a Chinese idiom literally translating to "beautiful face, calamitous water." It typically refers to a beautiful woman whose allure brings ruin to a man, a family, or even a nation. Applying it to a man emphasizes his exceptionally dangerous and captivating beauty.

title: 第二十章 不患寡而患不均
content:
The bathroom Xu Le had wasn't actually well-renovated. It only had a simple washbasin and a squat toilet, not even a showerhead. The second floor, let alone a bed, didn't even have a straw mat to begin with; it was purely used as a small storeroom, because the Xu Le of the past had to go home every day.

Even if at home there was a father-in-law and mother-in-law who looked down on him,

Even if at home there was a bossy sister-in-law,

Even if at home there was a wife who didn't sleep with him,

Xu Le would still, after finishing the little work there was to do at the bookstore each day, lock up the shop and head home at a leisurely pace.

This was life.

You couldn't call it dignified,

Nor could you say it was carefree,

But he accepted it gladly.

He was a wimp, a coward, with no spirit.

Because he was Xu Le, not some great figure who had left a name in history, everyone felt it didn't matter.

If you put him in the shoes of some ancient historical figure, however, Xu Le’s life would seem like a case of great wisdom appearing as foolishness, adding layers upon layers of flavor out of thin air.

Zhou Ze couldn't relate to what Xu Le felt. Having grown up in an orphanage, the sense of inferiority in his heart, though never shown, had always existed. That was why he was sensitive, why he strived so hard—in his studies, his work, his own life, it was always the same. He always insisted on being the best, the most outstanding.

But right now, looking at the wet face in the mirror, a sliver of pity appeared in Zhou Ze's heart.

Pity for Xu Le, and at the same time, pity for himself.

Everyone has their own cage. The only differences are the style and size, but a cage is there all the same.

Zhou Ze didn't want to become some Ghost King, nor did he fantasize about using his special powers to call the shots in the mortal world. On one hand, he knew that if he became too high-profile, something bad would probably happen to him right away. On the other hand, his previous life had been exhausting enough; he wanted to live differently this time around.

Regardless, he wanted to live, to continue living in this physical body.

He spread his palm open and held it in front of him. The long nails had long since receded, showing no trace of anything unusual.

Zhou Ze smiled.

*Forget it.*

*Maybe this is just what I deserve.*

He took a towel and wiped his face, then his hands. When Zhou Ze walked out of the bathroom, the conflict on his face was gone, replaced by a kind of carefree air.

The little loli was still sitting on the plastic stool, engrossed in her picture book.

"Uncle, Rui Rui is thirsty," the little loli called out to Zhou Ze.

Like a pet acting cute for its master.

Zhou Ze nodded, took a paper cup, and poured a glass of water, mixing hot and cold to a lukewarm temperature before bringing it to her.

The little loli took the cup, took a sip, and her lips curved into a crescent moon.

Zhou Ze simply sat down on the tiled floor, reached out, and ruffled the little loli's head, open and forthright, without the slightest bit of caution.

Time slowly trickled by.

The little loli continued to read her book.

Zhou Ze continued to lie beside her.

One big, one small.

They got along peacefully.

The little loli would show Zhou Ze the interesting stories she read to share them with him, and Zhou Ze would respond in kind, telling her about the deeper morals in fables or other little tales.

After an unknown amount of time, the red sedan pulled up again.

The girl's mother pushed open the door and expressed her thanks to Zhou Ze. Her hair was exactly the same as when she had arrived. A curve formed on Zhou Ze's lips; he really wanted to suggest that the woman go demand an explanation from that barbershop. You can't fool people like that.

Of course, if he really said that, the woman would probably blame him for being a busybody.

The little loli bowed to Zhou Ze and said thank you, then left with her mother.

From beginning to end, the little loli never once looked back at him.

Gone was gone.

Zhou Ze walked over to the counter and picked up the gift box the woman had left earlier, only to discover a stack of cash inside. Three thousand yuan.

Not bad.

Zhou Ze had no intention of returning it.

He needed money. He might as well use it for now.

Zhou Ze felt that he had come to an understanding, like a cultivator suddenly achieving enlightenment.

But he also felt like he was just throwing caution to the wind, letting things fall apart since they were already broken. *Come what may, I'll be free.*

But no matter what, at least he felt much more relaxed now.

Zhou Ze casually picked up a book with a large cover from the shelf. It was an appreciation of famous calligraphers' works, the kind of thing that was purely unsellable. He had no idea if Xu Le's head had been run over by a large iron gate countless times for him to even stock this kind of book.

He flipped it open casually.

This page happened to show the four characters for "Nándé Hútú."¹

"Tsk tsk."

Zhou Ze clicked his tongue.

*Interesting.*

He checked the time and saw it was almost evening. Remembering that he had plans to see a movie with Doctor Lin that night, Zhou Ze decided to get something to eat first.

Walking next door, Zhou Ze froze for a moment when he saw Xu Qinglang kneeling on the floor.

Xu Qinglang's eyes were bloodshot, and several empty liquor bottles lay beside him. At that moment, he was holding another bottle, continuing to drink.

"It's not fair... It's not fair..."

Xu Qinglang muttered to himself. Even when Zhou Ze walked into the shop, it was as if he hadn't noticed him at all.

"Hey?" Zhou Ze reached out and patted Xu Qinglang's shoulder. "You alright?"

He really wanted to remind Xu Qinglang that for other men, getting drunk might only mean getting robbed. But if he, Xu Qinglang, got drunk and wandered outside, it wouldn't be as simple as just losing money.

In fact, if he were lying on a street late at night next to a starlet, Xu Qinglang might be assaulted more times than the starlet.

Xu Qinglang's body trembled. He slowly raised his head, his face tear-streaked and pitiable like a pear blossom in the rain, a sight to evoke compassion in anyone. Posing his fingers delicately like an orchid, he pointed at Zhou Ze and said mournfully, "Today is the anniversary of my parents' death."

Zhou Ze was silent for a moment before saying, "My condolences."

He waited a bit.

Xu Qinglang continued to drink.

Zhou Ze could only remind him, "Are you not cooking tonight?"

"Yes! I'll cook!"

Xu Qinglang stood up shakily. His slender, willow-like waist was graceful and exceptionally alluring, especially with his teetering posture, making one want to rush over and support him, to take a whiff of his fragrance.

"You don't have to force yourself."

Zhou Ze said this, but he still sat down in a chair, ready to eat.

Getting a meal wasn't easy for him, so he didn't want to look for another place.

Xu Qinglang waved his hand and walked into the back room.

Soon, the sound of the stove flaring up came from inside. Xu Qinglang was stir-frying.

Zhou Ze took out his phone and saw that Doctor Lin had just sent him a message, saying she was coming to pick him up soon.

Zhou Ze replied with an "Okay."

Thinking it wasn't enthusiastic enough, he sent a "laughing Paopaobing emoji."²

Then he immediately felt it was too flippant, so he retracted the emoji.

Thinking that retracting it seemed like he was trying to hide something, which only made it more obvious, he replied again with a "Heh heh."

Right after, he felt that "Heh heh" wasn't friendly enough, but then he thought retracting a second time would seem too pretentious.

What a dilemma...

Zhou Ze was conflicted at the dining table.

The other person, the chef currently stir-frying, was also conflicted.

In the wok was twice-cooked pork. Once it was done, he would ladle it over rice to make a plate of twice-cooked pork over rice. It was simple and went well with rice.

"Why didn't she take you, but took my parents?"

Xu Qinglang muttered to himself as he cooked.

As the old saying goes, one does not worry about scarcity, but about inequality. This saying explained so many truths and also revealed the darkest side of the human heart.

"It's not fair. It's really not fair," Xu Qinglang continued to mutter.

"How could you be partial? How could you play favorites?"

Xu Qinglang's gaze was vacant, but the rhythm of his stir-frying didn't change. He was a good cook; cooking had almost become an instinct.

Silently, Xu Qinglang took out a yellow jar from the cabinet under the stove and poured some powder from it into the twice-cooked pork.

"My parents were taken away. Why didn't you go? Don't tell me it's because you saved her life?"

"Heh, what a joke."

"You want to eat?"

"Fine, I'll give you food to eat."

Xu Qinglang kept taking deep breaths.

"Is it ready yet?" Zhou Ze called out from outside.

"Almost."

Xu Qinglang paused, a flicker of panic and hesitation in his eyes, but he still put the lid on the wok. He realized he hadn't heated up his own rice in the microwave yet, so he had to reheat it again.

Once the rice was hot, Xu Qinglang spooned the twice-cooked pork over it and carried the plate out.

Zhou Ze was staring at his phone screen, still conflicted. Seeing Xu Qinglang walk over, looking lost and dejected, he put the food down and said with some concern, "In your state, you didn't forget the salt, did you?"

Xu Qinglang shook his head.

Zhou Ze picked up his chopsticks, ready to eat.

Xu Qinglang's hand trembled. His lips parted slightly, and just as he was about to speak, Zhou Ze put his chopsticks down.

"What about the sour plum juice or bitter melon juice?" Zhou Ze asked.

"Oh, right."

Xu Qinglang went back and returned with a glass of sour plum juice.

Zhou Ze picked up the juice first, sniffed it, then took a deep breath, preparing to drink it when his phone vibrated.

"I'm here. Come out."

Zhou Ze hesitated for a moment, then put the sour plum juice down.

He knew that if he ate this meal, his face would probably be sour for a long time afterward, as if everyone around him owed him a huge sum of money.

*On second thought, forget it.*

Counting both his past and present lives, this was his first time asking a girl out to a movie. He should probably be a bit more composed.

There was no helping it. Originally, his quest for Doctor Lin was a beginner-level rookie mission.

Now, having swapped into Xu Le's skin, the rookie mission had instantly turned into a final boss-level quest.

He didn't know whether he should be secretly pleased or miserable.

What he had to work on now was... defeating himself? Only then could he win the beauty's heart.

"The money, put it on my tab. We'll settle it at the end of the month. I'm leaving."

Zhou Ze stood up and pushed the door open to leave.

Doctor Lin's car was parked by the roadside. The window was down, and she was waiting for him.

And inside the noodle shop, Xu Qinglang's expression flickered between pale and grim. Then, he violently swept the entire plate of twice-cooked pork over rice onto the floor.

He clutched his head and started crying on the ground.

His crying grew louder and louder,

Until finally,

It turned into dry, heaving sobs...

---
¹ Nándé Hútú (难得糊涂): A famous phrase by the Qing dynasty artist Zheng Banqiao, literally meaning "it is a rare gift to be muddled." It expresses the wisdom in not being overly sharp or serious about everything, akin to the English idiom "Ignorance is bliss."

² Paopaobing emoji (炮炮兵表情): Paopaobing is a popular Chinese emoji character set featuring a cartoon soldier with a big green helmet, known for its exaggerated and humorous expressions.

title: 第二十一章 狗說
content:
Dr. Lin got out of the car, just as Zhou Ze was also walking over. The two of them had a strange sort of rapport; neither spoke, silently walking toward the entrance at the other end of the mall.

This mall was already "dead." Apart from Zhou Ze and Xu Qinglang's small shop, all that was left was a movie theater and a buffet restaurant.

Of course, due to the influence of the bigger picture, the movie theater was probably also operating at a loss. It was rare for anyone to go see a movie there on a weekday; you could easily buy a ticket and have the whole theater to yourself.

But since it was the New Year holiday, most people were off work. Families coming out to see a movie together had become a common sight, adding a splash of popularity that was a world away from the theater's usual arctic desolation.

To Zhou Ze, however, this liveliness felt like the final flare-up before death.

The great mansion was about to fall. This was, he supposed, a case of "when the nest is overturned, no egg remains unbroken."¹

Zhou Ze went to buy the tickets, and also bought a couples' combo. He checked the time, and then he and Dr. Lin walked into the theater.

Because they'd arrived a bit late and Zhou Ze had bought tickets for the earliest showtime, all the good seats were gone. Zhou Ze and Dr. Lin could only sit in the first row.

It wasn't that they couldn't have waited, but there was nothing else to do in the mall. Besides, this movie, *Neon Street Detective 2*, was a 2D film, so sitting in the front row wouldn't be too bad.

Dr. Lin hadn't said much on the way over, and now she sat beside Zhou Ze in extreme quiet, gently crossing her long legs and looking up at the screen.

Zhou Ze offered her the popcorn. Dr. Lin waved her hand, indicating she didn't want any.

Zhou Ze sighed. For someone like him, who'd been an old bachelor in his past life, how to pursue a girl was truly an unfamiliar subject.

The movie's jokes were pretty good. Zhou Ze would laugh occasionally, and Dr. Lin often laughed too, but her laughs were soundless—very reserved, and very beautiful.

But for Zhou Ze, the atmosphere of this movie date was still somewhat different from what he had expected. A little bland, like food without salt.

The movie ended. Zhou Ze and Dr. Lin walked out side by side. It was only seven in the evening, not late at all, but once they left the theater area, the rest of the mall was already pitch black.

Dr. Lin remained silent, just walking along with him.

Zhou Ze wanted to say something but didn't know how.

He was the one who'd said he wanted to end things and say goodbye yesterday. If he acted too enthusiastic today, would she think he was a lunatic?

"Let's go to my bookstore..."

"Let's go sit in your bookstore..."

It seemed both of them were trying to find a way to break the current awkwardness, and they'd landed on the same idea.

Back at the bookstore, Zhou Ze saw that the noodle shop had already closed. The security shutter, rarely seen down, had been pulled. He had no idea if Xu Qinglang was still inside.

Dr. Lin picked out a magazine and sat down in the chair behind the counter. Zhou Ze also grabbed a book and sat beside her, flipping through it casually.

Two cups of hot tea sat on the counter, steam curling up from them.

Zhou Ze suddenly felt he no longer had the face to mock Xu Le. He realized that to have engineered a first date this "cultured" and this "respectful as guests"² was a rare feat indeed!

So rare he felt like rewarding himself with a slap across the face!

"You're not closing now?" Dr. Lin asked. In fact, her subtext was that she wanted to leave. After all, it was nighttime. As soon as Zhou Ze closed the shop, she could naturally say her goodbyes.

"Oh, I usually open for business at night." Zhou Ze didn't catch the subtext. He was telling the truth.

Dr. Lin was momentarily speechless. She could only smile, gently tucking a strand of dark hair behind her ear, and went back to the book in her hands.

"Squeak..."

The bookstore door was pushed open, and two men and a woman walked in.

None of the three were very old, looking to be in their early twenties. The two men had clearly been drinking; one of them was already flushed, his entire face rosy red.

"Boss, you got any water?" the woman asked.

Zhou Ze pointed to the water dispenser against the wall.

The woman went to pour a few cups of hot water and handed them to her friends, then walked up to the counter.

"How much?"

As she spoke, she took out her phone, looking ready to scan a code to pay.

"Thirty," Zhou Ze answered.

"You can't rip people off like this just because it's the New Year, boss," the woman said with a laugh, but she still scanned the code to pay. Then she turned to her two male companions. "Let's just rest here for a bit, look at some books."

They were treating the bookstore as a temporary resting spot. To them, Zhou Ze charging 30 yuan was probably like a minimum charge to enter a teahouse, which was understandable.

"Read books? What books?"

The somewhat drunk man's voice was now loud as he called out,

"I want to read ghost stories! Horror novels! You got any in this shop?"

The man laughed out loud to himself as he spoke.

Zhou Ze sighed, took out two horror anthologies from under the counter, walked over to the man, and handed them to him, casually brushing the man's arm with his finger in the process.

*Hm, he's human, not a ghost.*

Tonight's date was already a failure.

If he made Dr. Lin experience something like the "Night of a Hundred Ghosts"³ with those five construction workers again, that would really be something else. Zhou Ze didn't want that.

*He's human, and that's good enough.* He looked almost endearing, even if he was drunk.

As for the other two, Zhou Ze didn't try to touch them; it wouldn't have been convenient.

The drunk man sat down. His two friends, the man and the woman, also sat down on the plastic stools. The three of them played on their phones while casually flipping through the books.

Purely to make it seem like they were getting their 30 yuan's worth, at least on the surface.

"What kind of crap is this ghost story."

The man tossed the book, and it landed right next to the water dispenser.

The woman went to pick it up and found that because she had just spilled some water while pouring, the book's cover and some pages inside were now wet.

"Boss, how much?"

"Eighty percent of the list price." Zhou Ze was actually amused; these three young people were surprisingly well-mannered.

Of course, Zhou Ze was hoping the drunk man would proceed to throw every book on his shelves, and get them all dirty, to help him clear his inventory.

The woman, looking a bit helpless, scanned the code to pay, then walked over to the drunk man.

"Let's go, stop going crazy."

"This isn't a ghost story! The person who wrote it has definitely never seen a ghost," the drunk man insisted stubbornly.

Zhou Ze let out a soft "en." *Well, you probably have seen a ghost. One's right in front of you.*

"I'm not going back, absolutely not! I'm not planning on sleeping tonight!" the man continued his drunken rant. "I see a ghost when I go home, I see a ghost when I sleep! I'd rather just stay here in this bookstore and read all night!

At least...

I won't run into any ghosts!"

"..." Zhou Ze.

At this, Dr. Lin also put down her book and looked at the drunken man. Clearly, she found this matter quite interesting.

"Yo, Brother Liu, your house is haunted?" the man who had come in with him joked.

The woman shot him a glance, signaling him not to talk nonsense.

"Screw you! Your house is the one that's haunted!"

The drunk man stood up.

"Dammit! That ghost only knows how to pick on me and torment me every New Year! It ignores everyone else! There are three of us brothers, plus an older sister, plus my mom and dad and my grandpa and grandma, and it doesn't bother any of them! It only messes with me!"

"A female ghost?" his male companion added.

"If only it were a female ghost! It's a female... dog!"

"Pfft!"

The drunk man's two companions couldn't help but laugh.

Even Zhou Ze and Dr. Lin lowered their heads and coughed a few times, but it was genuinely funny.

Especially the utter grievance on the drunk man's face when he said it wasn't a female ghost, but a female... dog.

*My heart is breaking,*

*I'm drunk and I need to pour my heart out!*

"Every New Year, for those few days, it comes looking for me! As soon as I fall asleep, it shows up! Crap!"

Though the drunk man was ranting, he was still in control. He didn't seem scary, but rather quite amusing.

"It's been doing this for seven years now! Every New Year's, it shows up right on time—more punctual than my parents giving me my New Year's money!" The man clutched his head and squatted right on the floor, starting to cry. "Damn it, I can't live like this anymore!"

"What really happened? That dog, did you know it?" his male companion asked.

"It was a dog our family used to have. It pulled out the money my dad kept under his bed and chewed it to pieces, so my brothers and I killed it and we ate the meat."

"The dog must have been holding a grudge and came back for revenge," his companion analyzed.

"But what I fucking don't get is why it only comes for me! When we killed the dog, it was me, my older brothers, my dad, and my grandpa!

When we ate the dog meat, the whole family ate it together, just treated it as an extra dish for the New Year!

That dog destroyed five thousand yuan, it deserved to be eaten!

But why does it only hate me?"

The drunk man practically cried, "I asked them! My brothers, my dad, my grandpa—nothing's happened to them! Why is it fixated only on me?"

"You're drunk. Let's go, I'll take you home." The woman helped the man up and gestured for her male companion to help.

The group left the bookstore.

The previous liveliness instantly vanished, replaced by quiet.

"What do you think? Why?" Dr. Lin asked Zhou Ze, not caring if it was true or not, she was simply making small talk after hearing a story. "Why does the dog only torment him? Is there something different about him?"

"You're very interested in this?" Zhou Ze asked, a little surprised.

"Mm-hmm," Dr. Lin nodded.

Zhou Ze smiled. "Actually, it's very simple. To understand its thinking, you first have to put yourself in the dog's place."

"How so?" Dr. Lin said, suppressing a smile. "That's pretty hard to do."

Right, how could a person put themselves in a dog's mind?

"The ghost of a dog comes back for revenge, to torment someone, because it holds a grudge," Zhou Ze explained. "That should be the same as with people."

"Then why doesn't it go after the other family members for revenge?"

"Perhaps, it's because of the money. The dog was mischievous and tore up some of it, but it's possible that this guy, who wasn't very old back then, stole some of it himself.

So the dog feels it's deeply unfair. It tore up the money and was punished—killed and eaten. It feels that's justified, that it had it coming.

But why...

did that person, who also stole money and made some of it disappear, get away with it completely?

So it can't accept it. It doesn't take revenge on the rest of the family; it specifically goes after him."

Dr. Lin shook her head, looking a little surprised. "It was just a drunkard's rambling story, but after your analysis, it almost sounds like it really happened."

Zhou Ze walked over to where the group had been sitting and noticed a wallet on the floor. He picked it up and walked to the shop entrance.

Just then, the female companion came jogging back.

"Excuse me, did we leave a..."

Zhou Ze handed her the wallet.

"Thank you so much!" The woman bowed to Zhou Ze to express her gratitude. "If this guy lost his wallet and ID on his way home tonight, his family would chew him out again."

"No problem," Zhou Ze said with a wave.

She waved back at Zhou Ze, then turned to chase after her friends up ahead.

Under the moonlight,

as the woman ran,

from beneath her coat,

it looked as if a fluffy yellow tail was swaying gently............

***

¹A Chinese idiom (覆巢之下，安有完卵) meaning that when a group or entity is destroyed, no individual within it can escape unharmed.

²A Chinese idiom (相敬如賓) describing a relationship, especially between a married couple, that is polite and respectful but lacks intimacy, as if they were interacting as formal guests.

³A reference to a traditional Japanese and Chinese parlor game (百物語怪談会) where participants tell ghost stories. Here, it refers to a previous event in the story.

title: 第二十二章 天雷，勾動地火！
content:
Zhou Ze felt his eyes must be playing tricks on him. After just hearing a drunkard's ghost story about a dog, coupled with the dim streetlights, it was normal for his vision to blur.

Yes, that must be it.

Zhou Ze was no Zhang Tianshi of Mount Longhu; he knew he was still a bit of a pushover. He couldn't change himself—otherwise, he would have extended his own fingernails to choke that little loli during the day.

As for whether the end result would be him being choked to death by the little loli or him *still* being choked to death by the little loli,

...that was anyone's guess.

Since he couldn't change himself, he might as well try to be less affected by all this damn trouble. The things he saw, he'd dodge if he could, or just cover his eyes if he couldn't.

Anyway, that dog had been toying with that man for seven years. Counting the years,

it was about time for the seven-year itch.

If that dog really meant to harm someone, it would have done so long ago. As for what kind of trouble it would stir up next, Zhou Ze didn't care.

The woman had come to his store, bought some water, and compensated him for the book. She paid readily. That was a point of good karma, and that was enough.

However, Zhou Ze was discovering for the first time that there were quite a few匪夷所思 (unimaginable) things in this world. Perhaps it was because he used to be a person, and now he was a ghost. Different circles, so naturally a different perspective on the world.

"What's wrong?" Dr. Lin had also walked over to the shop entrance by this time.

Zhou Ze smiled. "I'm glad I'm not like Spider-Man, without some random elder relative suddenly popping up to tell me:

'With great power comes great responsibility.'"

Dr. Lin didn't understand what that meant, but she still said, "I should be heading back."

It was getting late; she really should be going.

"You're not staying a little longer?"

"I might have to be on duty tomorrow," Dr. Lin said, tying her scarf.

"You can reschedule," Zhou Ze said.

"It's not convenient."

"You're not willing?"

Dr. Lin frowned slightly. This was the first time she had sensed such an aggressive feeling from Zhou Ze, and she was somewhat at a loss.

"You're my wife," Zhou Ze said, looking into Dr. Lin's eyes very seriously.

Dr. Lin took a small step back. "Yesterday, you said..."

The Zhou Ze of yesterday had just said it was over, that they would both be free.

"Yesterday was yesterday." Zhou Ze took half a step forward. "Before I've signed the divorce papers, I am your husband, and you are my wife. So, I want you, right now, to stay and keep me company a little longer!"

Zhou Ze's voice grew louder.

Dr. Lin said nothing, standing rooted to the spot.

A nameless rage suddenly surged within Zhou Ze.

He reached out, pinched Dr. Lin's jaw, and made a frivolous gesture of lifting her chin.

Dr. Lin looked at him, her gaze clear and calm. Her crimson lips, especially, were mesmerizing. She was beautiful, truly beautiful—the kind of beauty where exquisite features combined with a perfectly fitting temperament, giving one a very comfortable feeling.

Zhou Ze lowered his head and kissed her directly on the lips.

He kissed her fiercely, brutally, like a savage beast whose vicious nature had been completely unleashed from within! And the woman before him was the object of his taking.

Dr. Lin raised her hand, as if preparing to slap the man in front of her, but halfway up, she slowly lowered it again.

From the corner of her eye, a crystalline teardrop trickled down.

"What are you crying for?"

Their lips parted.

Zhou Ze looked up at Lin Wanqiu.

"You think your crying will make me feel guilty? You think your crying will make me stop?

I'm telling you,

crying won't do you any good today. You are my wife, and I am your husband!

Look at your parents! What kind of trash are they? Look at your sister, the way she usually looks at me!

And then look at you.

You're noble,

you're cold and glamorous,

you're a goddess,

you're above the mortal world!

In the bedroom, you even sleep in a separate bed from me!

You're married, you're a wife now, yet you still hypocritically care about your chastity. Take a look at yourself, are you even worthy of it anymore!

I know, I'm just a fucking idiot. In your whole family's eyes, I'm just a good-for-nothing and a fucking idiot!"

Zhou Ze grabbed Dr. Lin's neck with one hand, pushed her against the counter, and then pulled off her coat.

"Today, I'll teach you! I'll show you what a wife is supposed to do!"

"Xu Le..." Dr. Lin didn't resist. She just stared coldly at Zhou Ze. "You... bastard..."

"Heh heh." Zhou Ze just smiled, completely unconcerned. He then took off his own jacket and pressed Dr. Lin down onto the counter.

He was rough, he was tyrannical.

At this moment,

the dry firewood was already stacked; all it needed was a tiny spark to burst into a raging fire.

Zhou Ze was that bundle of firewood!

She smelled so good, her skin was so soft, her body so voluptuous. Everything, everything was so wonderful, so intoxicating.

But just then, Zhou Ze suddenly froze, stumbling back a few steps.

Before him, Dr. Lin lay on the counter, her blouse in disarray, while Zhou Ze himself was panting heavily.

No,

How did it turn into this?

Dr. Lin was still lying on the counter. Her eyes were still open; she still hadn't resisted.

She felt guilty toward Xu Le. She was a very independent and strong woman, but her social environment and the family education she had received since childhood left her in a constant state of conflict.

Her parents had threatened her with their own deaths, desperate for a grandchild to be born soon, which forced her to agree to marry Xu Le. Yet she held fast to her own bottom line, her heart belonging to another man—even though that man had died in a car crash half a year ago, even though that man might have long forgotten her, or perhaps never even knew that a woman like her had been secretly watching him for years after her internship ended.

To put it in the critical style common in middle school textbooks: Dr. Lin had chosen to yield to feudal conventions in her life, yet she was unwilling to continue living that way, still holding onto her own principles and resistance in her heart.

This was why, despite being ten thousand times unwilling, Lin Wanqiu still didn't resist and had allowed Zhou Ze to do as he pleased just now.

She felt she had no reason to resist. Zhou Ze was her husband, and she was well aware that her actions since their marriage had wronged her husband and their marriage.

She did not accept it, did not consent to it,

but she did not resist.

"Get your clothes on! Put your clothes on!"

Zhou Ze roared at Lin Wanqiu, who was still lying on the counter.

Lin Wanqiu froze for a moment, then stood up straight, looking at Zhou Ze in disbelief. Just a moment ago, she had already resigned herself to her fate.

"I haven't even done anything to you yet, so don't act like you were just violated. Get your clothes on for me!

Now!

Immediately!

Right this instant!

And then get out!"

Dr. Lin silently put her clothes back on, then straightened the hem in front of a mirror. She was expressionless. When she was done tidying up, she poured Zhou Ze a fresh cup of hot water and placed it on the counter. Then, without even glancing at Zhou Ze, she walked straight out of the bookstore.

Zhou Ze sank dejectedly to the floor, somewhat dazed, somewhat baffled.

On his lips and in his palms, her warmth seemed to linger. He didn't know why he had stopped, nor did he understand why he hadn't continued.

It felt so good,

It was something he yearned for,

It was so intoxicating,

But for some reason, he felt something was wrong. It seemed... this wasn't the feeling he wanted.

He was just about to sleep with her.

She had agreed to it.

But that scene just now was completely different from what he had wanted.

Zhou Ze staggered to his feet. He picked up the teacup, took a sip, and then spat out the hot water. The water was scalding, not tempered with the slightest bit of cold water.

Tossing the cup aside and letting the water soak the floor, Zhou Ze looked around, recalling his actions and replaying the words he had just said.

His fists clenched, then relaxed, only to clench tight once more.

He went to the washroom, turned on the faucet, and stuck his head directly under the running water to rinse it.

He needed to calm down, to find his peace.

Not just to quell the fire in his body, but also the one in his heart.

The shock of cold winter water was not something an ordinary person could endure. Zhou Ze lifted his head, feeling a wave of dizziness wash over his mind.

He looked at the mirror before him.

In the mirror, his own face was reflected.

Zhou Ze gripped the porcelain edge of the sink, panting nonstop. Then, he slowly raised his head again, and as if muttering to himself, said:

"It was you!

"It was you, you damned son of a bitch, you useless loser!

You're influencing me, you're trying to control me!

You piece of trash, you scum, you mutt!"

Zhou Ze cursed at his own reflection in the mirror.

Yes,

that wasn't him. His behavior just now had been too abnormal. That nameless, rising fire, that unreasonable stupor, that inexplicable impulse—

it was definitely more than just a young man's virility.

Just a moment ago, at that very instant,

a guy he thought had long since gone to hell, had long since ceased to exist in this world,

he had influenced him.

He hadn't left.

He was still hiding somewhere near him.

Even...

He was hiding inside his own body!

He was a good-for-nothing, he was weak. He had been scorned his whole life, never daring to resist, never having the courage to raise his head. But after death, cowering in a corner, he wanted to use someone else's hands to take revenge on his wife in the simplest, most brutal way!

Using another person's strength to get back at his own wife.

"I used to feel sorry for you, felt a little bit bad for you," Zhou Ze murmured. "Now I understand. The pitiful always have their detestable side. The fact that you lived your life the way you did, I can only say you deserved it!"

*Crack!*

Zhou Ze raised his fist and smashed it directly into the mirror.

The mirror shattered.

Zhou Ze's palm was streaming with blood, which began to drip into the sink.

On the fragmented shards of the mirror,

Zhou Ze's face was still reflected.

No,

it was Xu Le's face.

Zhou Ze stood there without moving.

The person in the mirror didn't move either.

But in the next moment,

a glint of sinister malice appeared in the eyes of the person in the mirror, who then spoke:

"Well now. You found me out."

title: 第二十三章 嗨！
content:
"You are... courting death."

A black luster surged in the depths of Zhou Ze's eyes. At this moment, he was furious.

Yes, he was a cuckoo in another's nest.

But,

so what!

I'm going to use your body to keep on living, can you stop me?

Your revenge,

is merely to suddenly provoke me into forcing myself on your wife?

Is that all you've got?

Zhou Ze spread his right hand open. Black fingernails slowly grew out, wreathed in wisps of black mist.

Often, the true solution to a problem depends on where you sit—that is, your standpoint.

From Zhou Ze's standpoint, there was simply no way to distinguish right from wrong. He wanted to live. As long as any action was based on this premise, it was correct. Otherwise, everything lost its meaning.

If it loses its meaning, is there any need for right or wrong to exist?

"No matter where you're hiding, I'll drag you out, even if... you're hiding in this body!"

Zhou Ze's face began to contort. His fingernails started to dig into his own chest.

"Hiss..."

Intense pain was accompanied by an uncontrollable twitching. Zhou Ze's whole body trembled, and he collapsed to his knees.

He opened his mouth,
looking somewhat dazed.

Not here.

He's not here at all!

Why,

he had just verified at the risk of nearly shredding his own soul. Inside this body, there was one and only one soul—his, Zhou Ze's. Xu Le simply didn't exist!

Zhou Ze crawled back to his feet. In the shattered mirror, his own face was still reflected. This time, he waited a long while, but the person in the mirror showed no change at all.

Xu Le was long gone.

Then, everything I did to Dr. Lin before, was that driven by my own nature?

No,

that's impossible,

Impossible!

It can't be like that.

For the first time, Zhou Ze felt that the person in the mirror was so unfamiliar—not because he had changed bodies and faces, but because his own heart, his own soul, seemed to be, compared to his original self-perception,

fundamentally different.

The body and the soul, which one is the real me?

From ancient times to the present, many great poets and thinkers, both at home and abroad, have actually given a similar answer: the flesh will change, it will decay, but the soul can be eternal.

It can be noble, it can be remembered, it can shine brightly throughout the long river of history.

Zhou Ze also believed that he was still Zhou Ze, still his original self. Right now, it was merely his body that had changed, but he still considered himself to be Zhou Ze.

Now,

he began to feel fear.

Because since Xu Le's soul was long gone,

that meant...

the one who had changed... was himself?

...

"You go to bed, dear."

"Okay, I'll take our daughter to rest first. You finish up soon and get some rest too."

"Alright, as soon as I finish revising this treatment plan."

Wang Ke gently twisted his neck and yawned. He was indeed very tired, but the work at hand had to be finished. Though only in his early thirties, he already had a lot of white hair on his head.

Men of this age are in the most awkward position. If you don't strive, it's too early to retire. If you do strive, your body has already started its slow decline.

"Ding dong... ding dong..."

Wang Ke frowned slightly. Someone was visiting this late?

He walked to the entryway and glanced at the man in a black jacket standing outside on the video monitor. He asked, "Excuse me, who are you?"

"I'm looking for Wang Ke. A friend introduced me."

"I'm sorry, if you have business, you can make an appointment with my assistant. At home, I generally..."

"Zhou Ze sent me," the man outside said.

Hearing this name, Wang Ke paused, then opened the door.

The man looked a bit young, maybe twenty-five at most.

"Come in." Wang Ke gestured for him to enter, personally brewing him a cup of tea and placing it on the coffee table.

Zhou Ze sat on the sofa, looking at his old friend.

He hadn't changed, still striving in his profession. As children who grew up together in an orphanage, they had been close since they were young. And in the old director's eyes, the two of them were the most promising of the children who had left the orphanage in recent years.

Zhou Ze had become a deputy director at the hospital at a young age, while Wang Ke already had his own psychological clinic—not some small shop in a cramped location, but one right next to South Street, the heart of downtown Tongcheng.

Even this villa was something no ordinary person could afford.

"You know Zhou Ze?" Wang Ke asked first.

"Yes, he's been dead for half a year," Zhou Ze replied, then picked up the teacup and took a sip. He still liked Maojian tea; his taste hadn't changed.

"What can I do for you?"

"I need to see a doctor."

"See a doctor?" Wang Ke coughed. "You can make an appointment."

"It's urgent." Zhou Ze looked into Wang Ke's eyes. "Very urgent."

Wang Ke fell silent, then smiled and nodded. He stood up and said, "Please come with me to the study."

Regardless of whether the man's sudden visit was impolite, or whether his request was abrupt, since he claimed to be Zhou Ze's friend, Wang Ke had no reason or way to refuse.

Zhou Ze sat properly in Wang Ke's study for a while. Wang Ke returned, having changed into a white outfit, a sign of his seriousness.

"Tell me about your situation." Wang Ke twirled a pen in his hand. It was a dark gold fountain pen, very eye-catching under the study's light.

Zhou Ze slowly shook his head. "Don't try to hypnotize me, not even shallow hypnosis."

Wang Ke nodded and put down the pen.

"I might have... a split personality," Zhou Ze said, choosing his words carefully.

"Be more specific," Wang Ke asked.

"It feels like there's another person's personality inside my body. To be precise, at certain moments, that person's temperament will suddenly influence my actions, and I can clearly sense that those are definitely not things I should be doing. I've always... been a very self-disciplined person."
