"Signs of a split personality?" Wang Ke's eyes narrowed. "How long has this been going on?"

"Just recently."

"How about this? On this piece of paper, draw your second personality. Just go with your gut feeling and draw what he looks like, even if you've never seen his true appearance."

Wang Ke pushed a sheet of white paper and the fountain pen in front of Zhou Ze.

"The second personality?" Zhou Ze asked.

"Yes," Wang Ke nodded.

"But... strictly speaking, I *am* the second personality." Zhou Ze pointed at himself. "The one causing trouble now should be this body's original personality."

Wang Ke's gaze sharpened, and he began to re-examine Zhou Ze.

"You're saying that your current state *is* the second personality?"

"Using your theory to describe it, that should be it," Zhou Ze replied.

The original owner of this body was Xu Le, and Zhou Ze was the outsider. Therefore, Zhou Ze was the second personality.

"You've already killed him?" Wang Ke asked with great interest. He seemed... somewhat excited.

"I suppose so. And I'm certain he's gone," Zhou Ze answered.

"Then what you did is technically murder," Wang Ke reminded him. "Although legally, this kind of act can't be judged, and its nature can't be defined, I still have to sit here and condemn you."

"And after the condemnation?"

"You came to me to find a way to completely rid yourself of the first personality's influence?"

"Yes."

Wang Ke began to twirl the pen again, this time not for hypnosis, but because he was thinking.

"I don't know if I should help you, because from my perspective, you killed a 'person' who originally existed. And if I help you, it would be helping you destroy the evidence, making me an accomplice."

"Help me," Zhou Ze said.

"I need to think about it," Wang Ke said, deliberating.

"No need to think. Help me," Zhou Ze urged. Then, he added, "Brother Erdan."¹

When the name "Brother Erdan" was spoken, Wang Ke's expression changed abruptly. He said with some surprise, "Zhou Ze even told you that?"

Zhou Ze nodded.

Wang Ke looked up, appearing conflicted, but he gritted his teeth and began writing a prescription.

"I'll prescribe you some medicine. These are really just for support, to help you stabilize your mood and aid your sleep."

"Then there's no need to prescribe them," Zhou Ze said.

"The most important step is that you need a change of environment." Wang Ke ignored Zhou Ze's previous words and continued after writing the prescription, "Break away from the social circle your first personality originally lived in and reconstruct your own. Many people think that a person's thoughts reside only in the soul—although whether souls, or ghosts for that matter, truly exist in this world is still unknown. But that statement itself is inaccurate. In fact, our body, our muscles, our eyes, including many other organs, can also store a person's 'soul.' This 'soul' is different from the soul in the broader sense. It refers to things like the 'muscle memory' developed by athletes through countless repetitions, as well as 'psychological suggestions' and so on. You can think of it as a kind of inertia. You are the second personality who killed the first personality, but this body, after all, was operated by the first personality for a very, very long time. It has its own inertia, its own memories. The reason you sometimes suddenly make baffling choices that leave you shocked and surprised afterward, creating the illusion that the first personality still exists and is causing trouble, is because of this. First, sever all your current interpersonal networks and build your own social circle. Let this body begin to re-adapt to you, to counteract the previous inertia, and the problem will be solved. Actually, your current situation isn't serious. Your logical thinking is very clear. Overcoming it is just a matter of time." Wang Ke smiled.

At that moment, there was a knock on the study door.

"Dear, do we have a guest?"

"Yes, bring us two more cups of coffee."

"Okay."

Zhou Ze thought of Dr. Lin, of his parents-in-law, of that sister-in-law.

Indeed,

in the beginning, he had rejected that person's social circle, even wanting to cut ties long ago.

But he didn't know when it started,

*she won't sleep with me anyway,*

that it became an obsession of his.

"How long will it take to sever the ties?" Zhou Ze asked.

"It won't take long." Wang Ke shrugged, looking very relaxed. "I've been observing you since you walked in. The feeling you give me, how should I put it... You are the second personality, but I think you're the most thorough case I've ever seen of a second personality killing the first. It's like... borrowing a corpse to resurrect a soul from ancient tales of the strange and supernatural. It's very clean, very neat, you could even use the word 'perfect' to describe it. Right now, you can think of it as a mild side effect from a medicine you took. You can completely overcome it with your own immune system. Maybe just two or three months. After that, you can pick up your old relationships again without any problem."

Zhou Ze nodded. "Thanks."

"You're welcome."

"Coffee's here."

The study door was pushed open, and a woman walked in carrying two cups of coffee, placing them on the desk.

Zhou Ze looked at the woman, and the woman looked at Zhou Ze.

The next moment,

Zhou Ze's heart suddenly stirred, and the woman's expression also changed abruptly.

"What, you two know each other?" Wang Ke asked.

"Yes, he's Dr. Lin's husband, Xu Le," the woman replied.

"Ah?" Wang Ke stood up in surprise.

He came over to shake Zhou Ze's hand to express his gratitude.

A moment ago, the man before him was a patient introduced by his deceased best friend. Now, he was also the savior of his own daughter. The relationship had naturally grown one level closer.

Zhou Ze responded perfunctorily, his mind actually wondering whether he should warn this best friend of his, who was so devoted to his career, that his wife was recently very engrossed in the indescribable activity of "getting her hair permed."²

After thinking about it, he decided it was best to warn him anonymously after leaving. Although the two of them, knowing each other's personalities after starting their careers, had both thrown themselves into their work and thus didn't disturb each other, the friendship and childhood memories hadn't changed. They never had the habit of just getting together for a drink or tea to chat when they had nothing to do. In fact, if not for this rather tricky problem, Zhou Ze wouldn't have come looking for Wang Ke.

He was married, Zhou Ze didn't know. He had a child, Zhou Ze didn't know. But when help was needed, just mentioning his name was enough for the other to agree.

Wang Ke and his wife walked Zhou Ze to the door. Zhou Ze declined Wang Ke's kind offer to drive him home.

"Dear, what did he come to you for?"

"To see a doctor," Wang Ke replied. "You said he runs a bookstore?"

"Yes, a bookstore that's sort of like a tea party venue."

"Alright then, I'll go check it out when I have the chance."

...

Just as Zhou Ze walked out of the villa's premises,

he suddenly felt something, stopped in his tracks, and turned to look back at the villa.

On the villa's balcony,

stood a little girl.

She was hugging her white teddy bear, wearing red pajamas, standing outside in the wind.

Her hair stirred, her nightgown fluttered, yet she remained perfectly still, seemingly unaware.

But that pair of eyes,

was fixed upon him.

At first, Zhou Ze's expression was grave, his body a little tense.

But slowly, the tension began to fade. The pressure of Xu Le's matter on his mind had also been eased by their recent conversation. Zhou Ze felt very relaxed.

However, what troubled Zhou Ze a little was,

it seemed he didn't just have to warn his best friend about his wife's problem,

his daughter,

seemed to have a problem too.

Silently, in the bottom of his heart, Zhou Ze felt for his best friend,

a pang of pity.

What sins did he commit in a past life to deserve such a "happy and perfect" family?

At this thought, a bitter smile appeared on Zhou Ze's lips.

The next moment, facing the little girl's gaze on the distant balcony,

Zhou Ze raised his hand,

waved in that direction,

and said:

"Hi."

***
**Footnotes:**
¹ *Erdan Ge* (二蛋哥): A rustic and affectionate childhood nickname. "Ge" means "older brother."
² *"getting her hair permed"* (燙頭髮): This is used euphemistically, as a slang term for having an affair.

title: 第二十四章 老道
content:
Leaving the villa district, Zhou Ze didn't rush to hail a cab. Instead, he decided to take a walk alone on the night road.

Wang Ke had said his side of things wasn't a big problem; he just needed to sever Xu Le's old network of connections. Of course, at this point, it was practically severed already.

After the way he had treated Dr. Lin, Zhou Ze figured she wouldn't be speaking to him for some time. As for his in-laws, he hadn't been back for several days either.

The only potential complication was his own bookstore, since the money to open it had come from his wife's family.

He'd just let things be for now. He needed some time to cool down anyway.

Up ahead was a footbridge. Zhou Ze walked up and sat down on one of the steps, took out his phone, and scrolled through it casually.

As chance would have it, Zhou Ze opened that live-streaming app. Xu Le had followed many gaming and "good-looks" streamers, but Zhou Ze wasn't very interested in any of them. Scrolling down, he saw that the old Daoist streamer he had watched last time still wasn't broadcasting.

He hadn't been live for so long; he'd probably quit for good.

The streaming industry seemed easy—making money while sitting at home—but the pressure was immense. Forget one or two months of not streaming; even a few days off could make you yesterday's news.

Just then, however, Zhou Ze noticed an unread message in his account. He tapped it open and saw it was a private message from the old Daoist, sent the day before yesterday.

"This humble Daoist is in Tongcheng. Hey dear, wanna meet up?"

Below the message was the old Daoist's phone number.

Zhou Ze frowned slightly. Besides the message, the old Daoist had also included many little heart emojis. Zhou Ze then checked the profile information for this account of Xu Le's.

It was a female account.

And the location was set to Tongcheng.

Xu Le must have tried her hand at streaming before, so she even had her own stream room, though her popularity was dismal.

Zhou Ze finally understood where that strange feeling was coming from. The old Daoist's message clearly had the vibe of a streamer trying to hook up with his fans. He had come to Tongcheng for some reason, looked up his local fans, and was casting a wide net to see what he could catch.

Zhou Ze wasn't interested in this old Daoist. What he was interested in was the young man who had appeared in the old Daoist's video, the one who had great difficulty drinking porridge.

Still, Zhou Ze sent a reply: his own phone number.

Standing up, he stretched and prepared to leave. He was starting to miss his freezer.

However, his phone rang right at that moment.

He picked it up. The caller ID showed a number from Rongcheng.

Zhou Ze answered the call.

"Hello, Benefactor, where are you!"

The old Daoist's voice was extremely loud, as if he were shouting into the phone's speaker. It sounded like there were trains in the background.

"Where are you?" Zhou Ze asked.

Was this old Daoist really that free? Didn't he have a lot of fans? How did he manage to reply to his message so quickly every time?

Could it be that the "female fan" tag was really that appealing?

"Huh...?" The old Daoist was startled. He fell silent for a moment, not expecting the fan he was planning to meet to be a man!

A... cute girl with a dick!¹

Heartbreak,

Disappointment,

Despair!

But the old Daoist immediately changed his tone, wailing with all his might:

"Big bro, I'm starving! Begging for a few beers and a bite to eat!"

...

Taking a taxi over, Zhou Ze found the old Daoist in a nook under a railway bridge. The man was wearing a filthy Daoist robe, his hair was a mess, and his face was bruised. He looked for all the world like a refugee. He had been lying on a plastic sheet on the ground.

Nearby on the street was a restaurant called "Longtan Homestyle Cooking." Zhou Ze ordered him two bowls of noodles, a plate of Kung Pao Chicken, and a plate of small fried fish. The old Daoist devoured his food with gusto.

"Bro, you're a real one!" The old Daoist finished one bowl of noodles and finally began to slow down. He then told the owner to warm a pot of yellow wine before smiling apologetically at Zhou Ze. He barely had any money left; Zhou Ze would definitely be the one paying for this meal.

"How did you end up like this?" A glass of water sat in front of Zhou Ze. He hadn't touched any of the food on the table.

"Sigh, don't ask." The old Daoist drank a mouthful of noodle soup, smacking his lips. "Luck's been bad lately. I was originally with a film crew that came to Tongcheng to shoot on location."

"Switched careers?"

"I guess. Haven't felt like streaming lately." The old Daoist sighed. "A man's got to have a dream, right?"

"True," Zhou Ze nodded.

"This humble Daoist's dream for the future is to act in a *Mr. Vampire* movie, whether it's part three, four, five, or six, seven, eight." When he spoke of his dream, the old Daoist's entire demeanor seemed to change slightly.

"And you ended up like this from being on a film crew?" Zhou Ze asked, a little curious.

"Heh heh, I was actually a minor supporting actor in the crew, but who knew fate could be so cruel."

The wine arrived.

The old Daoist poured a cup for Zhou Ze first, then filled his own. He took a small sip, his eyes narrowing:

"Tsk tsk tsk, mighty fine, mighty fine."

Zhou Ze picked up his plain water and took another sip.

"The assistant director's a piece of work. He wanted to use the casting couch on a young actress. That girl probably wasn't even eighteen. Sigh, the girl cried, she didn't want to.

"This old Daoist happened to run into them, so I went up and gave that assistant director a beating."

The old Daoist patted his chest and said:

"Making money is making money, getting famous is getting famous, but no matter what we do, we can't go against our conscience, right?

"Tell me, my friend, am I right?"

"Mhm," Zhou Ze grunted. "So you got fired?"

"Nah, he didn't dare use that as an excuse." The old Daoist continued to grin. "Quite a few people knew I beat him up. He wouldn't dare try to get rid of me like that, or his own reputation would be ruined."

"And then?"

"And then, the next night, that young actress I saved walked into the assistant director's room on her own and didn't come out all night."

The old Daoist's voice was full of wistfulness as he said this. "They're all pitiful people. Life isn't easy for any of them."

"And then?"

"And then that young actress claimed I groped her, that I took liberties with her. The assistant director didn't get involved. The main director fired me from the crew." The old Daoist was still smiling, but there was a bitterness in his smile.

"Let's drink," Zhou Ze said.

"Come on, bottoms up!" The old Daoist raised his cup. Seeing that Zhou Ze was holding plain water, he immediately said, "You looking down on me, bro? Let's have a drink. I'm down on my luck today, and I'm grateful for your help. Mountains and rivers will meet again. Sooner or later, when I've got money again, I'll return the favor."

Zhou Ze shook his head. "I'm allergic to alcohol."

"Alright then, tea will do!"

The two clinked their cups, and the old Daoist downed his in one go.

Life’s grievances, frustrations, indignation, inequalities—

All of it was in that one cup of wine.

"You're broke?" Zhou Ze asked, though the question was unnecessary.

"Yeah." After saying this, the old Daoist looked on expectantly, hoping Zhou Ze would lend him some money. He originally had some savings, but he had donated it all at the beginning of the month. Now that he'd been fired from his new job, he was suddenly destitute.

"Oh," Zhou Ze nodded.

"..." The old Daoist suddenly felt a sense of familiarity in the way this person conversed.

*What the fuck*, he thought. *You just say "oh"? Then why did you ask if I had money?*

Zhou Ze stood up, went to pay the bill, and then prepared to leave. Treating the old Daoist to a meal was purely because Zhou Ze was also a bit bored tonight and wanted to find someone to talk to.

He could have gone back to find Xu Qinglang, but Xu Qinglang had closed up early tonight—the roller shutter was already down—so he couldn't find him.

Now, he was tired and wanted to go back and rest.

"Buddy, you run a bookstore?" the old Daoist asked.

"Mhm."

"Bookstores don't make much money, do they?" The old Daoist held out his palm, pinching his fingertips together as if making a calculation.

"Mhm."

"This humble Daoist thinks that opening a spirit shop² is where the real money is." Seeing that Zhou Ze didn't seem interested in his "divination," the old Daoist thought, *Alright, this one was born under the red flag, doesn't give a damn about feudal superstitions,* and dropped the act.

"A spirit shop?" Zhou Ze shook his head. "Don't want to open one."

He was a ghost himself. Why would he open a spirit shop?

"To be honest with you, this old Daoist used to run a spirit shop back in Rongcheng." The old Daoist pulled a wad of bills from his pocket. It was spirit money. "Buddy, thanks for the meal today. I don't have much to give you. Take this stack of spirit money. Don't be in a hurry to curse me out. Of course, you can't spend this money, but it carries yin virtue. Just keep it on you. Don't worry about it being bad luck; it might bring you some good fortune."

Zhou Ze didn't reach out for the money.

Who in their right mind would take a stack of spirit money and put it in their pocket?

"Brother, don't be a skeptic." Seeing Zhou Ze refuse, the old Daoist got anxious. He pulled up his robe and pointed to a scar on the right side of his chest. "Back then, it was a wad of spirit money just like this that saved my life."

"Fine, fine, I'll take it."

Zhou Ze couldn't be bothered to watch a grown man expose his chest in front of him, so he had no choice but to reach out and take the spirit money.

"I remember from your video, there was another person in the spirit shop. That person... had a lot of trouble drinking porridge," Zhou Ze asked.

"Oh, him. He was an employee I hired. Lazy as hell. All he did all day was sunbathe, didn't do a lick of work. I yelled at him every day, telling him he couldn't be so lazy at his young age."

"Oh, does he have anorexia?" Zhou Ze asked.

"Something like that." The old Daoist seemed a bit down when talking about him. "What, is he very handsome?"

"No, he just felt... familiar."

"Familiar my ass," the old Daoist said, as if he'd just heard a hilarious joke.

*You feel a kinship with a ghost? Don't tell me you're a ghost too?*

*Hahahahahaha,*

*You're killing this humble Daoist!*

The two of them walked out of the restaurant together. Zhou Ze offered the old Daoist a cigarette. The supermarket next door was still open, with a small fruit stand at its entrance.

"You stand here and don't move. I'm going to go buy you some oranges," the old Daoist joked.

"I'll just have two. You can have the rest," Zhou Ze replied.

"What?" The old Daoist thought Zhou Ze was a bit out of the loop and didn't get his joke. Finding it a bit dull, he figured this bookstore owner must be a bookworm.

Zhou Ze didn't bother to explain.

In reality, "I'm going to go buy you some oranges, you just stand here and don't move" is what a father says to his son in Zhu Ziqing's famous essay *The Rear View*. The speaker is effectively calling himself the listener's "father."

And Zhou Ze's reply was what a grandfather says to his grandson in Lao She's *Rickshaw Boy*.³

Finally, Zhou Ze reached out and patted the old Daoist on the shoulder. "I'm leaving. Take care."

Just as the old Daoist was about to say something,

He suddenly clutched his crotch.

Then, the smell of burnt hair wafted out.

"Holy mother, it's burning this humble Daoist to death!"

---
¹ **A... cute girl with a dick!**: The original Chinese is internet slang for a "trap" or a male pretending to be a female online.
² **Spirit shop**: A shop that sells joss paper, incense, and other ritual items for honoring the dead or deities.
³ **The orange joke**: The old Daoist's line comes from a famous essay where a father says it to his son before parting, thus jokingly calling Zhou Ze his "son." Zhou Ze's reply is from another classic novel, where a grandfather says it to his grandson, thus one-upping the joke by calling the Daoist his "grandson."

title: 第二十五章 大火
content:
"What's wrong?" Zhou Ze frowned. Clearly, he had smelled it too.

"Nothing, I have to pee. You go on ahead!"

After saying this, the old Taoist immediately turned and ran off.

Zhou Ze looked at his own hand, didn't follow to ask any more questions, and instead hailed a cab back to the bookstore.

The old Taoist reached the side of the road and pulled a paper talisman from his crotch. The talisman had already turned red, and upon meeting the wind, it disintegrated into ash and scattered.

This was an ancestral talisman of the old Taoist's. As for why he kept it in that particular spot, well, that was a secret not to be shared with outsiders.

But that last scene was already seared into the old Taoist's memory.

Of course, looking down at his 'walnuts,'¹ which had been scalded tight together,

it was actually seared onto his flesh as well.

"Holy mother, Boss, I never would've thought I'd run into one of your kind here in Tongcheng, over two thousand kilometers away."

In the great scheme of things,

perhaps there was some kind of connection.

Just like when Zhou Ze watched the old Taoist's livestream video and saw the young man sitting behind the counter of the Spirit Shop, struggling to drink porridge, he'd felt an inexplicable connection.

It wasn't just as simple as anorexia.

In truth,

they were the same kind of person.

In this world, he was not the absolute, one and only, solitary anomaly.

Just as the Faceless Woman in Hell had roared in unwilling fury:

"How can you leave too?"

This implied that,

it wasn't just Zhou Ze; someone else had left from before the Faceless Woman in the past.

Add to that the old man with the black fingernails whom Zhou Ze had saved after the car accident...

This world,

was truly not as peaceful as one might imagine.

..................

By the time he took a cab back to the bookstore, it was already one in the morning. Zhou Ze cleaned up the broken glass on the bathroom floor, then boiled a few kettles of water and managed a makeshift wipe-down with a towel.

He decided he would have someone come install a shower head tomorrow for convenience. For a person with mild mysophobia, not being able to shower was absolute torture.

Returning to the second floor, he set the temperature. Zhou Ze lay down inside it, closed his eyes, and prepared to bid farewell to the day's exhaustion and all its chaos.

He slept soundly and peacefully that night.

The night passed without incident.

When he woke up the next morning, Zhou Ze, emerging from the freezer, first went to wash up, then opened the shop's door and glanced next door.

The shop next door was closed again today.

There was no way to contact Dr. Lin for now.

His wife was gone.

Now he was gone too.

Zhou Ze shook his head sharply. *Damn it, how could I have such a thought?*

*Xu Le's lingering poison is corrupting me.*

Yes,

that must be it.

Having not eaten since last night, Zhou Ze could only take out his phone and order takeout, with a note asking the shop to send extra vinegar.

After about a twenty-minute wait, a young delivery guy in a yellow uniform arrived on an electric scooter. He pushed open the shop door, walked right in, and handed the food to Zhou Ze, who was sitting behind the counter reading a book.

"Thank you. It can't be easy, delivering food during the Lunar New Year," Zhou Ze said politely.

"You've got it tough too, having to eat takeout during the Lunar New Year," the delivery guy shot back.

"..." Zhou Ze.

Zhou Ze felt like he'd taken an arrow to the knee. He looked up and took a good look at the delivery guy in front of him. He was very young, looking to be in his early twenties.

"This is a bookstore?" The delivery guy glanced around the shop. "The kind where you can sit and read? How much?"

"Pay what you think it's worth," Zhou Ze said, opening the takeout bag.

"Deal."

The delivery guy sat down on a plastic stool, found a copy of *Battle Through the Heavens*, and began to read with great interest.

Zhou Ze, meanwhile, downed the vinegar the shop had sent in one gulp. It seemed that thanks to the training from the freakishly sour plum juice at Xu Qinglang's place, ordinary vinegar didn't have much of an effect on him anymore.

Next, he began to wolf down his food. Halfway through, the nausea and urge to vomit began to set in.

Zhou Ze clutched his own throat with both hands, forcing himself not to throw up. Finally, after a terrible standoff, the nausea slowly began to recede. Zhou Ze wiped the corner of his mouth, then started coughing heavily.

"Bro, eat slower. The way you eat... to use my grandma's words, it's like you're a reincarnated hungry ghost."

The delivery guy commented while still reading his book.

Zhou Ze glared at him, then simply sat on the chair, panting. He needed a moment.

*Damn that Xu Qinglang!*

*Why isn't he open yet!*

Zhou Ze decided that if the man still wasn't open by the afternoon, he would have no choice but to break down his door to find the rest of the sour plum juice or bitter melon juice. Otherwise, he really wouldn't be able to get his meals down.

The delivery guy seemed to have stopped taking orders, sitting there and reading his novel for an hour.

"Huh, why do I smell something like burning coal?" The delivery guy suddenly sniffed the air, then walked outside the bookstore.

Zhou Ze didn't think much of it. The guy probably wanted to read for a bit without paying. Whatever.

This bookstore's profits really were up to fate.

But then, the delivery guy who had just stepped outside immediately opened his mouth and shouted:

"Whoa, it's on fire!"

Only then was Zhou Ze jolted to attention. He also walked out of the shop, looked up, and his gaze immediately fixed. On the fourth floor of the building above, thick smoke was billowing out.

That was,

the location of the movie theater!

The only part of the once-bustling commercial center that still had some life was that movie theater. And because it was the New Year holiday, a lot of people had been coming to watch movies.

"Let's go, save people!" The delivery guy immediately sprinted in that direction.

Zhou Ze stood there, hesitating for ten seconds. The fire was definitely serious, but it absolutely wouldn't burn down to his bookstore. He was suppressing the instinct deep inside him to go and help.

He couldn't remember how many times in the past he had rushed to the front lines of a disaster site to participate in rescue efforts. But just recently, he had been planning to break this bad habit.

However, after an intense internal struggle, Zhou Ze still ran after him.

Me...

Still a sucker, I guess!

On the stairs leading from the first to the third floor, many people were running down, while Zhou Ze ran up.

Although this commercial center was "dead," it was located in the city center. The fire trucks should arrive quickly.

There weren't as many people watching movies in the morning as in the afternoon, but the number was still considerable. By the time Zhou Ze ran up the stairs to the fourth floor, he saw that the smoke inside was much thicker, and the flames were burning strangely. Even if it were an accidental fire, it shouldn't be burning this wildly!

But this wasn't the time to analyze the cause. Amidst the thick smoke, Zhou Ze saw the delivery guy, his face blackened by soot, carrying an old woman out.

The guy glanced at Zhou Ze, smiled, revealing a set of white teeth, then turned and ran back toward the theater auditoriums to continue rescuing people.

The fire hadn't completely spread out, but in the auditorium area, the blaze was intense.

Zhou Ze hesitated no longer. Since he was already here, he had to do something. He immediately ran into the thick smoke.

"*Cough cough... cough cough...*"

Without any protective gear, rushing in like this was a foolish act. It was easy to fail to save anyone and end up getting himself killed.

So Zhou Ze knew his time was limited. If he saw someone who needed help, he'd just get them out. He couldn't do much else; he could only wait for professional firefighters to handle the rest.

"*Whoosh...*"

The moment Zhou Ze opened the door to Theater 2, flames shot out directly at him. Zhou Ze had to step back to avoid the worst of it.

And inside, there were still sounds of crying and shouting.

Zhou Ze gritted his teeth and charged straight in. Inside the theater, there were flames everywhere—on the floor, the ceiling, the walls, all on fire. And because of the confined space, the thick smoke produced by the combustion could only billow and fill the room.

In most fire scenes, many more victims die from smoke inhalation than from being burned.

Only at a time like this did people realize how important those annoying fire safety announcement videos before every movie really were.

As soon as Zhou Ze rushed in, he saw two people lying in the small space of the aisle.

One was an adult man in a black suit. He was on the ground, coughing, clearly unable to get up.

The other was a boy of about ten, lying unconscious on the ground, it was impossible to tell if he had just fainted or had already suffocated.

"Save me... save me... save..." The man in the suit managed to lift his head, looking at Zhou Ze standing before him.

Zhou Ze jumped right over him, lifted the little boy onto his back, and prepared to rush out.

He was already feeling dizzy. Clearly, without a gas mask or other professional equipment, he wouldn't last much longer either.

However, just as he was about to run out with the boy on his back, Zhou Ze felt a tug on his leg, and his whole body fell to the ground. The boy on his back tumbled off as well.

"Save... save... me... first... I'll... give you... money... save... me... first..."

The man in the suit used his last bit of strength to grip Zhou Ze's ankle tightly. He knew he couldn't hold on for much longer. He couldn't breathe at all now, and his lungs felt like they were on fire.

Having been pulled down, Zhou Ze felt his head spin, and he nearly passed out. In that instant, he bit down hard on the tip of his own tongue, forcing himself to stay conscious.

"Thump!"

"Thump!"

Zhou Ze used his other foot to kick the man's hand and head.

After several kicks, the man finally let go.

Zhou Ze staggered back to his feet, hoisted the boy onto his back again, and charged out of Theater 2.

As he burst through the billowing smoke and into a safe area, Zhou Ze's knees buckled, and he fell directly to the ground. The boy on his back fell too, but because Zhou Ze had subconsciously cushioned the fall, it wasn't serious.

The firefighters had already arrived and were beginning to extinguish the fire. Another group of firefighters in full gear was charging into the blaze.

"There's still someone in Theater 2."

Zhou Ze grabbed the uniform of a firefighter running past him and said.

"Okay, got it." The firefighter nodded and rushed into the fire.

"*Haaah... haaah...*"

Zhou Ze lay flat on the tiled floor, gasping for air. Opposite him, the delivery guy, his yellow uniform now blackened by soot, was also leaning against the wall, panting. The two made eye contact and managed a weak, exhausted smile.

The paramedics had also arrived, a group of doctors and nurses in white. Zhou Ze didn't have the strength to see if Dr. Lin was part of this rescue operation.

Gritting his teeth, he got up again. Zhou Ze glanced at the boy who was receiving emergency treatment from a doctor. The boy's chest was still rising and falling; he should be fine.

At the same time, Zhou Ze saw several other people being carried out by the firefighters. Some couldn't be saved, while others were. The man in the black suit was lying on a stretcher, motionless. He was probably gone.

Zhou Ze felt no guilt. He had no reason to feel guilty.

He was doing a good deed, saving people, but who he saved first was his decision. No one had the right to morally condemn him.

Besides, at that moment, he had absolutely no ability to carry a child while also hauling an adult man out. If he had tried, the only result would have been him dying in there as well.

The body he had possessed was Xu Le's, a "scholar" with no strength to even truss a chicken, not Schwarzenegger's.

What's more, that guy had almost gotten him killed in the theater too.

He struggled to his feet, refusing the help of a nurse who wanted to check his condition. Zhou Ze walked to the restroom at the other end of the building, turned on the tap, and vigorously splashed cold water on his face.

Finally,

he had caught his breath.

Lifting his head,

Zhou Ze looked at himself in the mirror.

Suddenly, he noticed,

in the mirror, behind him, a faint human figure was slowly appearing.

This person,

was wearing a black suit.

Staring at him with a face full of venomous hatred.

His mouth was open, shouting incessantly, as if questioning him about something, hysterical, frantic, and agitated.

After a person dies, under specific circumstances, there is a certain probability they might turn into a vengeful ghost to seek revenge.

Right now, this man had just died, and his soul was still in the ghost-formation stage. It would likely take full form on the seventh day after his death.

He was not yet a ghost, merely a nascent form.

But because of Zhou Ze's own unique nature, he could perceive the man's existence ahead of time.

He hated him.

For not saving him.

And this hatred was so strong,

it was enough to turn him into a vengeful ghost!

"Heh, interesting."

Zhou Ze smiled.

He lowered his head back into the sink and continued to rinse his face with water.

At the same time, he sighed inwardly:

"Heh, people..."

***

¹A common slang term for testicles.

title: 第二十六章 頭七
content:
According to the Jianghai Evening News (a local Tongcheng newspaper), seven people lost their lives in the movie theater fire, and more than thirty others suffered injuries of varying degrees.

A week had passed. The movie theater had been closed down, and it was impossible for it to reopen anytime soon. It was even likely that the theater would be abandoned altogether. It had already been losing money, so naturally, they wouldn't go through the trouble of a grand reopening.

With that, this commercial complex was basically declared completely dead.

During this time, Zhou Ze hadn't contacted Dr. Lin. Both sides maintained a tacit understanding not to interfere with each other, each living their own life. His father-in-law and mother-in-law, however, had called several times, questioning why Zhou Ze wasn't coming home, saying he'd gotten bold, and so on.

Eventually, Zhou Ze simply blocked their numbers.

The current headache was that his in-laws had paid to open this bookstore. *One's mouth is soft from eating their food, and one's hands are weak from taking their things.*¹ The problem was, Zhou Ze still hadn't figured out a way to earn some money so he could open a new store and be truly independent.

All he could say was that the foundation Xu Le had left him was just too poor.

Several media outlets had contacted him, hoping to interview Zhou Ze about his heroic deed and promote some positive energy for the new era, but Zhou Ze refused them all.

He had no interest in that kind of fame. As the saying goes, a tall tree attracts the wind. Given his identity and role, turning himself into some kind of celebrity would only invite more uncontrollable dangers.

This past week, business had been unremarkable. Daily sales were less than a hundred yuan, not even enough to cover rent and utilities, but Zhou Ze wasn't too concerned about it.

What he was concerned about was that his next-door neighbor, Xu Qinglang, hadn't opened his door in a week.

Zhou Ze hired an unscrupulous locksmith to open the lock. He went inside and searched the place but couldn't find any sour plum juice or anything of the sort. The kitchen in the back room was spotless and very tidy.

It was quite helpless.
A handsome man who owned over twenty properties—
if he suddenly decided to renounce the material world and go chasing the wind, free and easy,
you'd have a really hard time finding him.

And because of that, Zhou Ze's week had been pretty miserable.

Chili oil,
aged black vinegar,
dark soy sauce,
high-concentration orange juice—he had tried them all. Although they allowed him to get some food down, they all made him miserable. The effect was far inferior to Xu Qinglang's family-recipe sour plum juice.

As night fell, Zhou Ze squatted alone at the entrance of his bookstore, a cigarette dangling from his lips. His gaze occasionally drifted next door, giving off a feeling of 'where in this life can one speak of desolation'.

By the road in front of the shop, four or five pagoda incense coils were burning. The people from the shopping center had set them up. According to custom, today was the day to welcome the God of Wealth. Even though they knew the God of Wealth could hardly save this shopping center, they still had to go through the motions.

What if a miracle happened?

Occasionally, Zhou Ze would glance behind him or at his reflection in the glass in front of him. The vengeful ghost of the man in the black suit was continuously taking shape. Tonight was his *touqi*,² so it should be almost complete.

The materialization of a vengeful ghost was an incredibly small probability to begin with. Besides, an ordinary vengeful ghost could at most make you trip while walking or bite your tongue while eating. Making you catch a minor illness that required a two-day IV drip would be considered an impressive feat for a ghost.

The kind of thing you see in movies, where vengeful ghosts run rampant killing people everywhere, could never happen in reality. Otherwise, the world of the living would have descended into chaos long ago.

Even Zhou Ze, who had returned to life in a borrowed body, was keeping such a low profile.
How dare those scumbags who didn't even have a physical body come out and act tough?

This week, whenever he had nothing to do, Zhou Ze would read, space out, trim his nails, and incidentally check if the ghost behind him had become any clearer.
It gave him a feeling of... raising something. He was experiencing 'a father's love, as solid as a mountain'.

*Daddy loves you.*
*Daddy's waiting for you to grow up.*

Zhou Ze could clearly perceive the emotions of the one behind him. His greatest hatred wasn't directed at the cause of the fire, but at Zhou Ze himself. He was resentful, furious, expectant, and waiting.

Perhaps,
in his view, tonight—the day of his *touqi*—was his moment of revenge.

Interesting.
Zhou Ze flicked the ash from his cigarette. After the ghost finished forming, Zhou Ze would show him why the flowers are so red.

As for saving the man, Zhou Ze didn't feel he'd done anything wrong. Nor did he think it was wrong for the man in the suit to hate him.

Previously, Zhou Ze had encountered a similar incident. A person was drowning, and someone went in to save them. In the end, the rescuer was grabbed tightly by the drowning person, and they both drowned.

Generally speaking, when rescuing someone from the water, you have to approach from behind and hold them to pull them out. If you approach from the front, the drowning person will easily latch onto you like a final straw to clutch at.

Of course, he could understand it,
but understanding wasn't a reason for Zhou Ze to allow the man in the suit to run wild in his bookstore at midnight.

During the day, Zhou Ze ordered takeout and chatted a bit with the new delivery guy. He learned that the delivery guy who had helped with the rescue had gotten famous recently. Not only was he attending various award ceremonies, but he had also been commended and rewarded by his company. He now had a nickname: "The Most Handsome Delivery Guy." He was still delivering food, but now he did it while livestreaming, and his popularity was very high.

While eating his meal and chugging aged black vinegar, Zhou Ze casually scrolled through Weibo and actually saw the delivery guy in the trending topics.

A week had passed since the incident. It had moved from the initial phase of handling and summarizing to the current phase of developing and promoting positive energy, placing it at the peak of public discussion. The incident's influence had spread not just in Tongcheng, but throughout the entire country.

At eleven at night, Zhou Ze watched the man in the suit slowly become more solid while also watching a movie. The movie was called *Demon Cop*, a work from a few years ago by the recently famous director Dante Lam, starring Daniel Wu and Nick Cheung.

The bookstore door was pushed open, and the delivery guy, wearing his uniform, walked in while holding a selfie stick.

"This is a bookstore I often come to. After a busy day of delivering food, I always come here to read. Not for any scholarly reason, I just simply like to read."

After speaking, the delivery guy took a copy of Wen Tiejun's *Eight Crises* from the bookshelf.

The book was about China's various economic crises in modern history. The delivery guy opened the book, sat down on a plastic stool, and began to read with great interest.

Zhou Ze remembered that the last time he came, he had read two volumes of *Battle Through the Heavens*.

"Alright, that's all for today's stream. I want to read quietly for a bit. You all should get some rest too. Thanks for keeping me company all day." The delivery guy bowed to his phone screen.

A barrage of subscription notifications, planes, and rockets scrolled across the phone screen. His popularity was indeed terrifyingly high.

Turning off his phone, the delivery guy closed *Eight Crises*, stretched, looked at Zhou Ze, and said:

"Boss, let's go grab a late-night snack. My treat."

Zhou Ze shook his head and pointed at the computer screen in front of him.

"What are you watching?" The delivery guy came closer, glanced at the screen, and laughed. "I've seen this movie. *Demon Cop*, right?"

"Yeah." Zhou Ze nodded, simultaneously checking the time in the bottom right corner of the screen. It was almost midnight.

The "baby" behind him was already getting impatient.

"No reporters came to interview you?" the delivery guy asked.

Zhou Ze shook his head.

"You really should have accepted the interviews. Your bookstore's business would be a lot better."

"I like the quiet," Zhou Ze said, insincerely posturing.

Money is important, but life is more important.

"You can watch the movie later." The delivery guy seemed to feel a connection with Zhou Ze. After all, they were comrades who had rushed into the fire to save people together.
There was a sense of...
mutual admiration, perhaps.

"Did you know? *Demon Cop* is based on a true story. The real-life protagonist was apparently named Tsui Po-ko," Zhou Ze said.

"Heh, I actually didn't know that." The delivery guy smiled a little sheepishly. "It's just a movie, who pays attention to that stuff?"

"Mm, that's true." Zhou Ze shut down his computer and stretched. "It's so late, what do you want to eat?"

"Whatever's fine."

"Then I'll just order some takeout."

"No, let's eat out. My treat. What's so good about takeout? Let me tell you, the back kitchens of some of those places are unbearable to look at. Some businesses don't even have a physical store, they just rent a rundown place and cook there. Tsk tsk, anyway, I wouldn't dare eat it."

"I see." Zhou Ze nodded. "By the way, do you know the story of Tsui Po-ko?"

"If you tell me, won't I know then?"

"He killed his colleague, took the money, and then lived it up. He even participated in a TV show. He liked being in the spotlight, being famous." Zhou Ze rubbed the tip of his nose. "A very complex person. He really enjoyed being on camera."

The delivery guy was silent for a moment, not continuing the topic. Instead, he said, "Boss, are you going for a late-night snack or not?"

"I don't feel like it. Haven't you seen all the pagoda incense coils outside my door? The smoke has been wafting in all day, I've completely lost my appetite."

Pagoda incense coils are those large incense sticks, taller than a person, stacked layer upon layer like a pagoda. They are very thick and can burn for a long time.

"Haha, but your shop doesn't smell at all." The delivery guy pointed to the central air conditioning unit above Zhou Ze's bookstore. "That part, that's an air purifier, right?"

"Yeah, it was installed with the AC. And I'm used to spraying some air freshener in the store. After all, you have to create a bookish atmosphere, right? Since I don't offer coffee or pastries, the least I can do is provide a pleasant scent."

"So, Boss, you're still not going to give me face, huh?" the delivery guy said, pretending to be angry. "We've been through life and death together, you know."

Zhou Ze raised a hand and said curiously, "That's why I've always been curious about something."

"What is it?"

"That day, I didn't smell anything at all. In my shop, it's difficult to smell anything from outside—almost impossible. So how did you smell the fire that day?"

The delivery guy froze for a second, his expression turning a bit unnatural. But he brushed it off and said, "I've had a good sense of smell since I was a kid. My grandma said I had a dog's nose. When I was little, I was always dead on when sniffing out hidden snacks at home."

"Do you know what day it is today?" Zhou Ze asked again.

"What day?"

"The *touqi*."

"*Touqi*?"

"That's right. The *touqi*... for the seven people who died in the fire!"

***

¹ A Chinese idiom meaning one cannot be assertive toward one's benefactors.

² *Touqi* (头七), "the first seventh," is the seventh day after a person's death, a significant day in Chinese funerary traditions when the spirit is believed to return home.

title: 第二十七章 深夜派對
content:
The delivery guy stood still on the other side of the counter, looking at Zhou Ze, who was sitting behind it.

"Don't be scared. The store doesn't have any security cameras, and I don't have a voice recorder," Zhou Ze said, stretching lazily. "Of course, you're definitely not going to believe me. Tsk, suit yourself."

"I don't know what you mean," the delivery guy said calmly.

Someone who could do such a thing would have to be calm.

The police still hadn't identified a specific arsonist, which was a testament to his skill—in a derogatory sense, of course.

"I'm positive that you're the one who set that fire." Zhou Ze spread his hands. He was simply stating a fact, one that was beyond argument.

"You're drunk," the delivery guy said.

"Not drunk."

Zhou Ze smiled.

"And just what are you basing that on, saying I set the fire? You think you're better than the cops?" The delivery guy's expression was beginning to tense up, but he was still restraining himself.

"Sss... Of course I'm not as skilled as the police, but I'm not blind. And as for saying I figured you were the arsonist based on *that*—sorry, but that's not it at all.

"I first confirmed you were the arsonist, and then worked backward to deduce the evidence. Just wanted to see what it feels like to be Conan."

Zhou Ze pointed a finger behind the delivery guy.

The delivery guy whipped his head around, thinking the police were there, but there was no one, nor any sound of sirens.

In this nearly abandoned mall, so late at night, there wasn't even a single person passing by.

"They... all followed you in," Zhou Ze said.

"Who?" The delivery guy frowned.

"The six people who died in the movie theater. They followed you in, and as soon as I saw that, I went, 'Oh.' The killer is you. It's as plain as day.

"Aside from the dope standing behind me who's hell-bent on hating my guts, you can't be telling me the other six victims all got the wrong guy, can you?"

Zhou Ze slowly stood up, looking at the delivery guy before him.

"Stop with the hocus-pocus!" the delivery guy practically roared. For some reason, he felt the pressure mounting, and cold sweat began to bead on his face.

"Don't be nervous. They can't harm you."

Zhou Ze walked out from behind the counter, carrying a plastic bag.

Inside the bag were small boxes of rice and some pickles.

In Zhou Ze's line of sight, six people were sitting on plastic stools—men and women, two of them elderly.

They were all sitting there properly, reading books, quiet and not the least bit disruptive.

Zhou Ze placed a bowl of rice in front of each person. The rice was topped with pickles, and a pair of disposable chopsticks was stuck upright in it.

Then, Zhou Ze took out a bottle of cheap white liquor that cost less than ten yuan, poured it into plastic cups from the water dispenser, and placed a cup in front of each person.

"Hey fellas, life's not easy for me either. This bookstore's been losing money since it opened, so this is all I can offer. Don't mind me being cheap, alright? You guys are dead, but I still have to keep on living.

"Besides, your families will be making offerings to you, so you won't miss this little bit from me, right?"

Zhou Ze bent over, speaking as if he were casually serving customers.

Right. As for that dope behind him with a screw loose, Zhou Ze wasn't feeling charitable enough to leave him a portion.

"Are you fucking sick in the head!" The delivery guy couldn't hold it in anymore. "Ha, I should really record this for you, post it online, and let all my followers see you in this state!"

"You dare?" Zhou Ze asked, turning to the side. "You talk a big game. You've only been streaming for a few days. Even WuWu got taken down."¹

Yes, there were many reasons the police hadn't found the arsonist yet, but if they had a primary suspect to investigate, it would be very difficult for the arsonist to stay hidden.

"I'm leaving. You're crazy."

The delivery guy's friendly demeanor vanished. He had successfully converted his popularity into a livestreaming career and a huge income, not just because he was a "hero," but also because of his own marketing strategy.

He was very down-to-earth, and his original public image was excellent. On that foundation, livestreaming his deliveries, something that should have been tedious and boring, became something people enjoyed watching.

He knew he was panicking, that he'd lost his composure. So he wanted to leave, to flee this bookstore.

He regretted coming here today, regretted it very, very much.

Zhou Ze didn't try to stop him. But, just as the delivery guy reached out to push open the bookstore's door,

Zhou Ze took out his phone, checked the time, and said:

"It's midnight."

"Dong!"

There was no clock hanging in the bookstore, but at that moment, the delivery guy felt as if he had heard a bell toll.

He pushed the door with all his might, but it didn't budge. Enraged, he glanced at the lock. The door wasn't locked, and there was nothing blocking it, but it just wouldn't open.

The delivery guy began kicking the door like a madman, but it remained motionless.

What he couldn't see was that,

The six people who had been sitting and reading,

had all slowly risen to their feet.

The seventh night after death, the night of the soul's return.

Every injustice has a source, every debt a debtor.

They had come here, following their enemy,

and now,

they were all staring daggers at him,

the man who had become a hero after burning them to death.

"This is for not saving me!"

A low growl came from behind Zhou Ze.

Zhou Ze happened to be blowing on his fingernails at that exact moment. He then spun around abruptly, the nails of his right hand instantly growing long, their translucent blackness emitting a strange luster. Wisps of black energy coiled around his fingertips, carrying a terrifying aura.

At the same time, a black mist churned within Zhou Ze's eyes.

"Sssssss... AHHHHHHHHHHHH!!!!!!!!"

The man in the black suit, who had just managed to transform into a vengeful ghost, was seized by the shoulder by Zhou Ze's hand. His entire being began to tremble as the black energy from Zhou Ze's fingertips pierced his body like countless sharp knives. Wisps of green smoke rose from the top of the man's head.

"I understand you, but you disgust me."

Zhou Ze said in a deep voice,

"So, you should just say goodbye."

Zhou Ze's fingers tightened.

The man in the black suit wailed while his expression turned pleading. He hoped Zhou Ze would spare him. He had already become a vengeful ghost; to "die" again would mean his soul would be scattered, without even the chance to enter hell.

But Zhou Ze didn't let go.

His gaze remained ice-cold.

Only after the black-suited man's body had completely melted and evaporated,

did he withdraw his hand. In his palm, faint traces of ash could be seen.

"Hoo..."

Zhou Ze blew on his palm, then clapped his hands together.

Turning back around, Zhou Ze sighed.

He didn't know if it was because of his presence here that the bookstore's feng shui had changed,

or if,

this was just a coincidence.

The six customers who had been reading quietly earlier now had black mist rising from their bodies—a sign they were about to become vengeful ghosts to seek revenge.

Meanwhile, the delivery guy was still relentlessly punching and kicking the wall.

Look up, and see whom the heavens have spared. Perhaps that saying described this very scene.

These six victims had also been in a state of panic and confusion amidst the thick smoke and fire, ultimately failing to escape and dying a miserable death.

"Everyone, do me a favor. Don't be in such a hurry to become vengeful ghosts."

Zhou Ze walked into the middle of the group and raised a hand to the six figures.

"Come on, relax. How about you all give me a smile?"

Zhou Ze wanted to lighten the mood. Once they became vengeful ghosts, they could no longer enter the cycle of reincarnation. After taking their revenge, once their obsession was gone, they would simply dissipate into the wind.

That was the most tragic ending.

Zhou Ze felt it wasn't worth it, truly not worth it.

The arsonist had already caused your deaths, separating you from your loved ones forever. Your children lost a father or mother, your parents lost a child.

There was no need to push yourselves into an even more terrible abyss because of the same murderer.

However, Zhou Ze's words had no effect.

The faces of the six people remained frigid, and the black mist around them grew thicker. Black lines began to spread from the corners of their eyes and lips.

They were about to look like that dopey man in black had when he charged at him.

"Since you won't smile for me, how about I smile for you?"

Zhou Ze forced a very ugly smile.

It was over.

What a disaster.

They couldn't be saved.

Zhou Ze knew it would be easy for him to obliterate these vengeful ghosts, just like that dope who had been following him for a week and got slapped to death the moment his cooldown ended and he was about to use his ultimate move.

But as for delivering these souls from suffering, he truly had no idea how to do it. Besides, Zhou Ze was a ghost himself, which made it inconvenient for him to perform such a task—it was like asking Zhang Fei to do embroidery.

"The netherworld has a path, the Yellow Springs can be crossed!"

A sharp cry came from outside. Immediately after, the bookstore door was pushed open. Xu Qinglang walked in, holding a small porcelain bowl filled with rice grains, in which three sticks of incense were inserted.

"Rise!"

The three incense sticks burned down rapidly.

At the same time, the rice grains in the bowl turned from a crystalline white to black, while the black mist around the six figures began to fade. Finally, their expressions shifted from their initial cold and murderous look to one of peace and tranquility.

The six people slowly sat back down in front of their respective bowls and chopsticks.

"Xu Qinglang!" Zhou Ze shouted, pointing at him.

He was excited.

Truly excited.

More excited than when he saw Doctor Lin coming out of the bath.

Just think about how difficult it had been for him to eat this past week.

How could he not be excited!

As for Xu Qinglang's performance just now, Zhou Ze wasn't surprised. In fact, everyone had probably known the truth all along and just hadn't said it out loud.

Xu Qinglang shot Zhou Ze a look, and for a moment, he was overwhelmingly charming, like a mountainside of azaleas bursting into bloom.

But at the same time, he said irritably:

"Are you hosting a Chinese New Year midnight party here?"

"It's not like I wanted to," Zhou Ze said, briefly explaining the situation to Xu Qinglang.

Xu Qinglang nodded to show he understood. He clasped his hands and bowed to the six figures.

"Everyone, it is the seventh night of the soul's return. You should go back and see your loved ones. They should be at home waiting for you. As for what happened here, I will give you a proper resolution."

Hearing this, the six figures silently passed through the glass and left.

Zhou Ze's gaze, however, was fixed on the bowl of "black rice."

"How come this stuff has no effect on me?"

The corner of Xu Qinglang's mouth twitched. He fought back the urge to leap up and fight three hundred rounds with Zhou Ze.

He huffed:

"You're different."

He was still angry, still held a grudge against Zhou Ze, still felt it was unfair. But because of his looks, his temperament, and his voice, the words "You're different" carried the deep resentment of a lady locked away in her boudoir.

Then,

Xu Qinglang looked at the delivery guy, who had fainted in the corner. "What do we do with him?"

As he spoke, Xu Qinglang made a throat-slitting gesture.

Zhou Ze shook his head.

And said:

"We should hand him over to the country."

---
¹A reference to Lu Benwei (盧本偉), a top-tier Chinese streamer also known as "55Kai," who was permanently banned from streaming, serving as a cautionary tale about the precariousness of a streaming career.

title: 第二十八章 你想……接替我麼？
content:
周澤最後報了警，警察很快來了，按照周澤的說法，是說這位外賣小哥來到自己店裡後忽然發了瘋，說有很多被他燒死的人亡魂來找他復仇，然後不停地對著牆壁狂踹狂砸最後暈厥了過去。



  從警局做完筆錄出來時，天都已經亮了，影院縱火案，一波三折，但現在至少打開了局面，之前警方很可能只是因為燈下黑的緣故，沒有懷疑到見義勇為的外賣小哥身上，現在哪怕還沒有確切的證據，但只要真的將目光落在對方身上進行查找，應該很快就能發現真相。



  至於之後輿論的轉向，網上吃瓜群眾的顛覆以及那些曾給這位外賣小哥刷禮物的目瞪口呆，就不是周澤需要擔心和思考的問題了，他能做的，也就只有這麼多，願意做的，也就只有這麼多。



  鬼的事兒，還是交給鬼來解決，人的事兒，還是交給警察來解決為好。



  站在警局門口，呼吸著清晨新鮮的空氣，頭腦頓覺清醒。



  打車回到店裡時，周澤看見隔壁許清朗的店已經重新開門營業了，許清朗本人換了一身平常點的衣服坐在店鋪門口一邊擇菜一邊曬著太陽，嘴裡還哼著「童子戲」（地方曲種）小調，悠哉悠哉，自有一股子風流韻味流淌出來。



  一切，



  仿佛依舊。



  周澤走到店裡，許清朗拍了拍手，問道：「吃啥？」 



  「隨便吧，我要酸梅汁。」



  許清朗點點頭。



  周澤在店裡坐了下來，手指輕輕地敲擊著桌面。



  不一會兒，許清朗端上來一碗雞蛋面，麵湯清澈，麵條筋道，當然，這些都不重要，最重要的是，熟悉的酸梅汁，又出現在了周澤面前。



  「給我做一桶吧，多少錢？」周澤指了指店裡的飲水機水桶，「先做一桶。」



  「等過陣子吧。」許清朗在周澤面前坐下來，嘴裡叼著一根煙，他似乎很想做出一副小痞子抽菸吊啊吊的姿態，但偏偏給人一種「女人抽菸也能這般美麗」的違和感。



  他不娘，也不gay，只能怪老天給錯了皮囊。



  就著酸梅汁吃完了面，破天荒地，這次吃碗麵後周澤的噁心感不再那麼強烈了，但依舊多喝了好幾杯水緩了緩。



  「記得林黛玉初進賈府吃飯後遇到什麼事兒麼？」許清朗吐出一口煙圈問道。



  周澤想了想，明白了過來。



  林黛玉初入賈府，第一頓家宴，飯畢後，下人送上茶湯，林黛玉在家裡被父親教導過飯後不宜飲茶容易消化不良，但見賈母和諸多姐妹都喝了，她也只能跟著一起喝。



  「我能吃飽了就行。」周澤搖搖頭，以他現在這個情況，很可能這輩子是做不成一個老饕或者美食家了，至於消化問題，再說吧。 



  「我心裡有些不平衡。」許清朗開門見山地說道，「我父母，走了。」



  許清朗父母早就走了，但周澤清楚許清朗這次說「走了」是什麼意思，應該是下去了。



  「怎麼忽然就走了？」周澤問道，本想回應一個「節哀」，想想，不合適。



  「被發現了。」



  周澤拿煙的手微微一抖，



  被發現了？



  周澤記得那個老者在臨死前，也曾喊過「他們發現我了！」



  許清朗看著周澤，「我很不甘心，也很不平衡，為什麼她帶走了我父母，卻不帶走你。」



  「他？她？」周澤腦海中浮現出了那個小蘿莉的形象，再結合許清朗那日的狀態和晚上的離開，就猜出了七七八八。



  「她，不可能吧。」



  「陰司有序，亡者上路！」許清朗壓低了聲音，盯著周澤的眼睛，「長舌化路引，深喉許幽冥，熟悉麼？」



  「黑白無常？」



  「那只是一個統稱。」許清朗嘆了口氣，「但他們確實是執法者，遊歷陽間，肅清秩序，將人和鬼，區分開來。人有人間道，鬼有奈何橋。」



  「哦。」



  周澤還是有些不太相信，如果小蘿莉真的是白無常那種的身份，那她之前在校車上顯露出真身吐出長舌頭導致車禍和那位司機的死亡該怎麼算？ 



  「她沒帶走我，反而帶走你父母，所以，你恨我？」周澤伸手指了指自己。



  「對。」許清朗點頭道。



  「那這面里沒下毒吧？」



  「…………」許清朗。



  「沒下毒吧？」周澤又問道。



  「沒。」許清朗回答。



  「那就好。」周澤並不知道，在那天的回鍋肉蓋澆飯里，飯菜里是下了毒的，若不是那天林醫生來得早了一些，可能自己真得吃下那頓飯。



  「你是真傻還是假傻？」許清朗有些沒好氣地看著周澤，「她為什麼不抓你？」



  「對啊，她為什麼不抓我？」周澤也問道。



  「我問你呢！」許清朗提高了聲音。



  「我也不知道。」周澤攤攤手，「可能，是因為我救了她一次吧。」



  「…………」許清朗。



  兩個人的談話，最後以菸頭燒滅了作為終止符。



  雙方這次算是開門見山了，打破了原本的那種默不作聲地默契。



  周澤走回自己的店裡，收拾地上的塑料板凳時，卻發現有六張塑料板凳下面都貼著厚度不均的冥鈔。



  這是看書錢還是吃飯錢？ 



  周澤記得前陣子那個開直播的老道也曾給自己一沓冥鈔，說是能積攢陰德，那麼，他的那些冥鈔就是以這種方式弄來的麼？



  他是怎麼弄過來的？



  周澤將冥鈔都收集起來，整整一沓，手感不錯，沒有平日裡見到的那些冥鈔的粗糙，摸在手裡，有絲綢的觸感。



  這讓周澤想到了老道所說的冥店，和鬼做生意，最好的店鋪當然是冥店，因為那裡賣的東西，也都是給死人的。



  也因此，如果自己手中現在拿的冥鈔是死人的「鈔票」，那麼開冥店，肯定能比自己賺得更多。



  腦海中，再次浮現出視頻畫面里坐在櫃檯後面艱難喝粥的男子，



  周澤忽然覺得，



  自己好像發現了一件可能會很有趣的事情。



  當然，再有趣的事兒，現在也沒精力去管了，昨晚一宿沒睡，現在既然回來了，就得好好地補一個覺。



  周澤將書店捲簾門給拉了下來，上了鎖，不知道為什麼，他的書店正在變得晚上開門的時間比白天多，或許，自己以後有機會可以再訂做一個牌子，



  叫



  「深夜書屋。」



  反正白天也沒什麼生意，書店也一直在虧損著，自己可以隨意地玩一些噱頭，搞一些事情，最爛最壞的結果也不就是現在這個樣子唄。 



  外賣小哥的事兒是罪大惡極的錯誤，但也給周澤一些啟發。



  衛生間的洗澡設備已經被裝了起來，周澤買的是電熱水器，脫去衣服，周澤洗了一個澡，換上了一套干整的衣服上了樓。



  當周澤彎下腰準備調置冰櫃溫度時，整個人卻愣在了那裡，



  因為在他面前的冰櫃裡，



  躺著一個人。



  對方閉著眼，像是陷入了沉睡，呼吸平穩，雙手交叉放在胸前，有著一種小大人似地安逸。



  很平靜，也很可愛，



  前提是，



  她的舌頭如果不會變得那麼長的話。



  小蘿莉，



  把自己的巢穴給鵲巢鳩占了。



  周澤很想大喊一聲，讓隔壁的許清朗同學過來復仇。



  但想想還是算了，不是他覺得把許清朗喊來復仇是害了他，而是他認為許清朗也沒那個膽子過來復仇，說不定人家來了他還會親切地問候一聲：



  「您醒了啊？



  您想吃點什麼？



  我給您去做。」



  小蘿莉睜開了眼，她的眸子很深邃，不再是以往見面的清澈和單純。 



  對方伸出手，周澤幫忙把冰櫃蓋子打開。



  小蘿莉從裡面坐起來，周澤注意到了，她其實沒有設置溫度，只是選擇了一個通風換氣。



  「你躺在這裡，不冷麼？」坐在冰櫃裡的小蘿莉開口問道，沒等周澤回答，小蘿莉又開口道：「哦，我忘了，你不一樣。」



  說完，坐在冰櫃裡的小蘿莉伸手輕輕拍了拍自己身邊的空位置，一臉天真無邪地看向周澤：



  「一起睡不？」



  周澤伸手想要揉一揉這個女孩兒的頭，但手在旁邊，卻停了下來。



  她是黑白無常一類的存在，是陰司在人間的執法者。



  小蘿莉伸手，她的小手抓住了周澤的大手，把周澤的手按在她的頭上，然後按著周澤的手在自己頭上來回揉了揉。



  「…………」周澤。



  「你，很好。」小蘿莉終於從冰櫃裡站起來，但似乎因為腿短的原因，爬出來有些困難。



  周澤將她從冰櫃裡抱出來，



  也不知道她之前是怎麼躺進去的。



  「你，很好。」小蘿莉伸手指著周澤，「重複道。」



  「額……謝謝。」周澤不知道該如何回復了。 



  「我要走了。」小蘿莉轉過身，背對著周澤，雙手交叉負於身後，周澤知道她是想表現出一種高山仰止的氣質。



  但她的問題和許清朗一樣，



  老天給錯了皮囊。



  她這個樣子，怎麼都覺得好可愛。



  憋住，



  不准笑。



  周澤在不停地提醒自己，



  這是黑白無常老爺，



  不准笑！



  哈哈哈哈哈！



  但還是忍不住啊！



  作死了哈哈哈！



  完蛋了哈哈哈！



  憋得越狠笑起來就越誇張，連眼淚都滴出來了。



  小蘿莉沒理會周澤的笑聲，也沒治周澤一個大不敬之罪，



  只是問道：



  「你想，接替我麼？」

title: 第二十九章 過分麼？
content:
"You want to... take my place?"

This question stunned Zhou Ze.

What did that mean?

To go from being an undocumented person, hiding all over the city, to suddenly becoming a local civil servant?

The pleasant surprise came too suddenly.

Zhou Ze was a little afraid to accept.

Pies do fall from the sky, but most people who run into such things end up being crushed to death by the pie.

Most importantly, Zhou Ze didn't think that saving her life once was worthy of such a reward.

After all, the matter with that driver still hadn't been cleared up. This little loli was very adorable, but that was just her skin.

Xu Qinglang had said she once appeared in his shop, stuck out her tongue without a word, and collected the souls of his parents.

No matter how Xu Qinglang cried and begged, she remained completely unmoved.

You couldn't expect someone like that to repay a debt of gratitude; you should thank your lucky stars if she didn't turn around and bite you.

As an Underworld Emissary,

How many partings of joy and sorrow had she witnessed?

How much of humanity's evil?

How much of the ghosts' venomous resentment?

She was not a simple little girl, nor could she be.

"What, not talking anymore?" the little loli asked again.

"I don't know what to say. Are you just asking casually?" Zhou Ze asked cautiously.

"You can say no," said the little loli.

Then, silence.

The little loli added, "And then, I'll drag you down."

"..." Zhou Ze.

Alright then.

Isn't that much more straightforward?

Who needs multiple-choice questions?

Just fill in the blank.

The question was basically: write "Y" for the answer, or get shot.

"I agree," Zhou Ze replied. This time, there was no hesitation, no indecision.

The little loli turned around and smiled, looking somewhat innocent and pure. Then she slowly walked over to Zhou Ze, wanting to straighten his collar like a grown-up.

This seemed to be a gesture a superior would use to show favor to a subordinate, a bit like an ancient emperor granting a minister the chance to dine with him.

It was just that the little loli was too short. Standing in front of Zhou Ze, she couldn't reach his collar, so she could only help him adjust his belt.

"Pick me up," the little loli pouted, commanding him.

Zhou Ze bent down and picked her up.

The little loli reached out to straighten Zhou Ze's collar, then frowned, seeming to feel that being held by Zhou Ze like a daughter was rather inappropriate.

"Do I look really stupid like this?"

"Very cute."

The little loli raised her small hand, intending to slap Zhou Ze's cheek.

In that instant, the fingernails of the hand Zhou Ze was using to hold the little loli grew long and black, and black vortexes swirled deep within his eyes.

The little loli stopped, a meaningful smile playing on her lips.

Zhou Ze didn't make any further moves either.

"Do you know that showing anger and defiance in front of me is a very foolish thing to do?" the little loli asked.

"Doesn't matter. I'm already someone who's died once."

"That's because you were lucky. You only walked a small part of the Yellow Springs Road before you left. You've never experienced the pain and torture of the journey through hell!" the little loli said in a loud voice. "That kind of torment would make everyone who committed suicide and went to hell regret it endlessly! 'Better to be alive and wretched than dead' is by no means an empty platitude."

"Is that so?"

"Put me down."

Zhou Ze put the little loli down.

The little loli leaned back slightly, looking at Zhou Ze. "Do you know why I chose you?"

Zhou Ze shook his head.

"Because you're very smart. Or rather, you're very placid; you know your limits." The little loli counted on her fingers. "The Underworld has its order, and the mortal world has its laws. There are quite a few who sneak out for all sorts of reasons, but you're the most placid one I've ever seen."

"I don't believe that's the real reason," Zhou Ze said.

"The real reason, I don't want to tell you." The little loli stretched. "I'm tired. I want to go down. So, I happened to run into you, and you won't cause me too much trouble, so I picked you.

"Heh, a while ago in Rongcheng, there was this guy who caused a huge ruckus. He was clearly just a pathetic stowaway, yet he fancied himself a judge. A ghost, yet he deluded himself into thinking he could exercise his own judgment in the mortal world. Don't you think he was an idiot?"

"An idiot," Zhou Ze replied. Then, he suddenly remembered that the old Daoist priest seemed to be from Rongcheng. "What happened to him?"

"He was taken out of the picture."

The little loli tilted her head, a look of pure innocence on her face. "The rules are flexible, but for those who cross the line too brazenly, there's no hope at all."

"He died?" Zhou Ze asked. "I mean, was he dragged back to hell, or did his soul scatter to the winds?"

Hearing this, a hint of displeasure appeared on the little loli's face, as if he had touched a raw nerve.

"That, you don't need to know."

The little loli grabbed Zhou Ze's hand, placing her small palm against his.

Immediately, Zhou Ze felt a searing heat in his palm. When the little loli moved her hand away, Zhou Ze saw a black sigil had appeared in the center of his palm.

The sigil wasn't complex; it looked like an eye.

"The Underworld has its order, the Yellow Springs can be crossed," the little loli said very seriously. "Those who should go down, you send them down. Those who should be dispersed, you can disperse them directly.

"Of course, if you want to 'see injustice on the road and let out a roar,'¹

"that's fine too.

"But you'll have to bear the consequences yourself.

"If you screw up, you deal with it."

The little loli yawned, as if she were tired.

"You said you're tired, so how long will you be resting? Is this... like I'm covering your shift?" Zhou Ze asked.

"We'll talk when I get back," the little loli said, preparing to go downstairs.

Zhou Ze continued to ask, "So what do I have to do? Go out on patrol every night?

"Look for ghosts?

"And then,

"deal with ghosts?"

"The door is in your hands; you can figure it out. You can keep running your bookstore. You're a ghost, a ghost possessing a corpse. Those filthy things and all that other riff-raff will naturally flock to you.

"To them, you're a candle in the night, and they're the moths.

"Furthermore, after I left that mark on you, it's like I upgraded you from a candle to an incandescent lightbulb, bright enough to blind their damn dog eyes."

"..." Zhou Ze.

The little loli went downstairs, and Zhou Ze followed.

"I'll read for a bit, then I'll be going. This body's mother will be here to pick her up soon."

The little loli sat down on a plastic chair and casually picked up an illustrated book to flip through.

Zhou Ze stood beside her, not to wait on her, but because he had some questions to ask.

"Go on, ask," the little loli said.

"Is there... a salary?" Zhou Ze asked. "You know, this business of mine is a money-losing venture."

"The economy's in a slump. Money from the living is getting harder and harder to earn these days," the little loli lamented.

"Yeah, it is," Zhou Ze agreed.

"Then just earn money from the dead."

"Can't spend money from the dead," Zhou Ze shrugged.

"That's because you're not doing it right." The little loli held out her hand. "Bring me some spirit money. The kind that... the dead give you."

Zhou Ze took out a stack of spirit money and placed half of it in the little loli's hand.

"You've earned quite a bit," the little loli glanced at it and smiled.

Zhou Ze didn't mention that half of it was from the old Daoist priest from Rongcheng. Inexplicably, Zhou Ze felt that letting this little loli know about it would bring him trouble.

The little loli took the money, pushed open the bookstore door, and squatted down by the roadside.

"Lighter."

Zhou Ze handed her the lighter.

The little loli burned the spirit money, and the ashes were quickly blown away by the wind.

Then, the little loli stood up and clapped her hands. "Alright."

Zhou Ze stood in the wind, feeling a bit disoriented.

"Is this an advance deposit into my account at the Underworld bank?"

"Just wait and see. This place of yours... still doesn't have enough human traffic." The little loli and Zhou Ze, one big and one small, stood waiting at the shop entrance for about half an hour.

The wind had blown the little loli's delicate face a little red. Zhou Ze wasn't afraid of the cold, but standing by the roadside looking around like a pair of idiots felt very strange.

Finally,

a pot-bellied man walked past them. Then, a wallet fell from the man's pocket. He didn't notice at all and kept walking.

Zhou Ze went to pick up the wallet and found it contained several thousand yuan, along with an ID card, bank cards, and other things.

"Should I go return it to him?" Zhou Ze asked tentatively.

The little loli burst out laughing with a "pfft."

"That man has a guilty conscience. Consider this him spending money to avert disaster. This money is rightfully yours."

The little loli pushed open the door and entered the bookstore, then rubbed her hands together. Clearly, she had gotten quite cold during that half hour; it was warmer inside the bookstore.

Zhou Ze walked in with the wallet, asking in disbelief, "He won't call the police?"

"This money, you can take it. It won't burn your hands at all," the little loli said, a little impatiently.

"Alright. So in the future, if I'm short on cash, I can just stand at the door and burn spirit money, and someone will deliver money to me?"

Zhou Ze didn't know whether to laugh or cry, but he also found it interesting.

Just then, Xu Qinglang walked over, carrying a large bottle of sour plum juice.

"Hey, these are all the ingredients I have in the shop, this is all I could make. For the rest, you'll have to wait..."

Xu Qinglang had just pushed open the door and come in when he saw the little loli sitting there. He stumbled, and the bottle in his hand fell to the floor, shattering into pieces.

Sour plum juice splashed all over the bookstore floor.

Zhou Ze looked at Xu Qinglang, signaling him to control himself.

The little loli seemed to completely ignore Xu Qinglang's existence.

Indeed, a person who was lucky enough to have some knowledge of the mystic arts was really not worth a second glance from her.

"Whose daughter is this? So cute, hahahaha. Come, little friend, uncle has a tank of little goldfish at home, want to come home with uncle to see them?"

Xu Qinglang's smile was very awkward, forced out.

The little loli just spat out a single word: "Scram."

Xu Qinglang smiled again, turned around, and went back to his own shop.

"Do you think I'm being unreasonable?" The little loli looked up at Zhou Ze.

"A little," Zhou Ze said honestly.

"Then what if I also told you that the driver's death was just because I was bored on the school bus at the time, revealed my true form, and wanted to play a joke?

"Would you think that...

"...was even more out of line?"

The little loli tilted her head, looking at Zhou Ze with a blank, adorable expression.

***

**Footnotes:**

1.  A famous heroic line from the theme song of *The Water Margin*, one of China's Four Great Classical Novels. It means to stand up and act against injustice.

title: 第三十章 biu！
content:
"Is that going too far?"

This was a question Zhou Ze couldn't answer. Whether the little loli was telling the truth or not, he had no standing to question her further.

It was frustrating, but it was the truth.

Although he’d heard from the Rongcheng loli about that "fellow" in Rongcheng who, as a ghost,妄图 attempted to become the judge of the mortal world...

Zhou Ze was envious and full of admiration, but that ghost’s end was also a lamentable one.

When you lack the capital and the power to stand on the same level as the other party, you don't even have the right to an equal conversation. Where would the right to interrogate come from?

"Boring." The little loli shook her head, but then she smiled. "But that's precisely what I admire about you."

The little loli continued to hold the book in both hands as if she were about to fall asleep, and murmured:

"You're the one person I've met who truly knows their own damn place."¹

"..." Zhou Ze.

Was that a compliment or an insult?

"I have to go." The little loli was getting sleepier and more fatigued.

"I have one more question. Eating and sleeping—is there really no other way to solve or improve these issues?" This was the question Zhou Ze most wanted to ask, the problem he was most desperate to solve.

Since his return by borrowing a corpse, he could perfectly integrate into society, except for these two problems.

"In terms of stability, an assembled computer is never as good as a pre-built one." The little loli shook her head weakly. "As for sleeping, unless you have a creature of Yin from Hell next to you, providing an environmental magnetic field similar to that of Hell, you simply can't rest.

"You are originally a person of Hell. Lingering in the mortal world is like being unable to acclimate to a new environment—and the most severe case of it. Because you're a bit special, you can still rely on special methods to manage. Others can't sleep at all. Half a year without sleep would drive them mad, or even kill them!

"So, you're already considered lucky."

The little loli let out a couple of weak "hehe"s. "If I weren't going back, you could just hold me while you sleep."

"..." Zhou Ze.

"As for eating, I still can't get used to the food of the mortal world."

After saying this, the little loli's head tilted to the side, and she fell directly into a deep sleep. Zhou Ze reached out and steadied her. Seeing that she was still breathing and her body was normal, he breathed a sigh of relief.

Zhou Ze used to be a doctor, so he could naturally tell the girl was fine.

This little one was Wang Ke's daughter; he couldn't just watch something happen to her.

However, what disappointed Zhou Ze a little was that the scene of the little loli's departure was a bit too ordinary.

"Shouldn't she have vanished into the ground with a 'biu' sound? Is just falling asleep considered going back?" Zhou Ze muttered to himself.

It wasn't grand, and there was nothing to see, just like drawing a talisman on his own palm.

No sense of ceremony at all, no flair.

The little loli in his arms suddenly opened her eyes and said, "Alright."

Zhou Ze froze for a moment. She was faking it!

The next moment, a cloud of Yin energy so thick it seemed about to condense into droplets surged from the little loli's body. Even with the central air conditioning on, the temperature in Zhou Ze's bookstore plummeted in an instant.

The door was closed, but gusts of cold wind whipped through the room, accompanied by the sound of book pages flipping.

A vast shadow covered the area, like the awakening of a ferocious beast, bringing with it a pressure only ghosts could perceive.

Stimulated by this, Zhou Ze's fingernails grew out again, and he felt his blood surge as if the power within his body was responding to hers.

And then,

It really was,

with a "biu,"

all the Yin energy instantly rushed into a single point in the ground.

In a flash,

the clouds dissipated,

the temperature returned to normal,

the sun shone through.

In that daze, it seemed to truly echo the line:

*Like birds to the woods when food is gone, leaving a vast, white, and truly clean land!*²

***

In the evening, Xu Qinglang brought dinner. The plum juice was gone, replaced by bitter melon juice.

"The... uh... 'sour-sweetie' juice³ is gone. Make do with bitter melon juice for now."

Xu Qinglang said, a little embarrassed. During the day, seeing the little loli had scared him witless.

In truth, he understood that he was a coward and quite useless.

When the little loli had taken his parents' souls, he didn't dare to confront her for revenge, much less resist. He could only kneel there and beg like a weakling.

Moreover, he had even redirected his anger toward Zhou Ze, attempting to poison his food.

Now, Xu Qinglang had come to terms with it. So what if he was a coward? He was just a minor mystic who happened to have Yin-Yang Eyes due to his physical constitution. He really didn't have the guts to face a Hell emissary.

In fact, the little loli could have punished him for privately detaining his parents' souls—deducting his mortal lifespan or even dragging his soul out and taking it back to Hell.

She had treated him like a fart in the wind and just let him go.

There was no need for him to keep making a fuss.

The dead can't be brought back to life, and his previous actions were indeed a violation of the heavenly dao.

After finishing his meal, Zhou Ze placed a thousand yuan in front of Xu Qinglang.

"This is for the previous meals, plus for future ones. Let me know when it runs out."

"Yo, got money now?" A slight smile finally appeared on Xu Qinglang's face. He then pushed the money back towards Zhou Ze and said softly, "Life isn't easy. Don't be a big spender. You have to think of your home."

"..." Zhou Ze.

"I'm a man with over twenty properties. I look down on your little bit of money."

"..." Zhou Ze.
